00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.934
willing to fly against ours.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.934
So that overmatched capability
creates problems --

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.934
catastrophic successes
the White House calls them.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.934
(Laughter)

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.934
And we're trying to figure that out,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.934
because it is an amazing capability.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.934
The question is, what's the good
you can do with it?

00:01:57.958 --> 00:01:59.934
OK?

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:03.934
The theory of anti-access, area-denial
asymmetrical strategies --

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.934
gobbledygook that we sell to Congress,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.934
because if we just told them
we can kick anybody's asses

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.006
they wouldn't buy us
all the stuff we want.

00:02:11.030 --> 00:02:14.934
So we say, area-denial, anti-access
asymmetrical strategies

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.934
and their eyes glaze over.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.934
(Laughter)

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.934
And they say, "Will you
build it in my district?"

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.934
(Laughter)

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:28.934
(Applause)

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:29.934
Here's my parody and it ain't much of one.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:30.934
Let's talk about a battle space.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.934
I don't know, Taiwan Straits 2025.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.934
Let's talk about an enemy embedded
within that battle space.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.934
I don't know, the Million Man Swim.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.934
(Laughter)

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:44.101
The United States has to access
that battle space instantaneously.

00:02:44.125 --> 00:02:47.934
They throw up anti-access,
area-denial asymmetrical strategies.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.934
A banana peel on the tarmac.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:50.934
(Laughter)

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.934
Trojan horses on our computer networks

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.934
reveal all our Achilles' heels instantly.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.934
We say, "China, it's yours."

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.934
Prometheus approach, largely
a geographic definition,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.934
focuses almost exclusively
on the start of conflict.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.934
We field the first-half team in a league

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.934
that insists on keeping score
until the end of the game.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.934
That's the problem.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.934
We can run the score up against anybody,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.387
and then get our asses
kicked in the second half --

00:03:14.411 --> 00:03:16.934
what they call fourth generation warfare.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.101
Here's the way
I like to describe it instead.

00:03:19.125 --> 00:03:21.934
There is no battle space the U.S.
Military cannot access.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.934
They said we couldn't do Afghanistan.
We did it with ease.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.934
They said we couldn't do Iraq.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.934
We did it with 150 combat
casualties in six weeks.

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:33.934
We did it so fast we weren't
prepared for their collapse.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.934
There is nobody we can't take down.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.934
The question is, what do
you do with the power?

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.149
So there's no trouble
accessing battle spaces.

00:03:41.173 --> 00:03:43.934
What we have trouble accessing
is the transition space

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.934
that must naturally follow,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
and creating the peace space
that allows us to move on.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.054
Problem is, the Defense
Department over here

00:03:52.078 --> 00:03:54.078
beats the hell out of you.

00:03:54.784 --> 00:03:56.499
The State Department over here says,

00:03:56.523 --> 00:03:58.523
"Come on boy, I know you can make it."

00:03:58.934 --> 00:04:00.934
And that poor country runs off that ledge,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.934
does that cartoon thing and then drops.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:08.934
(Laughter)

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.934
This is not about overwhelming
force, but proportional force.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.934
It's about non-lethal technologies,

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.934
because if you fire real ammo into a crowd

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
of women and children rioting

00:04:18.934 --> 00:04:20.934
you're going to lose friends very quickly.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.816
This is not about projecting
power, but about staying power,

00:04:23.840 --> 00:04:25.934
which is about legitimacy with the locals.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.006
Who do you access in this
transition space?

00:04:28.030 --> 00:04:31.650
You have to create internal partners.
You have to access coalition partners.

00:04:31.674 --> 00:04:33.934
We asked the Indians
for 17,000 peace keepers.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.934
I know their senior leadership,
they wanted to give it to us.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.934
But they said to us, "You know what?

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
In that transition space you're
mostly hat not enough cattle.

00:04:42.784 --> 00:04:43.934
We don't think you can pull it off,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.934
we're not going to give you
our 17,000 peace keepers for fodder."

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.934
We asked the Russians for 40,000.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:49.934
They said no.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:50.934
I was in China in August, I said,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.934
"You should have 50,000
peace keepers in Iraq.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
It's your oil, not ours."

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.934
Which is the truth. It's their oil.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:02.101
And the Chinese said to me, "Dr.
Barnett, you're absolutely right.

00:05:02.125 --> 00:05:04.934
In a perfect world we'd have 50,000 there.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.934
But it's not a perfect world,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
and your administration isn't
getting us any closer."

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.006
But we have trouble
accessing our outcomes.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.934
We lucked out, frankly, on the selection.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.934
We face different opponents
across these three.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:19.934
And it's time to start admitting

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:23.934
you can't ask the same 19-year-old
to do it all, day in and day out.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.934
It's just too damn hard.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
We have an unparalleled
capacity to wage war.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.934
We don't do the everything else so well.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.934
Frankly, we do it better than anybody
and we still suck at it.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.934
We have a brilliant Secretary of War.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.934
We don't have a Secretary
of Everything Else.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.816
Because if we did, that guy
would be in front of the Senate,

00:05:42.840 --> 00:05:44.934
still testifying over Abu Ghraib.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.934
The problem is he doesn't exist.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
There is no Secretary of Everything Else.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.934
I think we have an unparalleled
capacity to wage war.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.934
I call that the Leviathan Force.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.934
What we need to build is a force
for the Everything Else.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.934
I call them the System Administrators.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.934
What I think this really represents

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.934
is lack of an A to Z rule set
for the world as a whole

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.006
for processing politically
bankrupt states.

00:06:06.030 --> 00:06:08.934
We have one for processing
economically bankrupt states.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.934
It's the IMF Sovereign
Bankruptcy Plan, OK?

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.934
We argue about it every time we use it.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.934
Argentina just went through it,
broke a lot of rules.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.149
They got out on the far end, we said,
"Fine, don't worry about it."

00:06:20.173 --> 00:06:22.934
It's transparent. A certain
amount of certainty

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.934
gives the sense of a non-zero outcome.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.816
We don't have one for processing
politically bankrupt states

00:06:27.840 --> 00:06:29.934
that, frankly, everybody wants gone.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Like Saddam, like Mugabe,
like Kim Jong-Il --

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:37.934
people who kill in hundreds
of thousands or millions.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
Like the 250,000 dead so far in Sudan.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.934
What would an A to Z system look like?

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.054
I'm going to distinguish
between what I call

00:06:46.078 --> 00:06:48.078
front half and back half.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.934
And let's call this red line,
I don't know, mission accomplished.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.934
(Laughter)

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.934
(Applause)

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.934
What we have extant right now,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.934
at the beginning of this system, is the U.N.
Security Council as a grand jury.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:04.934
What can they do?

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
They can indict your ass.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.934
They can debate it. They can
write it on a piece of paper.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.339
They can put it in an envelope
and mail it to you,

00:07:13.363 --> 00:07:17.934
and then say in no uncertain
terms, "Please cut that out."

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:22.934
(Laughter)

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:26.339
That gets you about four million dead
in Central Africa over the 1990s.

00:07:26.363 --> 00:07:30.363
That gets you 250,000 dead
in the Sudan in the last 15 months.

00:07:30.784 --> 00:07:31.934
Everybody's got to answer
their grandchildren some day

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.006
what you did
about the holocaust in Africa,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
and you better have an answer.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:43.934
We don't have anything to translate
that will into action.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.934
What we do have is the U.S.-enabled
Leviathan Force that says,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.934
"You want me to take that guy down?
I'll take that guy down.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.934
I'll do it on Tuesday. It will cost
you 20 billion dollars."

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:57.934
(Laughter)

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.934
But here's the deal.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.244
As soon as I can't find
anybody else to air out,

00:08:02.268 --> 00:08:03.934
I leave the scene immediately.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
That's called the Powell Doctrine.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.934
Way downstream we have
the International Criminal Court.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.934
They love to put them on trial.
They've got Milosević right now.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.934
What are we missing?

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.934
A functioning executive
that will translate will into action,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.934
because we don't have it.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.934
Every time we lead one of these efforts

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
we have to whip ourselves
into this imminent threat thing.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.934
We haven't faced an imminent threat since

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.934
the Cuban missile crisis in 1962.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:29.934
But we use this language from a bygone era

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.934
to scare ourselves into doing something

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.387
because we're a democracy
and that's what it takes.

00:08:35.411 --> 00:08:37.935
And if that doesn't work
we scream, "He's got a gun!"

00:08:37.959 --> 00:08:38.934
just as we rush in.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:46.934
(Laughter)

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:47.934
And then we look over the body

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.244
and we find an old cigarette
lighter and we say,

00:08:50.268 --> 00:08:51.934
"Jesus, it was dark."

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.934
(Laughter)

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.934
Do you want to do it, France?

00:08:55.958 --> 00:09:00.934
France says, "No, but I do
like to criticize you after the fact."

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.934
What we need downstream
is a great power enabled --

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.934
what I call that Sys Admin Force.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.934
We should have had 250,000
troops streaming into Iraq

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.934
on the heels of that Leviathan
sweeping towards Baghdad.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:11.934
What do you get then?

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.934
No looting, no military disappearing,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.006
no arms disappearing,
no ammo disappearing,

00:09:16.030 --> 00:09:18.269
no Muqtada Al-Sadr -- I'm
wrecking his bones --

00:09:18.293 --> 00:09:19.934
no insurgency.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.934
Talk to anybody who was over there
in the first six months.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.934
We had six months to feel
the lob, to get the job done,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.934
and we dicked around for six months.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.934
And then they turned on us.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.934
Why? Because they just got fed up.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.934
They saw what we did to Saddam.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.934
They said, "You're that powerful,
you can resurrect this country.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.934
You're America."

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.934
What we need is an international
reconstruction fund --

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.197
Sebastian Mallaby,
Washington Post, great idea.

00:09:41.221 --> 00:09:42.934
Model on the IMF.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.934
Instead of passing the hat each time, OK?

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.934
Where are we going to find this guy?
G20, that's easy.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.934
Check out their agenda since 9/11.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.934
All security dominated.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.934
They're going to decide up front
how the money gets spent

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:55.934
just like in the IMF.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
You vote according to how much
money you put in the kitty.

00:09:59.784 --> 00:10:00.934
Here's my challenge
to the Defense Department.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.934
You've got to build this force.
You've got to seed this force.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.149
You've got to track coalition partners.
Create a record of success.

00:10:07.173 --> 00:10:08.934
You will get this model.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.934
You tell me it's too hard to do.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.934
I'll walk this dog right
through that six part series on the Balkans.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.934
We did it just like that.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.934
I'm talking about regularizing
it, making it transparent.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.934
Would you like Mugabe gone?

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.934
Would you like Kim Jong-Il,
who's killed about two million people,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
would you like him gone?

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
Would you like a better system?

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.934
This is why it matters to the military.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:34.934
They've been experiencing an identity
crisis since the end of the Cold War.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:38.006
I'm not talking about the difference
between reality and desire,

00:10:38.030 --> 00:10:40.411
which I can do because I'm
not inside the beltway.

00:10:40.435 --> 00:10:42.934
(Laughter)

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:43.934
I'm talking about the 1990s.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.934
The Berlin Wall falls. We do Desert Storm.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.934
The split starts to emerge
between those in the military

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.934
who see a future they can live with,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.934
and those who see a future
that starts to scare them,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.934
like the U.S. submarine community,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.339
which watches the Soviet
Navy disappear overnight.

00:10:57.363 --> 00:10:58.934
Ah!

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.934
(Laughter)

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:04.934
So they start moving
from reality towards desire

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and they create their own special language

00:11:06.982 --> 00:11:10.125
to describe their voyage of self-discovery
and self-actualization.

00:11:10.149 --> 00:11:12.934
(Laughter)

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.934
The problem is you need a big,
sexy opponent to fight against.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.435
And if you can't find
one you've got to make one up.

00:11:17.459 --> 00:11:19.934
China, all grown up, going to be a looker!

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:23.934
(Laughter)

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.934
The rest of the military got
dragged down into the muck

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:26.934
across the 1990s

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.720
and they developed this very
derisive term to describe it:

00:11:29.744 --> 00:11:31.744
military operations other than war.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.911
I ask you, who joins the military
to do things other than war?

00:11:34.935 --> 00:11:36.934
Actually, most of them.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.934
Jessica Lynch never
planned on shooting back.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
Most of them don't pick up a rifle.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.054
I maintain this is code
inside the Army for,

00:11:46.078 --> 00:11:49.078
"We don't want to do this."

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.054
They spent the 1990s
working the messy scene

00:11:52.078 --> 00:11:53.934
between globalized parts of the world

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
What I call the core and the gap.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.934
The Clinton administration wasn't
interested in running this.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.934
For eight years, after screwing
up the relationship on day one --

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.934
inauguration day with gays
in the military --

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.934
which was deft.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.934
(Laughter)

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.934
So we were home alone for eight years.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.934
And what did we do home alone?

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.197
We bought one military
and we operated another.

00:12:16.221 --> 00:12:18.602
It's like the guy who goes
to the doctor and says,

00:12:18.626 --> 00:12:20.934
"Doctor, it hurts when I do this."

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.934
(Laughter)

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.934
The doctor says, "Stop
doing that you idiot."

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.934
I used to give this brief
inside the Pentagon in the early 1990s.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.934
I'd say, "You're buying one military
and you're operating another,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.149
and eventually it's going to hurt.
It's wrong.

00:12:33.173 --> 00:12:34.934
Bad Pentagon, bad!"

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.934
(Laughter)

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.197
And they'd say, "Dr.
Barnett, you are so right.

00:12:39.221 --> 00:12:41.555
Can you come back next year
and remind us again?"

00:12:41.579 --> 00:12:46.934
(Laughter)

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.934
Some people say 9/11 heals the rift --

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.934
jerks the long-term transformation gurus

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.934
out of their 30,000 foot view of history,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.934
drags them down in to the muck and says,
"You want a networked opponent?

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.934
I've got one, he's everywhere,
go find him."

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.934
It elevates MOOTW --
how we pronounce that acronym --

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.934
from crap to grand strategy,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.934
because that's how you're
going to shrink that gap.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:07.934
Some people put these two things together

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
and they call it empire, which I think
is a boneheaded concept.

00:13:10.982 --> 00:13:13.935
Empire is about the enforcement
of not just minimal rule sets,

00:13:13.959 --> 00:13:14.934
which you cannot do,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.934
but maximum rule sets which you must do.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.934
It's not our system of governance.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.934
Never how we've sought to interact
with the outside world.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.006
I prefer that phrase
System Administration.

00:13:23.030 --> 00:13:24.934
We enforce the minimal rule sets

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.387
for maintaining connectivity
to the global economy.

00:13:27.411 --> 00:13:29.411
Certain bad things you cannot do.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.934
How this impacts the way we think
about the future of war.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.054
This is a concept which gets me
vilified throughout the Pentagon.

00:13:37.078 --> 00:13:38.934
It makes me very popular as well.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.934
Everybody's got an opinion.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.101
Going back to the beginning
of our country --

00:13:43.125 --> 00:13:46.125
historically, defenses meant
protection of the homeland.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.934
Security has meant everything else.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.934
Written into our constitution,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.934
two different forces,
two different functions.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.934
Raise an army when you need it,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:01.934
and maintain a navy
for day-to-day connectivity.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.934
A Department of War,
a Department of Everything Else.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
A big stick, a baton stick.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
Can of whup ass,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.934
the networking force.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.006
In 1947 we merged these
two things together

00:14:17.030 --> 00:14:18.934
in the Defense Department.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.934
Our long-term rationale becomes,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.934
we're involved in a hair trigger
stand off with the Soviets.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.934
To attack America is to risk
blowing up the world.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:30.934
We connected national security
to international security

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
with about a seven minute time delay.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.934
That's not our problem now.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.197
They can kill
three million in Chicago tomorrow

00:14:39.221 --> 00:14:41.934
and we don't go
to the mattresses with nukes.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.934
That's the scary part.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.934
The question is how do we reconnect
American national security

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.934
with global security to make
the world a lot more comfortable,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.934
and to embed and contextualize
our employment

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
of force around the planet?

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
What's happened
since is that bifurcation I described.

00:15:03.784 --> 00:15:04.934
We talked about this
going all the way back

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.934
to the end of the Cold War.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.934
Let's have a Department of War,
and a Department of Something Else.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:12.934
Some people say, "Hell,
9/11 did it for you."

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.006
Now we've got a home
game and an away game.

00:15:15.030 --> 00:15:20.030
(Laughter)

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:24.244
The Department of Homeland Security
is a strategic feel good measure.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:28.197
It's going to be the Department
of Agriculture for the 21st century.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.934
TSA -- thousands standing around.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:38.780
(Laughter)

00:15:38.804 --> 00:15:40.780
I supported the war in Iraq.

00:15:40.804 --> 00:15:42.780
He was a bad guy with multiple priors.

00:15:42.804 --> 00:15:44.780
It's not like we had to find him

00:15:44.804 --> 00:15:48.804
actually killing somebody
live to arrest him.

00:15:49.804 --> 00:15:52.471
I knew we'd kick ass in the war
with the Leviathan Force.

00:15:52.495 --> 00:15:54.780
I knew we'd have a hard
time with what followed.

00:15:54.804 --> 00:15:58.281
But I know this organization doesn't
change until it experiences failure.

00:15:58.804 --> 00:16:00.947
What do I mean by these
two different forces?

00:16:01.804 --> 00:16:03.780
This is the Hobbesian Force.

00:16:03.804 --> 00:16:05.780
I love this force. I don't
want to see it go.

00:16:05.804 --> 00:16:07.780
That plus nukes rules out great power war.

00:16:07.804 --> 00:16:09.780
This is the military the rest
of the world wants us to build.

00:16:09.804 --> 00:16:12.995
It's why I travel all over the world
talking to foreign militaries.

00:16:13.019 --> 00:16:15.780
What does this mean?

00:16:15.804 --> 00:16:17.780
It means you've got to stop pretending

00:16:17.804 --> 00:16:21.281
you can do these two very disparate
skill sets with the same 19-year-old.

00:16:21.305 --> 00:16:23.780
Switching back, morning,
afternoon, evening,

00:16:23.804 --> 00:16:25.780
morning, afternoon, evening.

00:16:25.804 --> 00:16:27.780
Handing out aid, shooting back,

00:16:27.804 --> 00:16:29.780
handing out aid, shooting back.

00:16:29.804 --> 00:16:31.780
It's too much.

00:16:31.804 --> 00:16:34.780
The 19-year-olds get tired
from the switching, OK?

00:16:34.804 --> 00:16:36.780
(Laughter)

00:16:36.804 --> 00:16:39.804
That force on the left, you can
train a 19-year-old to do that.

00:16:39.828 --> 00:16:42.780
That force on the right is more
like a 40-year-old cop.

00:16:42.804 --> 00:16:44.804
You need the experience.

00:16:45.804 --> 00:16:47.852
What does this mean
in terms of operations?

00:16:49.804 --> 00:16:51.804
The rule is going to be this.

00:16:52.804 --> 00:16:55.780
That Sys Admin force is the force
that never comes home,

00:16:55.804 --> 00:16:57.780
does most of your work.

00:16:57.804 --> 00:17:00.780
You break out that Leviathan
Force only every so often.

00:17:00.804 --> 00:17:02.780
But here's the promise you
make to the American public,

00:17:02.804 --> 00:17:04.780
to your own people, to the world.

00:17:04.804 --> 00:17:06.780
You break out that Leviathan Force,

00:17:06.804 --> 00:17:09.780
you promise, you guarantee
that you're going to mount

00:17:09.804 --> 00:17:13.780
one hell of a -- immediately
-- follow-on Sys Admin effort.

00:17:13.804 --> 00:17:16.471
Don't plan for the war unless you
plan to win the peace.

00:17:16.495 --> 00:17:21.780
(Applause)

00:17:21.804 --> 00:17:23.780
Other differences. Leviathan

00:17:23.804 --> 00:17:26.185
traditional partners,
they all look like the Brits

00:17:26.209 --> 00:17:27.780
and their former colonies.

00:17:27.804 --> 00:17:29.780
(Laughter)

00:17:29.804 --> 00:17:31.780
Including us, I would remind you.

00:17:31.804 --> 00:17:33.780
The rest -- wider array of partners.

00:17:33.804 --> 00:17:35.780
International organizations,
non-governmental organizations,

00:17:35.804 --> 00:17:37.780
private voluntary
organizations, contractors.

00:17:37.804 --> 00:17:39.780
You're not going to get away from that.

00:17:39.804 --> 00:17:43.566
Leviathan Force, it's all about joint
operations between the military services.

00:17:43.590 --> 00:17:44.780
We're done with that.

00:17:44.804 --> 00:17:47.780
What we need to do
is inter-agency operations,

00:17:47.804 --> 00:17:49.804
which frankly Condi Rice was in charge of.

00:17:49.828 --> 00:17:53.114
And I'm amazed nobody asked her
that question when she was confirmed.

00:17:53.138 --> 00:17:55.780
I call the Leviathan Force
your dad's military.

00:17:55.804 --> 00:17:59.780
I like them young, male,
unmarried, slightly pissed off.

00:17:59.804 --> 00:18:06.780
(Laughter)

00:18:06.804 --> 00:18:09.043
I call the Sys Admin Force
your mom's military.

00:18:09.067 --> 00:18:11.043
It's everything the man's military hates.

00:18:11.067 --> 00:18:15.780
Gender balanced much more, older,
educated, married with children.

00:18:15.804 --> 00:18:18.780
The force on the left, up or out.

00:18:18.804 --> 00:18:20.804
The force on the right, in and out.

00:18:21.804 --> 00:18:24.780
The force on the left respects
Posse Comitatus restrictions

00:18:24.804 --> 00:18:26.780
on the use of force inside the U.S.

00:18:26.804 --> 00:18:28.780
The force on the right's going
to obliterate it.

00:18:28.804 --> 00:18:29.780
That's where the National
Guard's going to be.

00:18:29.804 --> 00:18:31.780
The force on the left is never
coming under the purview

00:18:31.804 --> 00:18:33.780
of the International Criminal Court.

00:18:33.804 --> 00:18:35.804
Sys Admin Force has to.

00:18:37.804 --> 00:18:40.780
Different definitions
of network centricity.

00:18:40.804 --> 00:18:43.780
One takes down networks, one puts them up.

00:18:43.804 --> 00:18:47.780
And you've got to wage war here
in such a way to facilitate that.

00:18:47.804 --> 00:18:49.780
Do we need a bigger budget?

00:18:49.804 --> 00:18:52.780
Do we need a draft to pull this off?

00:18:52.804 --> 00:18:54.804
Absolutely not.

00:18:56.804 --> 00:19:00.090
I've been told by the Revolution
of Military Affairs crowd for years,

00:19:00.804 --> 00:19:03.780
we can do it faster, cheaper,
smaller, just as lethal.

00:19:03.804 --> 00:19:07.780
I say, "Great, I'm going to take the Sys
Admin budget out of your hide."

00:19:07.804 --> 00:19:09.780
Here's the larger point.

00:19:09.804 --> 00:19:11.780
You're going to build the Sys Admin
Force inside the U.S. Military first.

00:19:11.804 --> 00:19:15.780
But ultimately you're going
to civilianize it, probably two thirds.

00:19:15.804 --> 00:19:19.780
Inter agency-ize it, internationalize it.

00:19:19.804 --> 00:19:21.780
So yes, it begins inside the Pentagon,

00:19:21.804 --> 00:19:24.780
but over time it's going
to cross that river.

00:19:24.804 --> 00:19:27.780
(Laughter)

00:19:27.804 --> 00:19:30.780
I have been to the mountain top.
I can see the future.

00:19:30.804 --> 00:19:34.138
I may not live long enough to get you
there, but it's going to happen.

00:19:34.162 --> 00:19:36.543
We're going to have
a Department of Something Else

00:19:36.567 --> 00:19:37.780
between war and peace.

00:19:37.804 --> 00:19:38.780
Last slide.

00:19:38.804 --> 00:19:40.780
Who gets custody of the kids?

00:19:40.804 --> 00:19:43.662
This is where the Marines
in the audience get kind of tense.

00:19:43.686 --> 00:19:49.780
(Laughter)

00:19:49.804 --> 00:19:52.662
And this is when they think
about beating the crap out of me

00:19:52.686 --> 00:19:53.780
after the talk.

00:19:53.804 --> 00:19:54.780
(Laughter)

00:19:54.804 --> 00:19:56.780
Read Max Boon.

00:19:56.804 --> 00:19:58.780
This is the history of the marines
-- small wars, small arms.

00:19:58.804 --> 00:20:00.780
The Marines are like my West
Highland Terrier.

00:20:00.804 --> 00:20:03.185
They get up every morning,
they want to dig a hole

00:20:03.209 --> 00:20:04.780
and they want to kill something.

00:20:04.804 --> 00:20:06.780
(Laughter)

00:20:06.804 --> 00:20:09.780
I don't want my Marines handing out aid.

00:20:09.804 --> 00:20:11.804
I want them to be Marines.

00:20:12.804 --> 00:20:14.780
That's what keeps the Sys Admin
Force from being a pussy force.

00:20:14.804 --> 00:20:16.780
It keeps it from being the U.N.

00:20:16.804 --> 00:20:18.780
You shoot at these people the Marines
are going to come over and kill you.

00:20:18.804 --> 00:20:21.780
(Laughter)

00:20:21.804 --> 00:20:24.780
(Applause)

00:20:24.804 --> 00:20:27.780
Department of Navy,
strategic subs go this way,

00:20:27.804 --> 00:20:29.780
surface combatants are over there,

00:20:29.804 --> 00:20:32.090
and the news is they may
actually be that small.

00:20:32.114 --> 00:20:34.780
(Laughter)

00:20:34.804 --> 00:20:36.780
I call it the Smart Dust Navy.

00:20:36.804 --> 00:20:38.780
I tell young officers, "You may
command 500 ships in your career.

00:20:38.804 --> 00:20:42.804
Bad news is they may not
have anybody on them."

00:20:43.804 --> 00:20:46.804
Carriers go both ways
because they're a swing asset.

00:20:47.804 --> 00:20:50.780
You'll see the pattern --
airborne, just like carriers.

00:20:50.804 --> 00:20:52.780
Armor goes this way.

00:20:52.804 --> 00:20:53.780
Here's the dirty secret of the Air Force,

00:20:53.804 --> 00:20:55.780
you can win by bombing.

00:20:55.804 --> 00:20:58.804
But you need lots of these guys
on the ground to win the peace.

00:20:58.828 --> 00:21:01.828
Shinseki was right with the argument.

00:21:02.804 --> 00:21:06.780
Air force, strategic
airlift goes both ways.

00:21:06.804 --> 00:21:10.804
Bombers, fighters go over here.

00:21:11.804 --> 00:21:13.780
Special Operations Command down at Tampa.

00:21:13.804 --> 00:21:16.804
Trigger-pullers go this way.

00:21:17.804 --> 00:21:20.780
Civil Affairs, that bastard
child, comes over here.

00:21:20.804 --> 00:21:22.780
Return to the Army.

00:21:22.804 --> 00:21:25.995
The point about the trigger-pullers
and Special Operations Command.

00:21:26.019 --> 00:21:28.115
No off season, these
guys are always active.

00:21:28.804 --> 00:21:34.780
They drop in, do
their business, disappear.

00:21:34.804 --> 00:21:36.780
See me now. Don't talk about it later.

00:21:36.804 --> 00:21:40.780
(Laughter)

00:21:40.804 --> 00:21:42.780
I was never here.

00:21:42.804 --> 00:21:45.780
(Laughter)

00:21:45.804 --> 00:21:47.780
The world is my playground.

00:21:47.804 --> 00:21:51.780
(Laughter)

00:21:51.804 --> 00:21:53.780
I want to keep trigger-pullers
trigger-happy.

00:21:53.804 --> 00:21:55.900
I want the rules to be
as loose as possible.

00:21:55.924 --> 00:21:58.210
Because when the thing
gets prevented in Chicago

00:21:58.234 --> 00:21:59.780
with the three million dead

00:21:59.804 --> 00:22:02.566
that perverts our political
system beyond all recognition,

00:22:02.590 --> 00:22:05.067
these are the guys who are going
to kill them first.

00:22:05.281 --> 00:22:07.257
So it's better off to have them
make some mistakes along the way

00:22:07.281 --> 00:22:08.780
than to see that.

00:22:08.804 --> 00:22:10.780
Reserve component --

00:22:10.804 --> 00:22:13.780
National Guard reserves
overwhelmingly Sys Admin.

00:22:13.804 --> 00:22:15.780
How are you going to get
them to work for this force?

00:22:15.804 --> 00:22:17.900
Most firemen in this
country do it for free.

00:22:17.924 --> 00:22:19.780
This is not about money.

00:22:19.804 --> 00:22:22.804
This is about being up front
with these guys and gals.

00:22:24.804 --> 00:22:26.780
Last point, intelligence community --

00:22:26.804 --> 00:22:30.780
the muscle and the defense
agencies go this way.

00:22:30.804 --> 00:22:33.780
What should be the CIA, open,
analytical, open source

00:22:33.804 --> 00:22:35.780
should come over here.

00:22:35.804 --> 00:22:38.780
The information you need
to do this is not secret.

00:22:38.804 --> 00:22:40.780
It's not secret.

00:22:40.804 --> 00:22:41.780
Read that great piece in the New Yorker

00:22:41.804 --> 00:22:44.780
about how our echo boomers,
19 to 25, over in Iraq

00:22:44.804 --> 00:22:47.780
taught each other
how to do Sys Admin work,

00:22:47.804 --> 00:22:49.780
over the Internet in chat rooms.

00:22:49.804 --> 00:22:51.780
They said, "Al Qaeda could be listening."

00:22:51.804 --> 00:22:54.424
They said, "Well, Jesus,
they already know this stuff."

00:22:54.448 --> 00:22:56.780
(Laughter)

00:22:56.804 --> 00:22:58.780
Take a gift in the left hand.

00:22:58.804 --> 00:23:02.804
These are the sunglasses that don't
scare people, simple stuff.

00:23:04.804 --> 00:23:07.780
Censors and transparency,
the overheads go in both directions.

00:23:07.804 --> 00:23:08.954
Thanks.

title: Tour Microsoft's Virtual Earth
transcript: What I want to talk to you about today is virtual worlds, digital globes, the 3-D Web, the Metaverse. What does this all mean for us? What it means is the Web is going to become an exciting place again. It's going to become super exciting as we transform to this highly immersive and interactive world. With graphics, computing power, low latencies, these types of applications and possibilities are going to stream rich data into your lives. So the Virtual Earth initiative, and other types of these initiatives, are all about extending our current search metaphor.When you think about it, we're so constrained by browsing the Web, remembering URLs, saving favorites. As we move to search, we rely on the relevance rankings, the Web matching, the index crawling. But we want to use our brain! We want to navigate, explore, discover information. In order to do that, we have to put you as a user back in the driver's seat. We need cooperation between you and the computing network and the computer.So what better way to put you back in the driver's seat than to put you in the real world that you interact in every day? Why not leverage the learnings that you've been learning your entire life? So Virtual Earth is about starting off creating the first digital representation, comprehensive, of the entire world. What we want to do is mix in all types of data. Tag it. Attribute it. Metadata. Get the community to add local depth, global perspective, local knowledge. So when you think about this problem, what an enormous undertaking. Where do you begin? Well, we collect data from satellites, from airplanes, from ground vehicles, from people. This process is an engineering problem, a mechanical problem, a logistical problem, an operational problem.Here is an example of our aerial camera. This is panchromatic. It's actually four color cones. In addition, it's multi-spectral. We collect four gigabits per second of data, if you can imagine that kind of data stream coming down. That's equivalent to a constellation of 12 satellites at highest res capacity. We fly these airplanes at 5,000 feet in the air. You can see the camera on the front. We collect multiple viewpoints, vantage points, angles, textures. We bring all that data back in.We sit here — you know, think about the ground vehicles, the human scale — what do you see in person? We need to capture that up close to establish that what it's like-type experience. I bet many of you have seen the Apple commercials, kind of poking at the PC for their brilliance and simplicity. So a little unknown secret is — did you see the one with the guy, he's got the Web cam? The poor PC guy. They're duct taping his head. They're just wrapping it on him. Well, a little unknown secret is his brother actually works on the Virtual Earth team. (Laughter). So they've got a little bit of a sibling rivalry thing going on here. But let me tell you — it doesn't affect his day job.We think a lot of good can come from this technology. This was after Katrina. We were the first commercial fleet of airplanes to be cleared into the disaster impact zone. We flew the area. We imaged it. We sent in people. We took pictures of interiors, disaster areas. We helped with the first responders, the search and rescue. Often the first time anyone saw what happened to their house was on Virtual Earth. We made it all freely available on the Web, just to — it was obviously our chance of helping out with the cause.When we think about how all this comes together, it's all about software, algorithms and math. You know, we capture this imagery but to build the 3-D models we need to do geo-positioning. We need to do geo-registering of the images. We have to bundle adjust them. Find tie points. Extract geometry from the images. This process is a very calculated process. In fact, it was always done manual. Hollywood would spend millions of dollars to do a small urban corridor for a movie because they'd have to do it manually. They'd drive the streets with lasers called LIDAR. They'd collected information with photos. They'd manually build each building. We do this all through software, algorithms and math — a highly automated pipeline creating these cities. We took a decimal point off what it cost to build these cities, and that's how we're going to be able to scale this out and make this reality a dream.We think about the user interface. What does it mean to look at it from multiple perspectives? An ortho-view, a nadir-view. How do you keep the precision of the fidelity of the imagery while maintaining the fluidity of the model? I'll wrap up by showing you the — this is a brand-new peek I haven't really shown into the lab area of Virtual Earth. What we're doing is — people like this a lot, this bird's eye imagery we work with. It's this high resolution data. But what we've found is they like the fluidity of the 3-D model. A child can navigate with an Xbox controller or a game controller.So here what we're trying to do is we bring the picture and project it into the 3-D model space. You can see all types of resolution. From here, I can slowly pan the image over. I can get the next image. I can blend and transition. By doing this I don't lose the original detail. In fact, I might be recording history. The freshness, the capacity. I can turn this image. I can look at it from multiple viewpoints and angles.What we're trying to do is build a virtual world. We hope that we can make computing a user model you're familiar with, and really derive insights from you, from all different directions. I thank you very much for your time. (Applause)

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:48.958
are going to stream rich data into your lives.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:53.958
So the Virtual Earth initiative, and other types of these initiatives,

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:59.958
are all about extending our current search metaphor.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
When you think about it, we're so constrained by browsing the Web,

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
remembering URLs, saving favorites.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
As we move to search, we rely on the relevance rankings,

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.958
the Web matching, the index crawling.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
But we want to use our brain!

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
We want to navigate, explore, discover information.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:21.958
In order to do that, we have to put you as a user back in the driver's seat.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:25.958
We need cooperation between you and the computing network and the computer.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:29.958
So what better way to put you back in the driver's seat

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
than to put you in the real world that you interact in every day?

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:36.958
Why not leverage the learnings that you've been learning your entire life?

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
So Virtual Earth is about starting off

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:44.958
creating the first digital representation, comprehensive, of the entire world.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
What we want to do is mix in all types of data.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:52.958
Tag it. Attribute it. Metadata. Get the community to add local depth,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
global perspective, local knowledge.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:57.958
So when you think about this problem,

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:01.958
what an enormous undertaking. Where do you begin?

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:05.958
Well, we collect data from satellites, from airplanes,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.958
from ground vehicles, from people.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:13.958
This process is an engineering problem,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:17.958
a mechanical problem, a logistical problem, an operational problem.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
Here is an example of our aerial camera.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
This is panchromatic. It's actually four color cones.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
In addition, it's multi-spectral.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:28.958
We collect four gigabits per second of data,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
if you can imagine that kind of data stream coming down.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:36.958
That's equivalent to a constellation of 12 satellites at highest res capacity.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:40.958
We fly these airplanes at 5,000 feet in the air.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
You can see the camera on the front. We collect multiple viewpoints,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:49.958
vantage points, angles, textures. We bring all that data back in.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
We sit here -- you know, think about the ground vehicles, the human scale --

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
what do you see in person? We need to capture that up close

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:59.958
to establish that what it's like-type experience.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:03.958
I bet many of you have seen the Apple commercials,

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:09.958
kind of poking at the PC for their brilliance and simplicity.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
So a little unknown secret is --

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:15.958
did you see the one with the guy, he's got the Web cam?

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
The poor PC guy. They're duct taping his head. They're just wrapping it on him.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:23.958
Well, a little unknown secret is his brother actually works on the Virtual Earth team.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:28.958
(Laughter). So they've got a little bit of a sibling rivalry thing going on here.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
But let me tell you -- it doesn't affect his day job.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
We think a lot of good can come from this technology.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:37.958
This was after Katrina. We were the first commercial fleet of airplanes

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
to be cleared into the disaster impact zone.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:45.958
We flew the area. We imaged it. We sent in people. We took pictures of interiors,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:49.958
disaster areas. We helped with the first responders, the search and rescue.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:54.958
Often the first time anyone saw what happened to their house was on Virtual Earth.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
We made it all freely available on the Web, just to --

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:00.958
it was obviously our chance of helping out with the cause.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
When we think about how all this comes together,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
it's all about software, algorithms and math.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
You know, we capture this imagery but to build the 3-D models

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:15.958
we need to do geo-positioning. We need to do geo-registering of the images.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
We have to bundle adjust them. Find tie points.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
Extract geometry from the images.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:24.958
This process is a very calculated process.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:25.958
In fact, it was always done manual.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:29.958
Hollywood would spend millions of dollars to do a small urban corridor

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
for a movie because they'd have to do it manually.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
They'd drive the streets with lasers called LIDAR.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
They'd collected information with photos. They'd manually build each building.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
We do this all through software, algorithms and math --

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
a highly automated pipeline creating these cities.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
We took a decimal point off what it cost to build these cities,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:50.958
and that's how we're going to be able to scale this out and make this reality a dream.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
We think about the user interface.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
What does it mean to look at it from multiple perspectives?

00:04:55.958 --> 00:05:00.958
An ortho-view, a nadir-view. How do you keep the precision of the fidelity of the imagery

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:04.958
while maintaining the fluidity of the model?

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
I'll wrap up by showing you the --

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.958
this is a brand-new peek I haven't really shown into the lab area of Virtual Earth.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
What we're doing is -- people like this a lot,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
this bird's eye imagery we work with. It's this high resolution data.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.958
But what we've found is they like the fluidity of the 3-D model.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
A child can navigate with an Xbox controller or a game controller.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:29.958
So here what we're trying to do is we bring the picture and project it into the 3-D model space.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:35.958
You can see all types of resolution. From here, I can slowly pan the image over.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
I can get the next image. I can blend and transition.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:43.958
By doing this I don't lose the original detail. In fact, I might be recording history.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
The freshness, the capacity. I can turn this image.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
I can look at it from multiple viewpoints and angles.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
What we're trying to do is build a virtual world.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:57.958
We hope that we can make computing a user model you're familiar with,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:01.958
and really derive insights from you, from all different directions.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
I thank you very much for your time.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:04.958
(Applause)

title: New insights on poverty
transcript: I told you three things last year. I told you that the statistics of the world have not been made properly available. Because of that, we still have the old mindset of developing in industrialized countries, which is wrong. And that animated graphics can make a difference. Things are changing and today, on the United Nations Statistic Division Home Page, it says, by first of May, full access to the databases. (Applause) And if I could share the image with you on the screen. So three things have happened. U.N. opened their statistic databases, and we have a new version of the software up working as a beta on the net, so you don't have to download it any longer.And let me repeat what you saw last year. The bubbles are the countries. Here you have the fertility rate — the number of children per woman — and there you have the length of life in years. This is 1950 — those were the industrialized countries, those were developing countries. At that time there was a "we" and "them." There was a huge difference in the world. But then it changed, and it went on quite well.And this is what happens. You can see how China is the red, big bubble. The blue there is India. And they go over all this — I'm going to try to be a little more serious this year in showing you how things really changed. And it's Africa that stands out as the problem down here, doesn't it? Large families still, and the HIV epidemic brought down the countries like this. This is more or less what we saw last year, and this is how it will go on into the future.And I will talk on, is this possible? Because you see now, I presented statistics that don't exist. Because this is where we are. Will it be possible that this will happen? I cover my lifetime here, you know? I expect to live 100 years. And this is where we are today. Now could we look here instead at the economic situation in the world? And I would like to show that against child survival. We'll swap the axis. Here you have child mortality — that is, survival — four kids dying there, 200 dying there. And this is GDP per capita on this axis. And this was 2007.And if I go back in time, I've added some historical statistics — here we go, here we go, here we go — not so much statistics 100 years ago. Some countries still had statistics. We are looking down in the archive, and when we are down into 1820, there is only Austria and Sweden that can produce numbers. (Laughter) But they were down here. They had 1,000 dollars per person per year. And they lost one-fifth of their kids before their first birthday.So this is what happens in the world, if we play the entire world. How they got slowly richer and richer, and they add statistics. Isn't it beautiful when they get statistics? You see the importance of that? And here, children don't live longer. The last century, 1870, was bad for the kids in Europe, because most of this statistics is Europe. It was only by the turn of the century that more than 90 percent of the children survived their first year. This is India coming up, with the first data from India. And this is the United States moving away here, earning more money. And we will soon see China coming up in the very far end corner here. And it moves up with Mao Tse-Tung getting health, not getting so rich. There he died, then Deng Xiaoping brings money. It moves this way over here. And the bubbles keep moving up there, and this is what the world looks like today. (Applause)Let us have a look at the United States. We have a function here — I can tell the world, "Stay where you are." And I take the United States — we still want to see the background — I put them up like this, and now we go backwards. And we can see that the United States goes to the right of the mainstream. They are on the money side all the time. And down in 1915, the United States was a neighbor of India — present, contemporary India. And that means United States was richer, but lost more kids than India is doing today, proportionally. And look here — compare to the Philippines of today. The Philippines of today has almost the same economy as the United States during the First World War. But we have to bring United States forward quite a while to find the same health of the United States as we have in the Philippines. About 1957 here, the health of the United States is the same as the Philippines. And this is the drama of this world which many call globalized, is that Asia, Arabic countries, Latin America, are much more ahead in being healthy, educated, having human resources than they are economically.There's a discrepancy in what's happening today in the emerging economies. There now, social benefits, social progress, are going ahead of economical progress. And 1957 — the United States had the same economy as Chile has today. And how long do we have to bring United States to get the same health as Chile has today? I think we have to go, there — we have 2001, or 2002 — the United States has the same health as Chile. Chile's catching up! Within some years Chile may have better child survival than the United States. This is really a change, that you have this lag of more or less 30, 40 years' difference on the health.And behind the health is the educational level. And there's a lot of infrastructure things, and general human resources are there. Now we can take away this — and I would like to show you the rate of speed, the rate of change, how fast they have gone. And we go back to 1920, and I want to look at Japan. And I want to look at Sweden and the United States. And I'm going to stage a race here between this sort of yellowish Ford here and the red Toyota down there, and the brownish Volvo. (Laughter) And here we go. Here we go. The Toyota has a very bad start down here, you can see, and the United States Ford is going off-road there. And the Volvo is doing quite fine. This is the war. The Toyota got off track, and now the Toyota is coming on the healthier side of Sweden — can you see that? And they are taking over Sweden, and they are now healthier than Sweden. That's the part where I sold the Volvo and bought the Toyota. (Laughter) And now we can see that the rate of change was enormous in Japan. They really caught up.And this changes gradually. We have to look over generations to understand it. And let me show you my own sort of family history — we made these graphs here. And this is the same thing, money down there, and health, you know? And this is my family. This is Sweden, 1830, when my great-great-grandma was born. Sweden was like Sierra Leone today. And this is when great-grandma was born, 1863. And Sweden was like Mozambique. And this is when my grandma was born, 1891. She took care of me as a child, so I'm not talking about statistic now — now it's oral history in my family. That's when I believe statistics, when it's grandma-verified statistics. (Laughter) I think it's the best way of verifying historical statistics. Sweden was like Ghana. It's interesting to see the enormous diversity within sub-Saharan Africa. I told you last year, I'll tell you again, my mother was born in Egypt, and I — who am I? I'm the Mexican in the family. And my daughter, she was born in Chile, and the grand-daughter was born in Singapore, now the healthiest country on this Earth. It bypassed Sweden about two to three years ago, with better child survival. But they're very small, you know? They're so close to the hospital we can never beat them out in these forests. (Laughter) But homage to Singapore.Singapore is the best one. Now this looks also like a very good story. But it's not really that easy, that it's all a good story. Because I have to show you one of the other facilities. We can also make the color here represent the variable — and what am I choosing here? Carbon-dioxide emission, metric ton per capita. This is 1962, and United States was emitting 16 tons per person. And China was emitting 0.6, and India was emitting 0.32 tons per capita. And what happens when we moved on? Well, you see the nice story of getting richer and getting healthier — everyone did it at the cost of emission of carbon dioxide. There is no one who has done it so far. And we don't have all the updated data any longer, because this is really hot data today. And there we are, 2001.And in the discussion I attended with global leaders, you know, many say now the problem is that the emerging economies, they are getting out too much carbon dioxide. The Minister of the Environment of India said, "Well, you were the one who caused the problem." The OECD countries — the high-income countries — they were the ones who caused the climate change. "But we forgive you, because you didn't know it. But from now on, we count per capita. From now on we count per capita. And everyone is responsible for the per capita emission."This really shows you, we have not seen good economic and health progress anywhere in the world without destroying the climate. And this is really what has to be changed. I've been criticized for showing you a too positive image of the world, but I don't think it's like this. The world is quite a messy place. This we can call Dollar Street. Everyone lives on this street here. What they earn here — what number they live on — is how much they earn per day. This family earns about one dollar per day. We drive up the street here, we find a family here which earns about two to three dollars a day. And we drive away here — we find the first garden in the street, and they earn 10 to 50 dollars a day.And how do they live? If we look at the bed here, we can see that they sleep on a rug on the floor. This is what poverty line is — 80 percent of the family income is just to cover the energy needs, the food for the day. This is two to five dollars. You have a bed. And here it's a much nicer bedroom, you can see. I lectured on this for Ikea, and they wanted to see the sofa immediately here. (Laughter) And this is the sofa, how it will emerge from there. And the interesting thing, when you go around here in the photo panorama, you see the family still sitting on the floor there. Although there is a sofa, if you watch in the kitchen, you can see that the great difference for women does not come between one to 10 dollars. It comes beyond here, when you really can get good working conditions in the family. And if you really want to see the difference, you look at the toilet over here. This can change. This can change. These are all pictures and images from Africa, and it can become much better. We can get out of poverty.My own research has not been in IT or anything like this. I spent 20 years in interviews with African farmers who were on the verge of famine. And this is the result of the farmers-needs research. The nice thing here is that you can't see who are the researchers in this picture. That's when research functions in poor societies — you must really live with the people.When you're in poverty, everything is about survival. It's about having food. And these two young farmers, they are girls now — because the parents are dead from HIV and AIDS — they discuss with a trained agronomist. This is one of the best agronomists in Malawi, Junatambe Kumbira, and he's discussing what sort of cassava they will plant — the best converter of sunshine to food that man has found. And they are very, very eagerly interested to get advice, and that's to survive in poverty. That's one context. Getting out of poverty. The women told us one thing. "Get us technology. We hate this mortar, to stand hours and hours. Get us a mill so that we can mill our flour, then we will be able to pay for the rest ourselves." Technology will bring you out of poverty, but there's a need for a market to get away from poverty. And this woman is very happy now, bringing her products to the market. But she's very thankful for the public investment in schooling so she can count, and won't be cheated when she reaches the market. She wants her kid to be healthy, so she can go to the market and doesn't have to stay home. And she wants the infrastructure — it is nice with a paved road. It's also good with credit. Micro-credits gave her the bicycle, you know. And information will tell her when to go to market with which product. You can do this.I find my experience from 20 years of Africa is that the seemingly impossible is possible. Africa has not done bad. In 50 years they've gone from a pre-Medieval situation to a very decent 100-year-ago Europe, with a functioning nation and state. I would say that sub-Saharan Africa has done best in the world during the last 50 years. Because we don't consider where they came from. It's this stupid concept of developing countries that puts us, Argentina and Mozambique together 50 years ago, and says that Mozambique did worse. We have to know a little more about the world. I have a neighbor who knows 200 types of wine. He knows everything. He knows the name of the grape, the temperature and everything. I only know two types of wine — red and white. (Laughter) But my neighbor only knows two types of countries — industrialized and developing. And I know 200, I know about the small data. But you can do that. (Applause)But I have to get serious. And how do you get serious? You make a PowerPoint, you know? (Laughter) Homage to the Office package, no? What is this, what is this, what am I telling? I'm telling you that there are many dimensions of development. Everyone wants your pet thing. If you are in the corporate sector, you love micro-credit. If you are fighting in a non-governmental organization, you love equity between gender. Or if you are a teacher, you'll love UNESCO, and so on. On the global level, we have to have more than our own thing. We need everything. All these things are important for development, especially when you just get out of poverty and you should go towards welfare.Now, what we need to think about is, what is a goal for development, and what are the means for development? Let me first grade what are the most important means. Economic growth to me, as a public-health professor, is the most important thing for development because it explains 80 percent of survival. Governance. To have a government which functions — that's what brought California out of the misery of 1850. It was the government that made law function finally. Education, human resources are important. Health is also important, but not that much as a mean. Environment is important. Human rights is also important, but it just gets one cross.Now what about goals? Where are we going toward? We are not interested in money. Money is not a goal. It's the best mean, but I give it zero as a goal. Governance, well it's fun to vote in a little thing, but it's not a goal. And going to school, that's not a goal, it's a mean. Health I give two points. I mean it's nice to be healthy — at my age especially — you can stand here, you're healthy. And that's good, it gets two plusses. Environment is very, very crucial. There's nothing for the grandkid if you don't save up. But where are the important goals? Of course, it's human rights. Human rights is the goal, but it's not that strong of a mean for achieving development. And culture. Culture is the most important thing, I would say, because that's what brings joy to life. That's the value of living.So the seemingly impossible is possible. Even African countries can achieve this. And I've shown you the shot where the seemingly impossible is possible. And remember, please remember my main message, which is this: the seemingly impossible is possible. We can have a good world. I showed you the shots, I proved it in the PowerPoint, and I think I will convince you also by culture. (Laughter) (Applause) Bring me my sword! Sword swallowing is from ancient India. It's a cultural expression that for thousands of years has inspired human beings to think beyond the obvious. (Laughter) And I will now prove to you that the seemingly impossible is possible by taking this piece of steel — solid steel — this is the army bayonet from the Swedish Army, 1850, in the last year we had war. And it's all solid steel — you can hear here. And I'm going to take this blade of steel, and push it down through my body of blood and flesh, and prove to you that the seemingly impossible is possible. Can I request a moment of absolute silence? (Applause)
