00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:30.958
Here you have child mortality -- that is, survival --

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
four kids dying there, 200 dying there.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
And this is GDP per capita on this axis.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
And this was 2007.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
And if I go back in time, I've added some historical statistics --

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:49.958
here we go, here we go, here we go -- not so much statistics 100 years ago.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
Some countries still had statistics.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
We are looking down in the archive,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.958
and when we are down into 1820,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
there is only Austria and Sweden that can produce numbers.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
(Laughter)

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:08.958
But they were down here. They had 1,000 dollars per person per year.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
And they lost one-fifth of their kids before their first birthday.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
So this is what happens in the world, if we play the entire world.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
How they got slowly richer and richer,

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:19.958
and they add statistics.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
Isn't it beautiful when they get statistics?

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
You see the importance of that?

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
And here, children don't live longer.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.958
The last century, 1870, was bad for the kids in Europe,

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
because most of this statistics is Europe.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
It was only by the turn of the century

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
that more than 90 percent of the children survived their first year.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
This is India coming up, with the first data from India.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:45.958
And this is the United States moving away here, earning more money.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:50.958
And we will soon see China coming up in the very far end corner here.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
And it moves up with Mao Tse-Tung getting health,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:53.958
not getting so rich.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
There he died, then Deng Xiaoping brings money.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:57.958
It moves this way over here.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
And the bubbles keep moving up there,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
and this is what the world looks like today.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:08.958
(Applause)

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
Let us have a look at the United States.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
We have a function here -- I can tell the world, "Stay where you are."

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
And I take the United States -- we still want to see the background --

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
I put them up like this, and now we go backwards.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
And we can see that the United States

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
goes to the right of the mainstream.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
They are on the money side all the time.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:35.958
And down in 1915, the United States was a neighbor of India --

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
present, contemporary India.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
And that means United States was richer,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:44.958
but lost more kids than India is doing today, proportionally.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
And look here -- compare to the Philippines of today.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
The Philippines of today has almost the same economy

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
as the United States during the First World War.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:58.958
But we have to bring United States forward quite a while

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
to find the same health of the United States

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:02.958
as we have in the Philippines.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
About 1957 here, the health of the United States

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
is the same as the Philippines.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
And this is the drama of this world which many call globalized,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
is that Asia, Arabic countries, Latin America,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:19.958
are much more ahead in being healthy, educated,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
having human resources than they are economically.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
There's a discrepancy in what's happening today

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
in the emerging economies.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
There now, social benefits, social progress,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
are going ahead of economical progress.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:39.958
And 1957 -- the United States had the same economy as Chile has today.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:43.958
And how long do we have to bring United States

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
to get the same health as Chile has today?

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:51.958
I think we have to go, there -- we have 2001, or 2002 --

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
the United States has the same health as Chile.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:54.958
Chile's catching up!

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
Within some years Chile may have better child survival

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
than the United States.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
This is really a change, that you have this lag

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:07.958
of more or less 30, 40 years' difference on the health.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
And behind the health is the educational level.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And there's a lot of infrastructure things,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and general human resources are there.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
Now we can take away this --

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
and I would like to show you the rate of speed,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
the rate of change, how fast they have gone.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:31.958
And we go back to 1920, and I want to look at Japan.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
And I want to look at Sweden and the United States.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
And I'm going to stage a race here

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
between this sort of yellowish Ford here

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
and the red Toyota down there,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
and the brownish Volvo.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
(Laughter)

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
And here we go. Here we go.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
The Toyota has a very bad start down here, you can see,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
and the United States Ford is going off-road there.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:55.958
And the Volvo is doing quite fine.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
This is the war. The Toyota got off track, and now

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
the Toyota is coming on the healthier side of Sweden --

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:01.958
can you see that?

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:02.958
And they are taking over Sweden,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
and they are now healthier than Sweden.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
That's the part where I sold the Volvo and bought the Toyota.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
(Laughter)

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:13.958
And now we can see that the rate of change was enormous in Japan.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
They really caught up.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
And this changes gradually.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
We have to look over generations to understand it.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:25.958
And let me show you my own sort of family history --

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
we made these graphs here.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:31.958
And this is the same thing, money down there, and health, you know?

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
And this is my family.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
This is Sweden, 1830, when my great-great-grandma was born.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
Sweden was like Sierra Leone today.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
And this is when great-grandma was born, 1863.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
And Sweden was like Mozambique.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
And this is when my grandma was born, 1891.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
She took care of me as a child,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
so I'm not talking about statistic now --

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
now it's oral history in my family.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:58.958
That's when I believe statistics,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
when it's grandma-verified statistics.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
(Laughter)

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
I think it's the best way of verifying historical statistics.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Sweden was like Ghana.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
It's interesting to see the enormous diversity

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
within sub-Saharan Africa.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
I told you last year, I'll tell you again,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
my mother was born in Egypt, and I -- who am I?

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:20.958
I'm the Mexican in the family.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
And my daughter, she was born in Chile,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
and the grand-daughter was born in Singapore,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
now the healthiest country on this Earth.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
It bypassed Sweden about two to three years ago,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
with better child survival.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:32.958
But they're very small, you know?

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
They're so close to the hospital we can never

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:35.958
beat them out in these forests.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
(Laughter)

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:39.958
But homage to Singapore.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
Singapore is the best one.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Now this looks also like a very good story.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
But it's not really that easy, that it's all a good story.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
Because I have to show you one of the other facilities.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:57.958
We can also make the color here represent the variable --

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:58.958
and what am I choosing here?

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:02.958
Carbon-dioxide emission, metric ton per capita.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:08.958
This is 1962, and United States was emitting 16 tons per person.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
And China was emitting 0.6,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:14.958
and India was emitting 0.32 tons per capita.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
And what happens when we moved on?

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
Well, you see the nice story of getting richer

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:20.958
and getting healthier --

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:25.958
everyone did it at the cost of emission of carbon dioxide.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
There is no one who has done it so far.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
And we don't have all the updated data

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
any longer, because this is really hot data today.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
And there we are, 2001.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:41.958
And in the discussion I attended with global leaders, you know,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:45.958
many say now the problem is that the emerging economies,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
they are getting out too much carbon dioxide.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
The Minister of the Environment of India said,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
"Well, you were the one who caused the problem."

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
The OECD countries -- the high-income countries --

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
they were the ones who caused the climate change.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
"But we forgive you, because you didn't know it.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
But from now on, we count per capita.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
From now on we count per capita.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
And everyone is responsible for the per capita emission."

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
This really shows you, we have not seen good economic

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
and health progress anywhere in the world

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:18.958
without destroying the climate.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
And this is really what has to be changed.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
I've been criticized for showing you a too positive image of the world,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
but I don't think it's like this.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
The world is quite a messy place.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
This we can call Dollar Street.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
Everyone lives on this street here.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
What they earn here -- what number they live on --

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:37.958
is how much they earn per day.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
This family earns about one dollar per day.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:42.958
We drive up the street here,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
we find a family here which earns about two to three dollars a day.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
And we drive away here -- we find the first garden in the street,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
and they earn 10 to 50 dollars a day.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
And how do they live?

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
If we look at the bed here, we can see

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
that they sleep on a rug on the floor.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
This is what poverty line is --

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
80 percent of the family income is just to cover the energy needs,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
the food for the day.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
This is two to five dollars. You have a bed.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
And here it's a much nicer bedroom, you can see.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
I lectured on this for Ikea, and they wanted to see

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
the sofa immediately here.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
(Laughter)

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:22.958
And this is the sofa, how it will emerge from there.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
And the interesting thing, when you go around here in the photo panorama,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
you see the family still sitting on the floor there.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
Although there is a sofa,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
if you watch in the kitchen, you can see that

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:36.958
the great difference for women does not come between one to 10 dollars.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
It comes beyond here, when you really can get

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
good working conditions in the family.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
And if you really want to see the difference,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
you look at the toilet over here.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
This can change. This can change.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
These are all pictures and images from Africa,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
and it can become much better.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
We can get out of poverty.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
My own research has not been in IT or anything like this.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
I spent 20 years in interviews with African farmers

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
who were on the verge of famine.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
And this is the result of the farmers-needs research.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
The nice thing here is that you can't see

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
who are the researchers in this picture.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
That's when research functions in poor societies --

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
you must really live with the people.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
When you're in poverty, everything is about survival.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
It's about having food.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
And these two young farmers, they are girls now --

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:29.958
because the parents are dead from HIV and AIDS --

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
they discuss with a trained agronomist.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.958
This is one of the best agronomists in Malawi, Junatambe Kumbira,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
and he's discussing what sort of cassava they will plant --

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
the best converter of sunshine to food that man has found.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
And they are very, very eagerly interested to get advice,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
and that's to survive in poverty.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:48.958
That's one context.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Getting out of poverty.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
The women told us one thing. "Get us technology.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
We hate this mortar, to stand hours and hours.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
Get us a mill so that we can mill our flour,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
then we will be able to pay for the rest ourselves."

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
Technology will bring you out of poverty,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:09.958
but there's a need for a market to get away from poverty.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
And this woman is very happy now, bringing her products to the market.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
But she's very thankful for the public investment in schooling

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
so she can count, and won't be cheated when she reaches the market.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
She wants her kid to be healthy, so she can go to the market

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
and doesn't have to stay home.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
And she wants the infrastructure -- it is nice with a paved road.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
It's also good with credit.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Micro-credits gave her the bicycle, you know.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
And information will tell her when to go to market with which product.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
You can do this.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
I find my experience from 20 years of Africa is that

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
the seemingly impossible is possible.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
Africa has not done bad.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
In 50 years they've gone from a pre-Medieval situation

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
to a very decent 100-year-ago Europe,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
with a functioning nation and state.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
I would say that sub-Saharan Africa has done best in the world

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:56.958
during the last 50 years.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
Because we don't consider where they came from.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
It's this stupid concept of developing countries

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
that puts us, Argentina and Mozambique together 50 years ago,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
and says that Mozambique did worse.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
We have to know a little more about the world.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
I have a neighbor who knows 200 types of wine.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:13.958
He knows everything.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
He knows the name of the grape, the temperature and everything.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
I only know two types of wine -- red and white.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
(Laughter)

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
But my neighbor only knows two types of countries --

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
industrialized and developing.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And I know 200, I know about the small data.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:28.958
But you can do that.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:33.958
(Applause)

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
But I have to get serious. And how do you get serious?

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
You make a PowerPoint, you know?

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:42.958
(Laughter)

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
Homage to the Office package, no?

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
What is this, what is this, what am I telling?

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
I'm telling you that there are many dimensions of development.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
Everyone wants your pet thing.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
If you are in the corporate sector, you love micro-credit.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
If you are fighting in a non-governmental organization,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
you love equity between gender.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
Or if you are a teacher, you'll love UNESCO, and so on.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
On the global level, we have to have more than our own thing.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
We need everything.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
All these things are important for development,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
especially when you just get out of poverty

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
and you should go towards welfare.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
Now, what we need to think about

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
is, what is a goal for development,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:20.958
and what are the means for development?

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
Let me first grade what are the most important means.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Economic growth to me, as a public-health professor,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:30.958
is the most important thing for development

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
because it explains 80 percent of survival.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
Governance. To have a government which functions --

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:40.958
that's what brought California out of the misery of 1850.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
It was the government that made law function finally.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
Education, human resources are important.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:50.958
Health is also important, but not that much as a mean.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
Environment is important.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
Human rights is also important, but it just gets one cross.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
Now what about goals? Where are we going toward?

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
We are not interested in money.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:00.958
Money is not a goal.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
It's the best mean, but I give it zero as a goal.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
Governance, well it's fun to vote in a little thing,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
but it's not a goal.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
And going to school, that's not a goal, it's a mean.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
Health I give two points. I mean it's nice to be healthy

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
-- at my age especially -- you can stand here, you're healthy.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
And that's good, it gets two plusses.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Environment is very, very crucial.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
There's nothing for the grandkid if you don't save up.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
But where are the important goals?

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
Of course, it's human rights.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
Human rights is the goal,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
but it's not that strong of a mean for achieving development.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:37.958
And culture. Culture is the most important thing, I would say,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
because that's what brings joy to life.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
That's the value of living.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
So the seemingly impossible is possible.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
Even African countries can achieve this.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:53.958
And I've shown you the shot where the seemingly impossible is possible.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:57.958
And remember, please remember my main message,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
which is this: the seemingly impossible is possible.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
We can have a good world.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
I showed you the shots, I proved it in the PowerPoint,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:11.958
and I think I will convince you also by culture.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:15.958
(Laughter)

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:16.958
(Applause)

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
Bring me my sword!

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:27.958
Sword swallowing is from ancient India.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:32.958
It's a cultural expression that for thousands of years

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:38.958
has inspired human beings to think beyond the obvious.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
(Laughter)

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:45.958
And I will now prove to you that the seemingly impossible is possible

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
by taking this piece of steel -- solid steel --

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
this is the army bayonet from the Swedish Army, 1850,

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
in the last year we had war.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
And it's all solid steel -- you can hear here.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:04.958
And I'm going to take this blade of steel,

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:09.958
and push it down through my body of blood and flesh,

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:13.958
and prove to you that the seemingly impossible is possible.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:18.958
Can I request a moment of absolute silence?

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:51.958
(Applause)

title: I'm going to the moon. Who's with me?
transcript: First place I'd like to take you is what many believe will be the world's deepest natural abyss. And I say believe because this process is still ongoing. Right now there are major expeditions being planned for next year that I'll talk a little bit about.One of the things that's changed here, in the last 150 years since Jules Verne had great science-fiction concepts of what the underworld was like, is that technology has enabled us to go to these places that were previously completely unknown and speculated about. We can now descend thousands of meters into the Earth with relative impunity. Along the way we've discovered fantastic abysses and chambers so large that you can see for hundreds of meters without a break in the line of sight. When you go on a thing like this, we can usually be in the field for anywhere from two to four months, with a team as small as 20 or 30, to as big as 150.And a lot of people ask me, you know, what kind of people do you get for a project like this? While our selection process is not as rigorous as NASA, it's nonetheless thorough. We're looking for competence, discipline, endurance, and strength. In case you're wondering, this is our strength test. (Laughter) But we also value esprit de corps and the ability to diplomatically resolve inter-personal conflict while under great stress in remote locations.We have already gone far beyond the limits of human endurance. From the entrance, this is nothing like a commercial cave. You're looking at Camp Two in a place called J2, not K2, but J2. We're roughly two days from the entrance at that point. And it's kind of like a high altitude mountaineering trip in reverse, except that you're now running a string of these things down. The idea is to try to provide some measure of physical comfort while you're down there, otherwise in damp, moist, cold conditions in utterly dark places. I should mention that everything you're seeing here, by the way, is artificially illuminated at great effort. Otherwise it is completely dark in these places.The deeper you go, the more you run into a conflict with water. It's basically like a tree collecting water coming down. And eventually you get to places where it is formidable and dangerous and unfortunately slides just don't do justice. So I've got a very brief clip here that was taken in the late 1980s. So descend into Huautla Plateau in Mexico. (Video) Now I have to tell you that the techniques being shown here are obsolete and dangerous. We would not do this today unless we were doing it for film. (Laughter)Along that same line, I have to tell you that with the spate of Hollywood movies that came out last year, we have never seen monsters underground — at least the kind that eat you. If there is a monster underground, it is the crushing psychological remoteness that begins to hit every member of the team once you cross about three days inbound from the nearest entrance.Next year I'll be leading an international team to J2. We're going to be shooting from minus 2,600 meters — that's a little over 8,600 feet down — at 30 kilometers from the entrance. The lead crews will be underground for pushing 30 days straight. I don't think there's been a mission like that in a long time.Eventually, if you keep going down in these things, probability says that you're going to run into a place like this. It's a place where there's a fold in the geologic stratum that collects water and fills to the roof. And when you used to find these things, they would put a label on a map that said terminal siphon. Now I remember that term really well for two reasons. Number one, it's the name of my rock band, and second, is because the confrontation of these things forced me to become an inventor. And we've since gone on to develop many generations of gadgets for exploring places like this.This is some life-support equipment closed-cycle. And you can use that now to go for many kilometers horizontally underwater and to depths of 200 meters straight down underwater. When you do this kind of stuff it's like doing EVA. It's like doing extra-vehicular activity in space, but at much greater distances, and at much greater physical peril. So it makes you think about how to design your equipment for long range, away from a safe haven.Here's a clip from a National Geographic movie that came out in 1999.(Video) Narrator: Exploration is a physical process of putting your foot in places where humans have never stepped before. This is where the last little nugget of totally unknown territory remains on this planet. To experience it is a privilege.Bill Stone: That was taken in Wakulla Springs, Florida. Couple of things to note about that movie. Every piece of equipment that you saw in there did not exist before 1999. It was developed within a two-year period and used on actual exploratory projects. This gadget you see right here was called the digital wall mapper, and it produced the first three-dimensional map anybody has ever done of a cave, and it happened to be underwater in Wakulla Springs. It was that gadget that serendipitously opened a door to another unexplored world.This is Europa. Carolyn Porco mentioned another one called Enceladus the other day. This is one of the places where planetary scientists believe there is a highest probability of the detection of the first life off earth in the ocean that exists below there. For those who have never seen this story, Jim Cameron produced a really wonderful IMAX movie couple of years ago, called "Aliens of the Deep." There was a brief clip —(Video) Narrator: A mission to explore under the ice of Europa would be the ultimate robotic challenge. Europa is so far away that even at the speed of light, it would take more than an hour for the command just to reach the vehicle. It has to be smart enough to avoid terrain hazards and to find a good landing site on the ice. Now we have to get through the ice. You need a melt probe. It's basically a nuclear-heated torpedo. The ice could be anywhere from three to 16 miles deep. Week after week, the melt probe will sink of its own weight through the ancient ice, until finally — Now, what are you going to do when you reach the surface of that ocean? You need an AUV, an autonomous underwater vehicle. It needs to be one smart puppy, able to navigate and make decisions on its own in an alien ocean.BS: What Jim didn't know when he released that movie was that six months earlier NASA had funded a team I assembled to develop a prototype for the Europa AUV. I mean, I cut through three years of engineering meetings, design and system integration, and introduced DEPTHX — Deep Phreatic Thermal Explorer. And as the movie says, this is one smart puppy. It's got 96 sensors, 36 onboard computers, 100,000 lines of behavioral autonomy code, packs more than 10 kilos of TNT in electrical onboard equivalent.This is the target site, the world's deepest hydrothermal spring at Cenote Zacaton in northern Mexico. It's been explored to a depth of 292 meters and beyond that nobody knows anything. This is part of DEPTHX's mission.There are two primary targets we're doing here. One is, how do you do science autonomy underground? How do you take a robot and turn it into a field microbiologist? There are more stages involved here than I've got time to tell you about, but basically we drive through the space, we populate it with environmental variables — sulphide, halide, things like that. We calculate gradient surfaces, and drive the bot over to a wall where there's a high probability of life. We move along the wall, in what's called proximity operations, looking for changes in color. If we see something that looks interesting, we pull it into a microscope. If it passes the microscopic test, we go for a collection. We either draw in a liquid sample, or we can actually take a solid core from the wall. No hands at the wheel. This is all behavioral autonomy here that's being conducted by the robot on its own.The real hat trick for this vehicle, though, is a disruptive new navigation system we've developed, known as 3D SLAM, for simultaneous localization and mapping. DEPTHX is an all-seeing eyeball. Its sensor beams look both forward and backward at the same time, allowing it to do new exploration while it's still achieving geometric sensor-lock on what it's gone through already.What I'm going to show you next is the first fully autonomous robotic exploration underground that's ever been done. This May, we're going to go from minus 1,000 meters in Zacaton, and if we're very lucky, DEPTHX will bring back the first robotically-discovered division of bacteria. The next step after that is to test it in Antartica and then, if the funding continues and NASA has the resolution to go, we could potentially launch by 2016, and by 2019 we may have the first evidence of life off this planet.What then of manned space exploration? The government recently announced plans to return to the moon by 2024. The successful conclusion of that mission will result in infrequent visitation of the moon by a small number of government scientists and pilots. It will leave us no further along in the general expansion of humanity into space than we were 50 years ago. Something fundamental has to change if we are to see common access to space in our lifetime.What I'm going to show you next are a couple of controversial ideas. And I hope you'll bear with me and have some faith that there's credibility behind what we're going to say here. There are three underpinnings of working in space privately. One of them is the requirement for economical earth-to-space transport. The Bert Rutans and Richard Bransons of this world have got this in their sights and I salute them. Go, go, go.The next thing we need are places to stay on orbit. Orbital hotels to start with, but workshops for the rest of us later on. The final missing piece, the real paradigm-buster, is this: a gas station on orbit. It's not going to look like that. If it existed, it would change all future spacecraft design and space mission planning.Now, to give you a chance to understand why there is power in that statement, I've got to give you the basics of Space 101. And the first thing is everything you do in space you pay by the kilogram. Anybody drink one of these here this week? You'd pay 10,000 dollars for that in orbit. That's more than you pay for TED, if Google dropped their sponsorship. (Laughter) The second is more than 90 percent of the weight of a vehicle is in propellant. Thus, every time you'd want to do anything in space, you are literally blowing away enormous sums of money every time you hit the accelerator. Not even the guys at Tesla can fight that physics.So, what if you could get your gas at a 10th the price? There is a place where you can. In fact, you can get it better — you can get it at 14 times lower if you can find propellant on the moon. There is a little-known mission that was launched by the Pentagon, 13 years ago now, called Clementine. And the most amazing thing that came out of that mission was a strong hydrogen signature at Shackleton crater on the south pole of the moon. That signal was so strong, it could only have been produced by 10 trillion tons of water buried in the sediment, collected over millions and billions of years by the impact of asteroids and comet material.If we're going to get that, and make that gas station possible, we have to figure out ways to move large volumes of payload through space. We can't do that right now. The way you normally build a system right now is you have a tube stack that has to be launched from the ground, and resist all kinds of aerodynamic forces. We have to beat that. We can do it because in space there are no aerodynamics. We can go and use inflatable systems for almost everything. This is an idea that, again, came out of Livermore back in 1989, with Dr. Lowell Wood's group. And we can extend that now to just about everything. Bob Bigelow currently has a test article in the orbit. We can go much further. We can build space tugs, orbiting platforms for holding cryogens and water. There's another thing. When you're coming back from the moon, you have to deal with orbital mechanics. It says you're moving 10,000 feet per second faster than you really want to be to get back to your gas station.You got two choices. You can burn rocket fuel to get there, or you can do something really incredible. You can dive into the stratosphere, and precisely dissipate that velocity, and come back out to the space station. It has never been done. It's risky and it's going to be one hell of a ride — better than Disney. The traditional approach to space exploration has been that you carry all the fuel you need to get everybody back in case of an emergency. If you try to do that for the moon, you're going to burn a billion dollars in fuel alone sending a crew out there. But if you send a mining team there, without the return propellant, first — (Laughter) Did any of you guys hear the story of Cortez? This is not like that. I'm much more like Scotty. I like this equipment, you know, and I really value it so we're not going to burn the gear. But, if you were truly bold you could get it there, manufacture it, and it would be the most dramatic demonstration that you could do something worthwhile off this planet that has ever been done. There's a myth that you can't do anything in space for less than a trillion dollars and 20 years. That's not true. In seven years, we could pull off an industrial mission to Shackleton and demonstrate that you could provide commercial reality out of this in low-earth orbit.We're living in one of the most exciting times in history. We're at a magical confluence where private wealth and imagination are driving the demand for access to space. The orbital refueling stations I've just described could create an entirely new industry and provide the final key for opening space to the general exploration. To bust the paradigm a radically different approach is needed. We can do it by jump-starting with an industrial Lewis and Clark expedition to Shackleton crater, to mine the moon for resources, and demonstrate they can form the basis for a profitable business on orbit.Talk about space always seems to be hung on ambiguities of purpose and timing. I would like to close here by putting a stake in the sand at TED. I intend to lead that expedition. (Applause) It can be done in seven years with the right backing. Those who join me in making it happen will become a part of history and join other bold individuals from time past who, had they been here today, would have heartily approved.There was once a time when people did bold things to open the frontier. We have collectively forgotten that lesson. Now we're at a time when boldness is required to move forward. 100 years after Sir Ernest Shackleton wrote these words, I intend to plant an industrial flag on the moon and complete the final piece that will open the space frontier, in our time, for all of us. Thank you. (Applause)

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
couple of years ago, called "Aliens of the Deep."

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
There was a brief clip --

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
(Video) Narrator: A mission to explore under the ice of Europa

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
would be the ultimate robotic challenge.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:16.958
Europa is so far away that even at the speed of light,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
it would take more than an hour for the command just to reach the vehicle.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
It has to be smart enough to avoid terrain hazards

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
and to find a good landing site on the ice.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
Now we have to get through the ice.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
You need a melt probe.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
It's basically a nuclear-heated torpedo.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
The ice could be anywhere from three to 16 miles deep.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
Week after week, the melt probe will sink of its own weight

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
through the ancient ice, until finally --

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
Now, what are you going to do when you reach the surface of that ocean?

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
You need an AUV, an autonomous underwater vehicle.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
It needs to be one smart puppy, able to navigate

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and make decisions on its own in an alien ocean.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
BS: What Jim didn't know when he released that movie

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:34.958
was that six months earlier NASA had funded a team I assembled

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
to develop a prototype for the Europa AUV.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:42.958
I mean, I cut through three years of engineering meetings, design

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
and system integration, and introduced DEPTHX --

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Deep Phreatic Thermal Explorer.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
And as the movie says, this is one smart puppy.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:55.958
It's got 96 sensors, 36 onboard computers,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
100,000 lines of behavioral autonomy code,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:03.958
packs more than 10 kilos of TNT in electrical onboard equivalent.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
This is the target site,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:10.958
the world's deepest hydrothermal spring at Cenote Zacaton in northern Mexico.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
It's been explored to a depth of 292 meters

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
and beyond that nobody knows anything.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
This is part of DEPTHX's mission.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
There are two primary targets we're doing here.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
One is, how do you do science autonomy underground?

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:26.958
How do you take a robot and turn it into a field microbiologist?

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
There are more stages involved here

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
than I've got time to tell you about, but basically we drive

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:34.958
through the space, we populate it with environmental variables --

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
sulphide, halide, things like that.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
We calculate gradient surfaces, and drive the bot over to a wall

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
where there's a high probability of life.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
We move along the wall, in what's called proximity operations,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
looking for changes in color.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
If we see something that looks interesting, we pull it into a microscope.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.958
If it passes the microscopic test, we go for a collection.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
We either draw in a liquid sample,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
or we can actually take a solid core from the wall.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:58.958
No hands at the wheel.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
This is all behavioral autonomy here

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
that's being conducted by the robot on its own.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
The real hat trick for this vehicle, though,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
is a disruptive new navigation system we've developed,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
known as 3D SLAM, for simultaneous localization and mapping.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
DEPTHX is an all-seeing eyeball.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.958
Its sensor beams look both forward and backward at the same time,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
allowing it to do new exploration

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
while it's still achieving geometric sensor-lock

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:24.958
on what it's gone through already.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
What I'm going to show you next

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.958
is the first fully autonomous robotic exploration underground

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
that's ever been done.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
This May, we're going to go from minus 1,000 meters in Zacaton,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
and if we're very lucky, DEPTHX will bring back the first

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
robotically-discovered division of bacteria.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
The next step after that is to test it in Antartica and then,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
if the funding continues and NASA has the resolution to go,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:41.958
we could potentially launch by 2016, and by 2019

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
we may have the first evidence of life off this planet.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
What then of manned space exploration?

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
The government recently announced plans to return to the moon by 2024.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
The successful conclusion of that mission will result

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:01.958
in infrequent visitation of the moon by a small number

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
of government scientists and pilots.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:07.958
It will leave us no further along in the general expansion

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
of humanity into space than we were 50 years ago.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Something fundamental has to change

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
if we are to see common access to space in our lifetime.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
What I'm going to show you next are a couple of controversial ideas.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And I hope you'll bear with me and have some faith

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.958
that there's credibility behind what we're going to say here.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:32.958
There are three underpinnings of working in space privately.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
One of them is the requirement

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
for economical earth-to-space transport.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
The Bert Rutans and Richard Bransons of this world

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
have got this in their sights and I salute them.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
Go, go, go.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
The next thing we need are places to stay on orbit.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
Orbital hotels to start with, but workshops for the rest of us later on.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:56.958
The final missing piece, the real paradigm-buster, is this:

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
a gas station on orbit.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
It's not going to look like that.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:07.958
If it existed, it would change all future spacecraft design and space mission planning.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
Now, to give you a chance to understand

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
why there is power in that statement,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
I've got to give you the basics of Space 101.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:21.958
And the first thing is everything you do in space you pay by the kilogram.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
Anybody drink one of these here this week?

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:30.958
You'd pay 10,000 dollars for that in orbit.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
That's more than you pay for TED,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
if Google dropped their sponsorship.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
(Laughter)

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:42.958
The second is more than 90 percent of the weight of a vehicle is in propellant.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Thus, every time you'd want to do anything in space,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
you are literally blowing away enormous sums of money

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
every time you hit the accelerator.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
Not even the guys at Tesla can fight that physics.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:13:00.958
So, what if you could get your gas at a 10th the price?

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
There is a place where you can.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
In fact, you can get it better -- you can get it at 14 times lower

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
if you can find propellant on the moon.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
There is a little-known mission that was launched

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.958
by the Pentagon, 13 years ago now, called Clementine.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
And the most amazing thing that came out of that mission

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
was a strong hydrogen signature at Shackleton crater

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
on the south pole of the moon.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
That signal was so strong,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
it could only have been produced by 10 trillion tons of water

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
buried in the sediment, collected over millions and billions of years

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:38.958
by the impact of asteroids and comet material.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
If we're going to get that, and make that gas station possible,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
we have to figure out ways to move large volumes of payload through space.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
We can't do that right now.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
The way you normally build a system right now is you have a tube stack

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
that has to be launched from the ground,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
and resist all kinds of aerodynamic forces.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
We have to beat that.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
We can do it because in space there are no aerodynamics.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:06.958
We can go and use inflatable systems for almost everything.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:10.958
This is an idea that, again, came out of Livermore back in 1989,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
with Dr. Lowell Wood's group.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
And we can extend that now to just about everything.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
Bob Bigelow currently has a test article in the orbit.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:19.958
We can go much further.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:24.958
We can build space tugs, orbiting platforms for holding cryogens and water.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
There's another thing.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
When you're coming back from the moon,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
you have to deal with orbital mechanics.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
It says you're moving 10,000 feet per second faster

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
than you really want to be to get back to your gas station.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
You got two choices.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:41.958
You can burn rocket fuel to get there, or you can do something really incredible.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
You can dive into the stratosphere,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and precisely dissipate that velocity, and come back out to the space station.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:48.958
It has never been done.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:52.958
It's risky and it's going to be one hell of a ride --

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
better than Disney.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
The traditional approach to space exploration

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
has been that you carry all the fuel you need

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
to get everybody back in case of an emergency.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
If you try to do that for the moon,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:06.958
you're going to burn a billion dollars in fuel alone sending a crew out there.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
But if you send a mining team there,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
without the return propellant, first --

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:14.958
(Laughter)

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
Did any of you guys hear the story of Cortez?

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
This is not like that. I'm much more like Scotty.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
I like this equipment, you know, and I really value it

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
so we're not going to burn the gear.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:30.958
But, if you were truly bold you could get it there, manufacture it,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
and it would be the most dramatic demonstration

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
that you could do something worthwhile off this planet

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
that has ever been done.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
There's a myth that you can't do anything in space

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:43.958
for less than a trillion dollars and 20 years.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:44.958
That's not true.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
In seven years, we could pull off

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
an industrial mission to Shackleton and demonstrate

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:52.958
that you could provide commercial reality out of this in low-earth orbit.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
We're living in one of the most exciting times in history.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
We're at a magical confluence where private wealth

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:02.958
and imagination are driving the demand for access to space.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
The orbital refueling stations I've just described

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
could create an entirely new industry and provide the final key

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
for opening space to the general exploration.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
To bust the paradigm a radically different approach is needed.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
We can do it by jump-starting with an industrial

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Lewis and Clark expedition to Shackleton crater,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
to mine the moon for resources, and demonstrate

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
they can form the basis for a profitable business on orbit.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Talk about space always seems to be hung on ambiguities

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
of purpose and timing.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:36.958
I would like to close here by putting a stake in the sand at TED.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
I intend to lead that expedition.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:47.958
(Applause)

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
It can be done in seven years with the right backing.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:54.958
Those who join me in making it happen will become a part of history

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
and join other bold individuals from time past

00:16:56.958 --> 00:17:00.958
who, had they been here today, would have heartily approved.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:06.958
There was once a time when people did bold things to open the frontier.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:10.958
We have collectively forgotten that lesson.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:15.958
Now we're at a time when boldness is required to move forward.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:21.958
100 years after Sir Ernest Shackleton wrote these words,

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
I intend to plant an industrial flag on the moon

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
and complete the final piece

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:30.958
that will open the space frontier, in our time, for all of us.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:31.958
Thank you.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:39.958
(Applause)

title: Dangerous memes
transcript: How many Creationists do we have in the room? Probably none. I think we're all Darwinians. And yet many Darwinians are anxious, a little uneasy — would like to see some limits on just how far the Darwinism goes. It's all right. You know spiderwebs? Sure, they are products of evolution. The World Wide Web? Not so sure. Beaver dams, yes. Hoover Dam, no. What do they think it is that prevents the products of human ingenuity from being themselves, fruits of the tree of life, and hence, in some sense, obeying evolutionary rules? And yet people are interestingly resistant to the idea of applying evolutionary thinking to thinking — to our thinking.And so I'm going to talk a little bit about that, keeping in mind that we have a lot on the program here. So you're out in the woods, or you're out in the pasture, and you see this ant crawling up this blade of grass. It climbs up to the top, and it falls, and it climbs, and it falls, and it climbs — trying to stay at the very top of the blade of grass. What is this ant doing? What is this in aid of? What goals is this ant trying to achieve by climbing this blade of grass? What's in it for the ant? And the answer is: nothing. There's nothing in it for the ant. Well then, why is it doing this? Is it just a fluke? Yeah, it's just a fluke. It's a lancet fluke. It's a little brain worm. It's a parasitic brain worm that has to get into the stomach of a sheep or a cow in order to continue its life cycle. Salmon swim upstream to get to their spawning grounds, and lancet flukes commandeer a passing ant, crawl into its brain, and drive it up a blade of grass like an all-terrain vehicle. So there's nothing in it for the ant. The ant's brain has been hijacked by a parasite that infects the brain, inducing suicidal behavior. Pretty scary.Well, does anything like that happen with human beings? This is all on behalf of a cause other than one's own genetic fitness, of course. Well, it may already have occurred to you that Islam means "surrender," or "submission of self-interest to the will of Allah." Well, it's ideas — not worms — that hijack our brains. Now, am I saying that a sizable minority of the world's population has had their brain hijacked by parasitic ideas? No, it's worse than that. Most people have. (Laughter) There are a lot of ideas to die for. Freedom, if you're from New Hampshire. (Laughter) Justice. Truth. Communism. Many people have laid down their lives for communism, and many have laid down their lives for capitalism. And many for Catholicism. And many for Islam. These are just a few of the ideas that are to die for. They're infectious.Yesterday, Amory Lovins spoke about "infectious repititis." It was a term of abuse, in effect. This is unthinking engineering. Well, most of the cultural spread that goes on is not brilliant, new, out-of-the-box thinking. It's "infectious repetitis," and we might as well try to have a theory of what's going on when that happens so that we can understand the conditions of infection. Hosts work hard to spread these ideas to others. I myself am a philosopher, and one of our occupational hazards is that people ask us what the meaning of life is. And you have to have a bumper sticker, you know. You have to have a statement. So, this is mine.The secret of happiness is: Find something more important than you are and dedicate your life to it. Most of us — now that the "Me Decade" is well in the past — now we actually do this. One set of ideas or another have simply replaced our biological imperatives in our own lives. This is what our summum bonum is. It's not maximizing the number of grandchildren we have. Now, this is a profound biological effect. It's the subordination of genetic interest to other interests. And no other species does anything at all like it.Well, how are we going to think about this? It is, on the one hand, a biological effect, and a very large one. Unmistakable. Now, what theories do we want to use to look at this? Well, many theories. But how could something tie them together? The idea of replicating ideas; ideas that replicate by passing from brain to brain. Richard Dawkins, whom you'll be hearing later in the day, invented the term "memes," and put forward the first really clear and vivid version of this idea in his book "The Selfish Gene." Now here am I talking about his idea. Well, you see, it's not his. Yes — he started it. But it's everybody's idea now. And he's not responsible for what I say about memes. I'm responsible for what I say about memes.Actually, I think we're all responsible for not just the intended effects of our ideas, but for their likely misuses. So it is important, I think, to Richard, and to me, that these ideas not be abused and misused. They're very easy to misuse. That's why they're dangerous. And it's just about a full-time job trying to prevent people who are scared of these ideas from caricaturing them and then running off to one dire purpose or another. So we have to keep plugging away, trying to correct the misapprehensions so that only the benign and useful variants of our ideas continue to spread. But it is a problem. We don't have much time, and I'm going to go over just a little bit of this and cut out, because there's a lot of other things that are going to be said.So let me just point out: memes are like viruses. That's what Richard said, back in '93. And you might think, "Well, how can that be? I mean, a virus is — you know, it's stuff! What's a meme made of?" Yesterday, Negroponte was talking about viral telecommunications but — what's a virus? A virus is a string of nucleic acid with attitude. (Laughter) That is, there is something about it that tends to make it replicate better than the competition does. And that's what a meme is. It's an information packet with attitude. What's a meme made of? What are bits made of, Mom? Not silicon. They're made of information, and can be carried in any physical medium. What's a word made of? Sometimes when people say, "Do memes exist?" I say, "Well, do words exist? Are they in your ontology?" If they are, words are memes that can be pronounced.Then there's all the other memes that can't be pronounced. There are different species of memes. Remember the Shakers? Gift to be simple? Simple, beautiful furniture? And, of course, they're basically extinct now. And one of the reasons is that among the creed of Shaker-dom is that one should be celibate. Not just the priests. Everybody. Well, it's not so surprising that they've gone extinct. (Laughter) But in fact that's not why they went extinct. They survived as long as they did at a time when the social safety nets weren't there. And there were lots of widows and orphans, people like that, who needed a foster home. And so they had a ready supply of converts. And they could keep it going. And, in principle, it could've gone on forever, with perfect celibacy on the part of the hosts. The idea being passed on through proselytizing, instead of through the gene line.So the ideas can live on in spite of the fact that they're not being passed on genetically. A meme can flourish in spite of having a negative impact on genetic fitness. After all, the meme for Shaker-dom was essentially a sterilizing parasite. There are other parasites that do this — which render the host sterile. It's part of their plan. They don't have to have minds to have a plan.I'm just going to draw your attention to just one of the many implications of the memetic perspective, which I recommend. I've not time to go into more of it. In Jared Diamond's wonderful book, "Guns, Germs and Steel," he talks about how it was germs, more than guns and steel, that conquered the new hemisphere — the Western hemisphere — that conquered the rest of the world. When European explorers and travelers spread out, they brought with them the germs that they had become essentially immune to, that they had learned how to tolerate over hundreds and hundreds of years, thousands of years, of living with domesticated animals who were the sources of those pathogens. And they just wiped out — these pathogens just wiped out the native people, who had no immunity to them at all.And we're doing it again. We're doing it this time with toxic ideas. Yesterday, a number of people — Nicholas Negroponte and others — spoke about all the wonderful things that are happening when our ideas get spread out, thanks to all the new technology all over the world. And I agree. It is largely wonderful. Largely wonderful. But among all those ideas that inevitably flow out into the whole world thanks to our technology, are a lot of toxic ideas. Now, this has been realized for some time. Sayyid Qutb is one of the founding fathers of fanatical Islam, one of the ideologues that inspired Osama bin Laden. "One has only to glance at its press films, fashion shows, beauty contests, ballrooms, wine bars and broadcasting stations." Memes.These memes are spreading around the world and they are wiping out whole cultures. They are wiping out languages. They are wiping out traditions and practices. And it's not our fault, anymore than it's our fault when our germs lay waste to people that haven't developed the immunity. We have an immunity to all of the junk that lies around the edges of our culture. We're a free society, so we let pornography and all these things — we shrug them off. They're like a mild cold. They're not a big deal for us. But we should recognize that for many people in the world, they are a big deal. And we should be very alert to this. As we spread our education and our technology, one of the things that we are doing is we're the vectors of memes that are correctly viewed by the hosts of many other memes as a dire threat to their favorite memes — the memes that they are prepared to die for.Well now, how are we going to tell the good memes from the bad memes? That is not the job of the science of memetics. Memetics is morally neutral. And so it should be. This is not the place for hate and anger. If you've had a friend who's died of AIDS, then you hate HIV. But the way to deal with that is to do science, and understand how it spreads and why in a morally neutral perspective.Get the facts. Work out the implications. There's plenty of room for moral passion once we've got the facts and can figure out the best thing to do. And, as with germs, the trick is not to try to annihilate them. You will never annihilate the germs. What you can do, however, is foster public health measures and the like that will encourage the evolution of avirulence. That will encourage the spread of relatively benign mutations of the most toxic varieties. That's all the time I have, so thank you very much for your attention.

WEBVTT
