to translate the Bible into Cameroonian patois,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
they chose the Igbo version.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
And I'm not going to give you the patois translation;

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:07.958
I'm going to make it standard English.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:14.958
Basically, it ends up as "God is on a bicycle with his angels."

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:19.958
This is good, because language complicates things.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
You know, we often think that language mirrors

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:25.958
the world in which we live, and I find that's not true.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:30.958
The language actually makes the world in which we live.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
Language is not -- I mean, things don't have

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.958
any mutable value by themselves; we ascribe them a value.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
And language can't be understood in its abstraction.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
It can only be understood in the context of story,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:44.958
and everything, all of this is story.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
And it's important to remember that,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:50.958
because if we don't, then we become ahistorical.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
We've had a lot of -- a parade of amazing ideas here.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
But these are not new to Africa.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
Nigeria got its independence in 1960.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
The first time the possibility for independence was discussed

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
was in 1922, following the Aba women's market riots.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:10.958
In 1967, in the middle of the Biafran-Nigerian Civil War,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
Dr. Njoku-Obi invented the Cholera vaccine.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
So, you know, the thing is to remember that

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
because otherwise, 10 years from now,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
we'll be back here trying to tell this story again.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:27.958
So, what it says to me then is that it's not really --

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
the problem isn't really the stories that are being told

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
or which stories are being told,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
the problem really is the terms of humanity

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
that we're willing to bring to complicate every story,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
and that's really what it's all about.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
Let me tell you a Nigerian joke.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
Well, it's just a joke, anyway.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:48.958
So there's Tom, Dick and Harry and they're working construction.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
And Tom opens up his lunch box and there's rice in it,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
and he goes on this rant about, "Twenty years,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
my wife has been packing rice for lunch.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
If she does it again tomorrow, I'm going to throw myself

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
off this building and kill myself."

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
And Dick and Harry repeat this.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
The next day, Tom opens his lunchbox, there's rice,

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
so he throws himself off and kills himself,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
and Tom, Dick and Harry follow.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
And now the inquest -- you know, Tom's wife

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:10.958
and Dick's wife are distraught.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
They wished they'd not packed rice.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
But Harry's wife is confused, because she said, "You know,

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
Harry had been packing his own lunch for 20 years."

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:22.958
(Laughter)

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:27.958
This seemingly innocent joke, when I heard it as a child in Nigeria,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
was told about Igbo, Yoruba and Hausa,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
with the Hausa being Harry.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
So what seems like an eccentric if tragic joke about Harry

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:39.958
becomes a way to spread ethnic hatred.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:43.958
My father was educated in Cork, in the University of Cork, in the '50s.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
In fact, every time I read in Ireland,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
people get me all mistaken and they say,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
"Oh, this is Chris O'Barney from Cork."

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:53.958
But he was also in Oxford in the '50s,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
and yet growing up as a child in Nigeria,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
my father used to say to me, "You must never eat or drink

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:03.958
in a Yoruba person's house because they will poison you."

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
It makes sense now when I think about it,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:06.958
because if you'd known my father,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
you would've wanted to poison him too.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:14.958
(Laughter)

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:18.958
So I was born in 1966, at the beginning

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:24.958
of the Biafran-Nigerian Civil War, and the war ended after three years.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
And I was growing up in school and the federal government

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
didn't want us taught about the history of the war,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
because they thought it probably would make us

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
generate a new generation of rebels.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
So I had a very inventive teacher, a Pakistani Muslim,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
who wanted to teach us about this.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
So what he did was to teach us Jewish Holocaust history,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:49.958
and so huddled around books with photographs of people in Auschwitz,

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
I learned the melancholic history of my people

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
through the melancholic history of another people.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
I mean, picture this -- really picture this.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:01.958
A Pakistani Muslim teaching Jewish Holocaust history

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:02.958
to young Igbo children.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Story is powerful.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
Story is fluid and it belongs to nobody.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
And it should come as no surprise

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
that my first novel at 16 was about Neo-Nazis

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
taking over Nigeria to institute the Fourth Reich.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:15.958
It makes perfect sense.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
And they were to blow up strategic targets

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
and take over the country, and they were foiled

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
by a Nigerian James Bond called Coyote Williams,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
and a Jewish Nazi hunter.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:29.958
And it happened over four continents.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
And when the book came out, I was heralded as Africa's answer

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:36.958
to Frederick Forsyth, which is a dubious honor at best.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
But also, the book was launched in time for me to be accused

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
of constructing the blueprint for a foiled coup attempt.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:48.958
So at 18, I was bonded off to prison in Nigeria.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:49.958
I grew up very privileged, and it's important

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
to talk about privilege, because we don't talk about it here.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
A lot of us are very privileged.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
I grew up -- servants, cars, televisions, all that stuff.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
My story of Nigeria growing up was very different from the story

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:05.958
I encountered in prison, and I had no language for it.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:09.958
I was completely terrified, completely broken,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:13.958
and kept trying to find a new language,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
a new way to make sense of all of this.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
Six months after that, with no explanation,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:20.958
they let me go.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
Now for those of you who have seen me at the buffet tables know

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
that it was because it was costing them too much to feed me.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:34.958
(Laughter)

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
But I mean, I grew up with this incredible privilege,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
and not just me -- millions of Nigerians

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
grew up with books and libraries.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:44.958
In fact, we were talking last night about how all

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
of the steamy novels of Harold Robbins

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:50.958
had done more for sex education of horny teenage boys in Africa

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:54.958
than any sex education programs ever had.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
All of those are gone.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
We are squandering the most valuable resource

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
we have on this continent: the valuable resource

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
of the imagination.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
In the film, "Sometimes in April" by Raoul Peck,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
Idris Elba is poised in a scene with his machete raised,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:13.958
and he's being forced by a crowd to chop up his best friend --

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
fellow Rwandan Army officer, albeit a Tutsi --

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
played by Fraser James.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:22.958
And Fraser's on his knees, arms tied behind his back,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
and he's crying.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:25.958
He's sniveling.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:26.958
It's a pitiful sight.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:31.958
And as we watch it, we are ashamed.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
And we want to say to Idris, "Chop him up.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
Shut him up."

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:40.958
And as Idris moves, Fraser screams, "Stop!

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
Please stop!"

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Idris pauses, then he moves again,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
and Fraser says, "Please!

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
Please stop!"

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:56.958
And it's not the look of horror and terror on Fraser's face that stops Idris or us;

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
it's the look in Fraser's eyes.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:02.958
It's one that says, "Don't do this.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
And I'm not saying this to save myself,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:08.958
although this would be nice. I'm doing it to save you,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:12.958
because if you do this, you will be lost."

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
To be so afraid that you're standing in the face

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
of a death you can't escape and that you're soiling yourself

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
and crying, but to say in that moment,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:23.958
as Fraser says to Idris, "Tell my girlfriend I love her."

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
In that moment, Fraser says,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:32.958
"I am lost already, but not you ... not you."

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
This is a redemption we can all aspire to.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:39.958
African narratives in the West, they proliferate.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:40.958
I really don't care anymore.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:44.958
I'm more interested in the stories we tell about ourselves --

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:49.958
how as a writer, I find that African writers

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
have always been the curators of our humanity on this continent.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:58.958
The question is, how do I balance narratives that are wonderful

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
with narratives of wounds and self-loathing?

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
And this is the difficulty that I face.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
I am trying to move beyond political rhetoric

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
to a place of ethical questioning.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
I am asking us to balance the idea

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.958
of our complete vulnerability with the complete notion

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
of transformation of what is possible.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
As a young middle-class Nigerian activist,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
I launched myself along with a whole generation of us

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
into the campaign to stop the government.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
And I asked millions of people,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
without questioning my right to do so,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
to go up against the government.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
And I watched them being locked up in prison and tear gassed.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
I justified it, and I said, "This is the cost of revolution.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
Have I not myself been imprisoned?

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
Have I not myself been beaten?"

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
It wasn't until later, when I was imprisoned again,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
that I understood the real meaning of torture,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
and how easy your humanity can be taken from you,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
for the time I was engaged in war,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
righteous, righteous war.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
Excuse me.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
Sometimes I can stand before the world --

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
and when I say this, transformation

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
is a difficult and slow process --

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
sometimes I can stand before the world and say,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
"My name is Chris Abani.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
I have been human six days, but only sometimes."

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
But this is a good thing.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
It's never going to be easy.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
There are no answers.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
As I was telling Rachel from Google Earth,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
that I had challenged my students in America --

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
I said, "You don't know anything about Africa, you're all idiots."

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
And so they said, "Tell me about Africa, Professor Abani."

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
So I went to Google Earth and learned about Africa.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
And the truth be told, this is it, isn't it?

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:35.958
There are no essential Africans,

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
and most of us are as completely ignorant as everyone else

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
about the continent we come from,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
and yet we want to make profound statements about it.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And I think if we can just admit that we're all trying

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
to approximate the truth of our own communities,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
it will make for a much more nuanced

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
and a much more interesting conversation.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.958
I want to believe that we can be agnostic about this,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
that we can rise above all of this.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
When I was 10, I read James Baldwin's "Another Country,"

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
and that book broke me.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
Not because I was encountering homosexual sex and love

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
for the first time, but because the way James wrote about it

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
made it impossible for me to attach otherness to it.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
"Here," Jimmy said.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
"Here is love, all of it."

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
The fact that it happens in "Another Country"

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
takes you quite by surprise.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
My friend Ronald Gottesman says there are three kinds of people in the world:

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
those who can count, and those who can't.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:31.958
(Laughter)

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
He also says that the cause of all our trouble

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
is the belief in an essential, pure identity:

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:42.958
religious, ethnic, historical, ideological.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
I want to leave you with a poem by Yusef Komunyakaa

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
that speaks to transformation.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
It's called "Ode to the Drum," and I'll try and read it

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
the way Yusef would be proud to hear it read.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:03.958
"Gazelle, I killed you for your skin's exquisite touch,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
for how easy it is to be nailed to a board

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
weathered raw as white butcher paper.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:15.958
Last night I heard my daughter praying for the meat here at my feet.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:19.958
You know it wasn't anger that made me stop my heart till the hammer fell.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
Weeks ago, you broke me as a woman

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
once shattered me into a song beneath her weight,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
before you slouched into that grassy hush.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:34.958
And now I'm tightening lashes, shaped in hide as if around a ribcage,

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
shaped like five bowstrings.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
Ghosts cannot slip back inside the body's drum.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:43.958
You've been seasoned by wind, dusk and sunlight.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:47.958
Pressure can make everything whole again.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
Brass nails tacked into the ebony wood,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
your face has been carved five times.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
I have to drive trouble in the hills.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
Trouble in the valley,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
and trouble by the river too.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:02.958
There is no palm wine, fish, salt, or calabash.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:06.958
Kadoom. Kadoom. Kadoom.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
Ka-doooom.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.958
Now I have beaten a song back into you.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:16.958
Rise and walk away like a panther."

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
Thank you.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:31.958
(Applause)

title: Patient capitalism
transcript: I really am honored to be here, and as Chris said, it's been over 20 years since I started working in Africa. My first introduction was at the Abidjan airport on a sweaty, Ivory Coast morning. I had just left Wall Street, cut my hair to look like Margaret Mead, given away most everything that I owned, and arrived with all the essentials — some poetry, a few clothes, and, of course, a guitar — because I was going to save the world, and I thought I would just start with the African continent.But literally within days of arriving I was told, in no uncertain terms, by a number of West African women, that Africans didn't want saving, thank you very much, least of all not by me. I was too young, unmarried, I had no children, didn't really know Africa, and besides, my French was pitiful. And so, it was an incredibly painful time in my life, and yet it really started to give me the humility to start listening.I think that failure can be an incredibly motivating force as well, so I moved to Kenya and worked in Uganda, and I met a group of Rwandan women, who asked me, in 1986, to move to Kigali to help them start the first microfinance institution there. And I did, and we ended up naming it Duterimbere, meaning "to go forward with enthusiasm." And while we were doing it, I realized that there weren't a lot of businesses that were viable and started by women, and so maybe I should try to run a business, too. And so I started looking around, and I heard about a bakery that was run by 20 prostitutes. And, being a little intrigued, I went to go meet this group, and what I found was 20 unwed mothers who were trying to survive.And it was really the beginning of my understanding the power of language, and how what we call people so often distances us from them, and makes them little. I also found out that the bakery was nothing like a business, that, in fact, it was a classic charity run by a well-intentioned person, who essentially spent 600 dollars a month to keep these 20 women busy making little crafts and baked goods, and living on 50 cents a day, still in poverty. So, I made a deal with the women. I said, "Look, we get rid of the charity side, and we run this as a business and I'll help you." They nervously agreed. I nervously started, and, of course, things are always harder than you think they're going to be.First of all, I thought, well, we need a sales team, and we clearly aren't the A-Team here, so let's — I did all this training. And the epitome was when I literally marched into the streets of Nyamirambo, which is the popular quarter of Kigali, with a bucket, and I sold all these little doughnuts to people, and I came back, and I was like, "You see?" And the women said, "You know, Jacqueline, who in Nyamirambo is not going to buy doughnuts out of an orange bucket from a tall American woman?" And like — (Laughter) — it's a good point.So then I went the whole American way, with competitions, team and individual. Completely failed, but over time, the women learnt to sell on their own way. And they started listening to the marketplace, and they came back with ideas for cassava chips, and banana chips, and sorghum bread, and before you knew it, we had cornered the Kigali market, and the women were earning three to four times the national average. And with that confidence surge, I thought, "Well, it's time to create a real bakery, so let's paint it." And the women said, "That's a really great idea." And I said, "Well, what color do you want to paint it?" And they said, "Well, you choose." And I said, "No, no, I'm learning to listen. You choose. It's your bakery, your street, your country — not mine." But they wouldn't give me an answer. So, one week, two weeks, three weeks went by, and finally I said, "Well, how about blue?" And they said, "Blue, blue, we love blue. Let's do it blue." So, I went to the store, I brought Gaudence, the recalcitrant one of all, and we brought all this paint and fabric to make curtains, and on painting day, we all gathered in Nyamirambo, and the idea was we would paint it white with blue as trim, like a little French bakery. But that was clearly not as satisfying as painting a wall of blue like a morning sky.So, blue, blue, everything became blue. The walls were blue, the windows were blue, the sidewalk out front was painted blue. And Aretha Franklin was shouting "R-E-S-P-E-C-T," the women's hips were swaying and little kids were trying to grab the paintbrushes, but it was their day. And at the end of it, we stood across the street and we looked at what we had done, and I said, "It is so beautiful." And the women said, "It really is." And I said, "And I think the color is perfect," and they all nodded their head, except for Gaudence, and I said, "What?" And she said, "Nothing." And I said, "What?" And she said, "Well, it is pretty, but, you know, our color, really, it is green." And — (Laughter)— I learned then that listening isn't just about patience, but that when you've lived on charity and dependent your whole life long, it's really hard to say what you mean. And, mostly because people never really ask you, and when they do, you don't really think they want to know the truth. And so then I learned that listening is not only about waiting, but it's also learning how better to ask questions.And so, I lived in Kigali for about two and a half years, doing these two things, and it was an extraordinary time in my life. And it taught me three lessons that I think are so important for us today, and certainly in the work that I do. The first is that dignity is more important to the human spirit than wealth. As Eleni has said, when people gain income, they gain choice, and that is fundamental to dignity. But as human beings, we also want to see each other, and we want to be heard by each other, and we should never forget that. The second is that traditional charity and aid are never going to solve the problems of poverty.I think Andrew pretty well covered that, so I will move to the third point, which is that markets alone also are not going to solve the problems of poverty. Yes, we ran this as a business, but someone needed to pay the philanthropic support that came into the training, and the management support, the strategic advice and, maybe most important of all, the access to new contacts, networks and new markets. And so, on a micro level, there's a real role for this combination of investment and philanthropy. And on a macro level — some of the speakers have inferred that even health should be privatized. But, having had a father with heart disease, and realizing that what our family could afford was not what he should have gotten, and having a good friend step in to help, I really believe that all people deserve access to health at prices they can afford. I think the market can help us figure that out, but there's got to be a charitable component, or I don't think we're going to create the kind of societies we want to live in.And so, it was really those lessons that made me decide to build Acumen Fund about six years ago. It's a nonprofit, venture capital fund for the poor, a few oxymorons in one sentence. It essentially raises charitable funds from individuals, foundations and corporations, and then we turn around and we invest equity and loans in both for-profit and nonprofit entities that deliver affordable health, housing, energy, clean water to low income people in South Asia and Africa, so that they can make their own choices. We've invested about 20 million dollars in 20 different enterprises, and have, in so doing, created nearly 20,000 jobs, and delivered tens of millions of services to people who otherwise would not be able to afford them.I want to tell you two stories. Both of them are in Africa. Both of them are about investing in entrepreneurs who are committed to service, and who really know the markets. Both of them live at the confluence of public health and enterprise, and both of them, because they're manufacturers, create jobs directly, and create incomes indirectly, because they're in the malaria sector, and Africa loses about 13 billion dollars a year because of malaria. And so as people get healthier, they also get wealthier.The first one is called Advanced Bio-Extracts Limited. It's a company built in Kenya about seven years ago by an incredible entrepreneur named Patrick Henfrey and his three colleagues. These are old-hand farmers who've gone through all the agricultural ups and downs in Kenya over the last 30 years. Now, this plant is an Artemisia plant; it's the basic component for artemisinin, which is the best-known treatment for malaria. It's indigenous to China and the Far East, but given that the prevalence of malaria is here in Africa, Patrick and his colleagues said, "Let's bring it here, because it's a high value-add product." The farmers get three to four times the yields that they would with maize.And so, using patient capital — money that they could raise early on, that actually got below market returns and was willing to go the long haul and be combined with management assistance, strategic assistance — they've now created a company where they purchase from 7,500 farmers. So that's about 50,000 people affected. And I think some of you may have visited — these farmers are helped by KickStart and TechnoServe, who help them become more self-sufficient. They buy it, they dry it and they bring it to this factory, which was purchased in part by, again, patient capital from Novartis, who has a real interest in getting the powder so that they can make Coartem. Acumen's been working with ABE for the past year, year and a half, both on looking at a new business plan, and what does expansion look like, helping with management support and helping to do term sheets and raise capital. And I really understood what patient capital meant emotionally in the last month or so. Because the company was literally 10 days away from proving that the product they produced was at the world-quality level needed to make Coartem, when they were in the biggest cash crisis of their history.And we called all of the social investors we know. Now, some of these same social investors are really interested in Africa and understand the importance of agriculture, and they even helped the farmers. And even when we explained that if ABE goes away, all those 7,500 jobs go away too, we sometimes have this bifurcation between business and the social. And it's really time we start thinking more creatively about how they can be fused. So Acumen made not one, but two bridge loans, and the good news is they did indeed meet world-quality classification and are now in the final stages of closing a 20-million-dollar round, to move it to the next level, and I think that this will be one of the more important companies in East Africa.This is Samuel. He's a farmer. He was actually living in the Kibera slums when his father called him and told him about Artemisia and the value-add potential. So he moved back to the farm, and, long story short, they now have seven acres under cultivation. Samuel's kids are in private school, and he's starting to help other farmers in the area also go into Artemisia production — dignity being more important than wealth.The next one, many of you know. I talked about it a little at Oxford two years ago, and some of you visited A to Z manufacturing, which is one of the great, real companies in East Africa. It's another one that lives at the confluence of health and enterprise. And this is really a story about a public-private solution that has really worked. It started in Japan. Sumitomo had developed a technology essentially to impregnate a polyethylene-based fiber with organic insecticide, so you could create a bed net, a malaria bed net, that would last five years and not need to be re-dipped.It could alter the vector, but like Artemisia, it had been produced only in East Asia. And as part of its social responsibility, Sumitomo said, "Why don't we experiment with whether we can produce it in Africa, for Africans?" UNICEF came forward and said, "We'll buy most of the nets, and then we'll give them away, as part of the global fund's and the U.N.'s commitment to pregnant women and children, for free." Acumen came in with the patient capital, and we also helped to identify the entrepreneur that we would all partner with here in Africa, and Exxon provided the initial resin.Well, in looking around for entrepreneurs, there was none better that we could find on earth than Anuj Shah, in A to Z manufacturing company. It's a 40-year-old company, it understands manufacturing. It's gone from socialist Tanzania into capitalist Tanzania, and continued to flourish. It had about 1,000 employees when we first found it. And so, Anuj took the entrepreneurial risk here in Africa to produce a public good that was purchased by the aid establishment to work with malaria.And, long story short, again, they've been so successful. In our first year, the first net went off the line in October of 2003. We thought the hitting-it-out-of-the-box number was 150,000 nets a year. This year, they are now producing eight million nets a year, and they employ 5,000 people, 90 percent of whom are women, mostly unskilled. They're in a joint venture with Sumitomo. And so, from an enterprise perspective for Africa, and from a public health perspective, these are real successes.But it's only half the story if we're really looking at solving problems of poverty, because it's not long-term sustainable. It's a company with one big customer. And if avian flu hits, or for any other reason the world decides that malaria is no longer as much of a priority, everybody loses. And so, Anuj and Acumen have been talking about testing the private sector, because the assumption that the aid establishment has made is that, look, in a country like Tanzania, 80 percent of the population makes less than two dollars a day. It costs, at manufacturing point, six dollars to produce these, and it costs the establishment another six dollars to distribute it, so the market price in a free market would be about 12 dollars per net. Most people can't afford that, so let's give it away free. And we said, "Well, there's another option. Let's use the market as the best listening device we have, and understand at what price people would pay for this, so they get the dignity of choice. We can start building local distribution, and actually, it can cost the public sector much less."And so we came in with a second round of patient capital to A to Z, a loan as well as a grant, so that A to Z could play with pricing and listen to the marketplace, and found a number of things. One, that people will pay different prices, but the overwhelming number of people will come forth at one dollar per net and make a decision to buy it. And when you listen to them, they'll also have a lot to say about what they like and what they don't like. And that some of the channels we thought would work didn't work. But because of this experimentation and iteration that was allowed because of the patient capital, we've now found that it costs about a dollar in the private sector to distribute, and a dollar to buy the net. So then, from a policy perspective, when you start with the market, we have a choice. We can continue going along at 12 dollars a net, and the customer pays zero, or we could at least experiment with some of it, to charge one dollar a net, costing the public sector another six dollars a net, give the people the dignity of choice, and have a distribution system that might, over time, start sustaining itself.We've got to start having conversations like this, and I don't think there's any better way to start than using the market, but also to bring other people to the table around it. Whenever I go to visit A to Z, I think of my grandmother, Stella. She was very much like those women sitting behind the sewing machines. She grew up on a farm in Austria, very poor, didn't have very much education. She moved to the United States, where she met my grandfather, who was a cement hauler, and they had nine children. Three of them died as babies. My grandmother had tuberculosis, and she worked in a sewing machine shop, making shirts for about 10 cents an hour. She, like so many of the women I see at A to Z, worked hard every day, understood what suffering was, had a deep faith in God, loved her children and would never have accepted a handout. But because she had the opportunity of the marketplace, and she lived in a society that provided the safety of having access to affordable health and education, her children and their children were able to live lives of real purpose and follow real dreams.I look around at my siblings and my cousins — and as I said, there are a lot of us — and I see teachers and musicians, hedge fund managers, designers. One sister who makes other people's wishes come true. And my wish, when I see those women, I meet those farmers, and I think about all the people across this continent who are working hard every day, is that they have that sense of opportunity and possibility, and that they also can believe and get access to services, so that their children, too, can live those lives of great purpose. It shouldn't be that difficult. But what it takes is a commitment from all of us to essentially refuse trite assumptions, get out of our ideological boxes. It takes investing in those entrepreneurs that are committed to service as well as to success. It takes opening your arms, both, wide, and expecting very little love in return, but demanding accountability, and bringing the accountability to the table as well. And most of all, most of all, it requires that all of us have the courage and the patience, whether we are rich or poor, African or non-African, local or diaspora, left or right, to really start listening to each other. Thank you. (Applause)

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I really am honored to be here, and as Chris said,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
it's been over 20 years since I started working in Africa.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:23.958
My first introduction was at the Abidjan airport on a sweaty, Ivory Coast morning.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:27.958
I had just left Wall Street, cut my hair to look like Margaret Mead,

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:29.958
given away most everything that I owned,

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
and arrived with all the essentials --

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
some poetry, a few clothes, and, of course, a guitar --

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
because I was going to save the world,

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:41.958
and I thought I would just start with the African continent.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.958
But literally within days of arriving I was told, in no uncertain terms,

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:50.958
by a number of West African women, that Africans didn't want saving,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
thank you very much, least of all not by me.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
I was too young, unmarried, I had no children,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:59.958
didn't really know Africa, and besides, my French was pitiful.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
And so, it was an incredibly painful time in my life,

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:07.958
and yet it really started to give me the humility to start listening.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:11.958
I think that failure can be an incredibly motivating force as well,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
so I moved to Kenya and worked in Uganda,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
and I met a group of Rwandan women, who asked me, in 1986,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:21.958
to move to Kigali to help them start the first microfinance institution there.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:25.958
And I did, and we ended up naming it Duterimbere,

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:28.958
meaning "to go forward with enthusiasm." And while we were doing it,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
I realized that there weren't a lot of businesses that were viable

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:35.958
and started by women, and so maybe I should try to run a business, too.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
And so I started looking around, and I heard about a bakery

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
that was run by 20 prostitutes.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:43.958
And, being a little intrigued, I went to go meet this group,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:48.958
and what I found was 20 unwed mothers who were trying to survive.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:53.958
And it was really the beginning of my understanding the power of language,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
and how what we call people so often distances us from them,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
and makes them little.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:02.958
I also found out that the bakery was nothing like a business,

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:06.958
that, in fact, it was a classic charity run by a well-intentioned person,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:10.958
who essentially spent 600 dollars a month

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:15.958
to keep these 20 women busy making little crafts and baked goods,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
and living on 50 cents a day, still in poverty.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
So, I made a deal with the women. I said, "Look, we get rid of the charity side,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
and we run this as a business and I'll help you."

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:28.958
They nervously agreed. I nervously started, and, of course,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
things are always harder than you think they're going to be.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
First of all, I thought, well, we need a sales team,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
and we clearly aren't the A-Team here,

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
so let's -- I did all this training.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:41.958
And the epitome was when I literally marched into the streets

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
of Nyamirambo, which is the popular quarter of Kigali, with a bucket,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and I sold all these little doughnuts to people,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
and I came back, and I was like, "You see?"

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
And the women said, "You know, Jacqueline, who in Nyamirambo is not going to buy

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.958
doughnuts out of an orange bucket from a tall American woman?" And like --

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
(Laughter) -- it's a good point.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
So then I went the whole American way,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
with competitions, team and individual. Completely failed,

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:08.958
but over time, the women learnt to sell on their own way.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
And they started listening to the marketplace,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
and they came back with ideas for cassava chips, and banana chips,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
and sorghum bread, and before you knew it,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
we had cornered the Kigali market,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
and the women were earning three to four times the national average.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.958
And with that confidence surge, I thought, "Well, it's time to create a real bakery,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:28.958
so let's paint it." And the women said, "That's a really great idea."

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
And I said, "Well, what color do you want to paint it?" And they said,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
"Well, you choose." And I said, "No, no, I'm learning to listen.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
You choose. It's your bakery, your street, your country -- not mine."

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
But they wouldn't give me an answer.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
So, one week, two weeks, three weeks went by,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
and finally I said, "Well, how about blue?"

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
And they said, "Blue, blue, we love blue. Let's do it blue."

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:49.958
So, I went to the store, I brought Gaudence, the recalcitrant one of all,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:53.958
and we brought all this paint and fabric to make curtains,

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
and on painting day, we all gathered in Nyamirambo,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
and the idea was we would paint it white with blue as trim,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
like a little French bakery. But that was clearly not as satisfying

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
as painting a wall of blue like a morning sky.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
So, blue, blue, everything became blue.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:09.958
The walls were blue, the windows were blue,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
the sidewalk out front was painted blue.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:16.958
And Aretha Franklin was shouting "R-E-S-P-E-C-T,"

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
the women's hips were swaying

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
and little kids were trying to grab the paintbrushes, but it was their day.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
And at the end of it, we stood across the street

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
and we looked at what we had done, and I said, "It is so beautiful."

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
And the women said, "It really is."

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
And I said, "And I think the color is perfect,"

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
and they all nodded their head, except for Gaudence,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
and I said, "What?"

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
And she said, "Nothing." And I said, "What?"

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:44.958
And she said, "Well, it is pretty, but, you know, our color, really, it is green." And --

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
(Laughter)

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:52.958
-- I learned then that listening isn't just about patience,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:57.958
but that when you've lived on charity and dependent your whole life long,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
it's really hard to say what you mean.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
And, mostly because people never really ask you,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
and when they do, you don't really think they want to know the truth.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
And so then I learned that listening is not only about waiting,

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:13.958
but it's also learning how better to ask questions.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And so, I lived in Kigali for about two and a half years, doing these two things,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
and it was an extraordinary time in my life.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And it taught me three lessons

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
that I think are so important for us today,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
and certainly in the work that I do.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
The first is that dignity is more important to the human spirit than wealth.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
As Eleni has said, when people gain income, they gain choice,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
and that is fundamental to dignity.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
But as human beings, we also want to see each other,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:43.958
and we want to be heard by each other, and we should never forget that.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
The second is that traditional charity and aid

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
are never going to solve the problems of poverty.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
I think Andrew pretty well covered that, so I will move to the third point,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
which is that markets alone also

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
are not going to solve the problems of poverty.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
Yes, we ran this as a business,

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:03.958
but someone needed to pay the philanthropic support

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
that came into the training, and the management support, the strategic advice

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
and, maybe most important of all,

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:13.958
the access to new contacts, networks and new markets.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:17.958
And so, on a micro level, there's a real role for this combination

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
of investment and philanthropy.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:24.958
And on a macro level -- some of the speakers have inferred that

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
even health should be privatized.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
But, having had a father with heart disease,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
and realizing that what our family could afford

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
was not what he should have gotten,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
and having a good friend step in to help,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
I really believe that all people deserve access to health

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
at prices they can afford.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
I think the market can help us figure that out,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
but there's got to be a charitable component,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:51.958
or I don't think we're going to create the kind of societies we want to live in.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
And so, it was really those lessons that made me decide to

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
build Acumen Fund about six years ago.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
It's a nonprofit, venture capital fund for the poor,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
a few oxymorons in one sentence.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:07.958
It essentially raises charitable funds from individuals, foundations and corporations,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
and then we turn around and we invest equity and loans

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
in both for-profit and nonprofit entities

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
that deliver affordable health, housing, energy, clean water

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
to low income people in South Asia and Africa,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
so that they can make their own choices.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
We've invested about 20 million dollars in 20 different enterprises,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:29.958
and have, in so doing, created nearly 20,000 jobs,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
and delivered tens of millions of services to people

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
who otherwise would not be able to afford them.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
I want to tell you two stories. Both of them are in Africa.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
Both of them are about investing in entrepreneurs

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
who are committed to service, and who really know the markets.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
Both of them live at the confluence of public health and enterprise,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
and both of them, because they're manufacturers,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
create jobs directly, and create incomes indirectly,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
because they're in the malaria sector,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:08:00.958
and Africa loses about 13 billion dollars a year because of malaria.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:04.958
And so as people get healthier, they also get wealthier.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
The first one is called Advanced Bio-Extracts Limited.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
It's a company built in Kenya about seven years ago

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
by an incredible entrepreneur named Patrick Henfrey and his three colleagues.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
These are old-hand farmers

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
who've gone through all the agricultural ups and downs

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
in Kenya over the last 30 years.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
Now, this plant is an Artemisia plant;

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
it's the basic component for artemisinin,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
which is the best-known treatment for malaria.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
It's indigenous to China and the Far East,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
but given that the prevalence of malaria is here in Africa,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:36.958
Patrick and his colleagues said, "Let's bring it here,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
because it's a high value-add product."

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:44.958
The farmers get three to four times the yields that they would with maize.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:48.958
And so, using patient capital -- money that they could raise early on,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
that actually got below market returns

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
and was willing to go the long haul and be combined

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
with management assistance, strategic assistance --

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:01.958
they've now created a company where they purchase from 7,500 farmers.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
So that's about 50,000 people affected.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
And I think some of you may have visited --

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
these farmers are helped by KickStart and TechnoServe,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
who help them become more self-sufficient.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
They buy it, they dry it and they bring it to this factory,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.958
which was purchased in part by, again, patient capital from Novartis,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
who has a real interest in getting the powder

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
so that they can make Coartem.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
Acumen's been working with ABE for the past year, year and a half,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
both on looking at a new business plan,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
and what does expansion look like, helping with management support

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
and helping to do term sheets and raise capital.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And I really understood what patient capital meant emotionally

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
in the last month or so. Because the company was literally

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
10 days away from proving that the product they produced

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
was at the world-quality level needed to make Coartem,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
when they were in the biggest cash crisis of their history.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
And we called all of the social investors we know.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Now, some of these same social investors are really interested in Africa

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
and understand the importance of agriculture,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
and they even helped the farmers.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
And even when we explained that if ABE goes away,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.958
all those 7,500 jobs go away too,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:19.958
we sometimes have this bifurcation between business and the social.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:23.958
And it's really time we start thinking more creatively about how they can be fused.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
So Acumen made not one, but two bridge loans,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:32.958
and the good news is they did indeed meet world-quality classification and are now

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
in the final stages of closing a 20-million-dollar round, to move it to the next level,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:42.958
and I think that this will be one of the more important companies in East Africa.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
This is Samuel. He's a farmer.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
He was actually living in the Kibera slums

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:51.958
when his father called him and told him about Artemisia and the value-add potential.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
So he moved back to the farm, and, long story short,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
they now have seven acres under cultivation.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
Samuel's kids are in private school,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:05.958
and he's starting to help other farmers in the area also go into Artemisia production --

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
dignity being more important than wealth.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
The next one, many of you know.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
I talked about it a little at Oxford two years ago,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
and some of you visited A to Z manufacturing,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:20.958
which is one of the great, real companies in East Africa.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:25.958
It's another one that lives at the confluence of health and enterprise.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:29.958
And this is really a story about a public-private solution

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
that has really worked.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.958
It started in Japan. Sumitomo had developed a technology

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
essentially to impregnate a polyethylene-based fiber with organic insecticide,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
so you could create a bed net,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
a malaria bed net, that would last five years and not need to be re-dipped.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
It could alter the vector, but like Artemisia,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
it had been produced only in East Asia. And as part of its social responsibility,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
Sumitomo said, "Why don't we experiment

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
with whether we can produce it in Africa, for Africans?"

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
UNICEF came forward and said, "We'll buy most of the nets,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
and then we'll give them away, as part of the global fund's

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and the U.N.'s commitment to pregnant women and children, for free."

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
Acumen came in with the patient capital,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
and we also helped to identify the entrepreneur

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
that we would all partner with here in Africa,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
and Exxon provided the initial resin.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
Well, in looking around for entrepreneurs,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
there was none better that we could find on earth than Anuj Shah,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
in A to Z manufacturing company.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
It's a 40-year-old company, it understands manufacturing.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
It's gone from socialist Tanzania into capitalist Tanzania,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:37.958
and continued to flourish. It had about 1,000 employees when we first found it.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
And so, Anuj took the entrepreneurial risk here in Africa

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:45.958
to produce a public good that was purchased by the aid establishment

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
to work with malaria.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
And, long story short, again, they've been so successful.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:56.958
In our first year, the first net went off the line in October of 2003.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:01.958
We thought the hitting-it-out-of-the-box number was 150,000 nets a year.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
This year, they are now producing eight million nets a year,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:09.958
and they employ 5,000 people, 90 percent of whom are women, mostly unskilled.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
They're in a joint venture with Sumitomo.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
And so, from an enterprise perspective for Africa,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
and from a public health perspective, these are real successes.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
But it's only half the story if we're really looking at solving problems of poverty,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
because it's not long-term sustainable.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
It's a company with one big customer.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
And if avian flu hits, or for any other reason

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:35.958
the world decides that malaria is no longer as much of a priority, everybody loses.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
And so, Anuj and Acumen

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
have been talking about testing the private sector,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:46.958
because the assumption that the aid establishment has made is that,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
look, in a country like Tanzania,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
80 percent of the population makes less than two dollars a day.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
It costs, at manufacturing point, six dollars to produce these,

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and it costs the establishment another six dollars to distribute it,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
so the market price in a free market would be about 12 dollars per net.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
Most people can't afford that, so let's give it away free.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
And we said, "Well, there's another option.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
Let's use the market as the best listening device we have, and

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:16.958
understand at what price people would pay for this, so they get the dignity of choice.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
We can start building local distribution,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
and actually, it can cost the public sector much less."

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
And so we came in with a second round of patient capital to A to Z,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:30.958
a loan as well as a grant, so that A to Z could play with pricing

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
and listen to the marketplace, and found a number of things.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
One, that people will pay different prices,

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:39.958
but the overwhelming number of people will come forth at one dollar per net

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
and make a decision to buy it.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And when you listen to them, they'll also have a lot to say

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
about what they like and what they don't like.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
And that some of the channels we thought would work didn't work.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
But because of this experimentation and iteration that was allowed

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
because of the patient capital,

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
we've now found that it costs about a dollar in the private sector

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
to distribute, and a dollar to buy the net.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:04.958
So then, from a policy perspective, when you start with the market,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:05.958
we have a choice.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:11.958
We can continue going along at 12 dollars a net, and the customer pays zero,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:17.958
or we could at least experiment with some of it, to charge one dollar a net,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
costing the public sector another six dollars a net,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:24.958
give the people the dignity of choice, and have a distribution system

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
that might, over time, start sustaining itself.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
We've got to start having conversations like this,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:33.958
and I don't think there's any better way to start than using the market,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
but also to bring other people to the table around it.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:44.958
Whenever I go to visit A to Z, I think of my grandmother, Stella.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:49.958
She was very much like those women sitting behind the sewing machines.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
She grew up on a farm in Austria, very poor,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
didn't have very much education.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
She moved to the United States, where she met my grandfather,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
who was a cement hauler,

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:03.958
and they had nine children. Three of them died as babies.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
My grandmother had tuberculosis, and she worked in a sewing machine shop,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
making shirts for about 10 cents an hour.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
She, like so many of the women I see at A to Z,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
worked hard every day, understood what suffering was,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
had a deep faith in God, loved her children

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
and would never have accepted a handout.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
But because she had the opportunity of the marketplace,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
and she lived in a society that provided the safety

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:33.958
of having access to affordable health and education,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:37.958
her children and their children were able to live

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
lives of real purpose and follow real dreams.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:44.958
I look around at my siblings and my cousins -- and as I said,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
there are a lot of us --

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:52.958
and I see teachers and musicians, hedge fund managers, designers.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:55.958
One sister who makes other people's wishes come true.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:17:00.958
And my wish, when I see those women, I meet those farmers,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
and I think about all the people across this continent

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
who are working hard every day,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:09.958
is that they have that sense of opportunity and possibility,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:14.958
and that they also can believe and get access to services,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:18.958
so that their children, too, can live those lives of great purpose.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
It shouldn't be that difficult.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:24.958
But what it takes is a commitment from all of us

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:28.958
to essentially refuse trite assumptions,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:31.958
get out of our ideological boxes.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
It takes investing in those entrepreneurs that are committed

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:38.958
to service as well as to success.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
It takes opening your arms, both, wide,

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
and expecting very little love in return,

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:46.958
but demanding accountability,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
and bringing the accountability to the table as well.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
And most of all, most of all,

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:56.958
it requires that all of us have the courage and the patience,

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:59.958
whether we are rich or poor, African or non-African,

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
local or diaspora, left or right,

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
to really start listening to each other.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
Thank you.

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:16.958
(Applause)

title: "Thula Mama"
transcript: I’d like to dedicate this one to all the women in South Africa — those women who refused to dwindle in the midst of apartheid. And, of course, I’m dedicating it also to my grandmother, whom I think really played quite a lot of important roles, especially for me when I was an activist, and being harassed by the police.You will recall that in 1976, June 16, the students of South Africa boycotted the language of Afrikaans as the medium of the oppressor, as they were sort of like really told that they must do everything in Afrikaans — biology, mathematics — and what about our languages? And the students wanted to speak to the government, and police answered with bullets. So every year, June 16, we will commemorate all those comrades or students who died. And I was very young then. I think I was 11 years, and I started asking questions, and that’s when my political education started. And I joined, later on, the youth organization under the African National Congress. So as part of organizing this and whatever, this commemoration, the police will round us up as they call us leaders. And I used to run away from home, when I know that maybe the police might be coming around the ninth or 10th of June or so. And my grandmother one time said, "No, look, you’re not going to run away. This is your place, you stay here." And indeed, the police came — because they’ll just arrest us and put us in jail and release us whenever they feel like, after the 20th or so.So it was on the 10th of June, and they came, and they surrounded the house, and my grandmother switched off all the lights in the house, and opened the kitchen door. And she said to them, "Vusi's here, and you're not going to take him tonight. I'm tired of you having to come here, harassing us, while your children are sleeping peacefully in your homes. He is here, and you're not going to take him. I've got a bowl full of boiling water — the first one who comes in here, gets it." And they left. No, no, no, no, no. no. ♫ ♫ Is it right heaping trouble on an old lady's head? ♫ ♫ So unlucky faceless people. ♫ ♫ Thula Mama Mama, Thula Mama. Thula Mama Mama. ♫ ♫ Thula Mama, Thula Mama, Thula Mama Mama, Thula Mama ♫ ♫ Tomorrow it’s going to be better. ♫ ♫ Tomorrow it's going to be better to climb, Mama. ♫ ♫ Thula Mama, Thula Mama. ♫♫ Am I to break into the song like the blues man or troubadour. ♫ ♫ And then from long distance in no blues club am I to sing, ♫ ♫ baby, baby, baby, baby, baby, baby, baby, baby, baby, baby, baby, baby. ♫ ♫ Should I now stop singing of love, ♫ ♫ now that my memory’s surrounded by blood? ♫ ♫ Sister, why oh why do we at times mistake a pimple for a cancer? ♫ ♫ So who are they who says, no more love poems now? ♫♫ I want to sing a song of love ♫ ♫ for that woman who jumped the fences pregnant ♫ ♫ and still gave birth to a healthy child. ♫ ♫ Softly I walk into the sun rays of the smile ♫ ♫ that will ignite my love song, my song of life, ♫ ♫ my song of love, my song of life, my song of love, ♫ ♫ my song of life, my song of love, my song of life. ♫ ♫ Ooh, I’ve not tried to run away from song, ♫ ♫ I hear a persistent voice, more powerful than the enemy bombs. ♫ ♫ The song that washed our lives and the rains of our blood. ♫♫ My song of love and my song of life, my song of love, ♫ ♫ my song of life, my song of love, ♫ ♫ my song of life, my song of love — I want everybody to sing with me — ♫ ♫ my song of life, my song of love, my song of life — everybody sing with me — ♫ ♫ my song of life, my song of love — I can’t hear you — ♫ ♫ my song of love, my song of life — you can do better — ♫ ♫ my song of life, my song of love — keep singing, keep singing — ♫ ♫ my song of love, my song of life, yes, my song of love — ♫ ♫ you can do better than that — ♫ ♫ my song of life, yes, my song of love, my song of life, my song of love — ♫ ♫ keep singing, keep singing, keep singing — my song of love. ♫ ♫ Oh yeah. My song of — a love song, my song of life. Sing. A love song, my song of life. Sing. ♫ ♫ Love song, my song of life. Sing. Love song, my song of life. Sing. ♫ ♫ Love song, my song of life. Sing. Love song, my song of life. ♫ ♫ Love song, my song of life. ♫ (Applause)
