00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
what do people carry?

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
And it turns out that people carry a lot of stuff.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
OK, that's fair enough.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:35.958
But if you ask people what the three most important things that they carry are --

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:39.958
across cultures and across gender and across contexts --

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
most people will say keys, money

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
and, if they own one, a mobile phone.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
And I'm not saying this is a good thing, but this is a thing, right?

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
I mean, I couldn't take your phones off you if I wanted to.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:54.958
You'd probably kick me out, or something.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
OK, it might seem like an obvious thing

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
for someone who works for a mobile phone company to ask.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
But really, the question is, why? Right?

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
So why are these things so important in our lives?

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:09.958
And it turns out, from our research, that it boils down to survival --

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:13.958
survival for us and survival for our loved ones.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:18.958
So, keys provide an access to shelter and warmth --

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
transport as well, in the U.S. increasingly.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:25.958
Money is useful for buying food, sustenance,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:26.958
among all its other uses.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:31.958
And a mobile phone, it turns out, is a great recovery tool.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
If you prefer this kind of Maslow's hierarchy of needs,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
those three objects are very good at supporting

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
the lowest rungs in Maslow's hierarchy of needs.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
Yes, they do a whole bunch of other stuff,

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
but they're very good at this.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:49.958
And in particular, it's the mobile phone's ability

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
to allow people to transcend space and time.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
And what I mean by that is, you know,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:58.958
you can transcend space by simply making a voice call, right?

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
And you can transcend time by sending a message at your convenience,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
and someone else can pick it up at their convenience.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:09.958
And this is fairly universally appreciated, it turns out,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
which is why we have three billion plus people who have been connected.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
And they value that connectivity.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
But actually, you can do this kind of stuff with PCs.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
And you can do them with phone kiosks.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And the mobile phone, in addition, is both personal --

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
and so it also gives you a degree of privacy -- and it's convenient.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
You don't need to ask permission from anyone,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
you can just go ahead and do it, right?

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:36.958
However, for these things to help us survive,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
it depends on them being carried.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:42.958
But -- and it's a pretty big but -- we forget.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
We're human, that's what we do. It's one of our features.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
I think, quite a nice feature.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:52.958
So we forget, but we're also adaptable,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
and we adapt to situations around us pretty well.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
And so we have these strategies to remember,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
and one of them was mentioned yesterday.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
And it's, quite simply, the point of reflection.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
And that's that moment when you're walking out of a space,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
and you turn around, and quite often you tap your pockets.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
Even women who keep stuff in their bags tap their pockets.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
And you turn around, and you look back into the space,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
and some people talk aloud.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And pretty much everyone does it at some point.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:22.958
OK, the next thing is -- most of you, if you have a stable home life,

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
and what I mean is that you don't travel all the time, and always in hotels,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
but most people have what we call a center of gravity.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:32.958
And a center of gravity is where you keep these objects.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
And these things don't stay in the center of gravity,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
but over time, they gravitate there.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
It's where you expect to find stuff.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:39.958
And in fact, when you're turning around,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
and you're looking inside the house,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
and you're looking for this stuff,

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
this is where you look first, right?

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:49.958
OK, so when we did this research,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
we found the absolutely, 100 percent, guaranteed way

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
to never forget anything ever, ever again.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:06:00.958
And that is, quite simply, to have nothing to remember.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:01.958
(Laughter)

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
OK, now, that sounds like something you get on a Chinese fortune cookie, right?

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:09.958
But is, in fact, about the art of delegation.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And from a design perspective,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:16.958
it's about understanding what you can delegate to technology

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
and what you can delegate to other people.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
And it turns out, delegation -- if you want it to be --

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:25.958
can be the solution for pretty much everything,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
apart from things like bodily functions, going to the toilet.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
You can't ask someone to do that on your behalf.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
And apart from things like entertainment,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
you wouldn't pay for someone to go to the cinema for you and have fun on your behalf,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
or, at least, not yet.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
Maybe sometime in the future, we will.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:45.958
So, let me give you an example of delegation in practice, right.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
So this is -- probably the thing I'm most passionate about

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
is the research that we've been doing on illiteracy

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and how people who are illiterate communicate.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:56.958
So, the U.N. estimated -- this is 2004 figures --

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
that there are almost 800 million people who can't read and write, worldwide.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
So, we've been conducting a lot of research.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
And one of the things we were looking at is --

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
if you can't read and write,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
if you want to communicate over distances,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
you need to be able to identify the person

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
that you want to communicate with.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
It could be a phone number, it could be an e-mail address,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:19.958
it could be a postal address.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
Simple question: if you can't read and write,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
how do you manage your contact information?

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
And the fact is that millions of people do it.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
Just from a design perspective, we didn't really understand how they did it,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
and so that's just one small example

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
of the kind of research that we were doing.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
And it turns out that illiterate people are masters of delegation.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:42.958
So they delegate that part of the task process to other people,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
the stuff that they can't do themselves.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Let me give you another example of delegation.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
This one's a little bit more sophisticated,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
and this is from a study that we did in Uganda

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:55.958
about how people who are sharing devices, use those devices.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
Sente is a word in Uganda that means money.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:03.958
It has a second meaning, which is to send money as airtime. OK?

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
And it works like this.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
So let's say, June, you're in a village, rural village.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
I'm in Kampala and I'm the wage earner.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
I'm sending money back, and it works like this.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
So, in your village, there's one person in the village with a phone,

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:19.958
and that's the phone kiosk operator.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.958
And it's quite likely that they'd have a quite simple mobile phone as a phone kiosk.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:28.958
So what I do is, I buy a prepaid card like this.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
And instead of using that money to top up my own phone,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
I call up the local village operator.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
And I read out that number to them, and they use it to top up their phone.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
So, they're topping up the value from Kampala,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and it's now being topped up in the village.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
You take a 10 or 20 percent commission, and then you --

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
the kiosk operator takes 10 or 20 percent commission,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.958
and passes the rest over to you in cash.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
OK, there's two things I like about this.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:59.958
So the first is, it turns anyone who has access to a mobile phone --

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
anyone who has a mobile phone --

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
essentially into an ATM machine.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
It brings rudimentary banking services to places

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
where there's no banking infrastructure.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
And even if they could have access to the banking infrastructure,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
they wouldn't necessarily be considered viable customers,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
because they're not wealthy enough to have bank accounts.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
There's a second thing I like about this.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
And that is that despite all the resources at my disposal,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
and despite all our kind of apparent sophistication,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
I know I could never have designed something as elegant

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:35.958
and as totally in tune with the local conditions as this. OK?

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
And, yes, there are things like Grameen Bank and micro-lending.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
But the difference between this and that

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
is, there's no central authority trying to control this.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
This is just street-up innovation.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
So, it turns out the street is a never-ending source of

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
inspiration for us.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
And OK, if you break one of these things here, you return it to the carrier.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:09:59.958
They'll give you a new one.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
They'll probably give you three new ones, right?

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
I mean, that's buy three, get one free. That kind of thing.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:08.958
If you go on the streets of India and China, you see this kind of stuff.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
And this is where they take the stuff that breaks,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.958
and they fix it, and they put it back into circulation.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:20.958
This is from a workbench in Jilin City, in China,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
and you can see people taking down a phone

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and putting it back together.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
They reverse-engineer manuals.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
This is a kind of hacker's manual,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
and it's written in Chinese and English.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
They also write them in Hindi.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
You can subscribe to these.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
There are training institutes where they're churning out people

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
for fixing these things as well.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
But what I like about this is,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:52.958
it boils down to someone on the street with a small, flat surface,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
a screwdriver, a toothbrush for cleaning the contact heads --

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
because they often get dust on the contact heads -- and knowledge.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:04.958
And it's all about the social network of the knowledge, floating around.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:08.958
And I like this because it challenges the way that we design stuff,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
and build stuff, and potentially distribute stuff.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
It challenges the norms.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:19.958
OK, for me the street just raises so many different questions.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:25.958
Like, this is Viagra that I bought from a backstreet sex shop in China.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And China is a country where you get a lot of fakes.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
And I know what you're asking -- did I test it?

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
I'm not going to answer that, OK.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
But I look at something like this, and I consider the implications

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
of trust and confidence in the purchase process.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
And we look at this and we think, well, how does that apply,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
for example, for the design of -- the lessons from this --

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:51.958
apply to the design of online services, future services in these markets?

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
This is a pair of underpants from --

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
(Laughter) --

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
from Tibet.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
And I look at something like this, and honestly, you know,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
why would someone design underpants with a pocket, right?

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
And I look at something like this and it makes me question,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:12.958
if we were to take all the functionality in things like this,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:13.958
and redistribute them around the body

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
in some kind of personal area network,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
how would we prioritize where to put stuff?

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
And yes, this is quite trivial, but actually the lessons from this can apply to that

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
kind of personal area networks.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And what you see here is a couple of phone numbers

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
written above the shack in rural Uganda.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:35.958
This doesn't have house numbers. This has phone numbers.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:41.958
So what does it mean when people's identity is mobile?

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
When those extra three billion people's identity is mobile, it isn't fixed?

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Your notion of identity is out-of-date already, OK,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
for those extra three billion people.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
This is how it's shifting.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:13:00.958
And then I go to this picture here, which is the one that I started with.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
And this is from Delhi.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
It's from a study we did into illiteracy,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
and it's a guy in a teashop.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
You can see the chai being poured in the background.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:14.958
And he's a, you know, incredibly poor teashop worker,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
on the lowest rungs in the society.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:20.958
And he, somehow, has the appreciation

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
of the values of Livestrong.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
And it's not necessarily the same values,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
but some kind of values of Livestrong,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
to actually go out and purchase them,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
and actually display them.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
For me, this kind of personifies this connected world,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958
where everything is intertwined, and the dots are --

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
it's all about the dots joining together.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
OK, the title of this presentation is "Connections and Consequences,"

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:49.958
and it's really a kind of summary of five years of trying to figure out

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
what it's going to be like when everyone on the planet

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
has the ability to transcend space and time

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
in a personal and convenient manner, right?

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
When everyone's connected.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
And there are four things.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
So, the first thing is the immediacy of ideas,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
the speed at which ideas go around.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
And I know TED is about big ideas,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:16.958
but actually, the benchmark for a big idea is changing.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
If you want a big idea, you need to embrace everyone on the planet,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
that's the first thing.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
The second thing is the immediacy of objects.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:29.958
And what I mean by that is, as these become smaller,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:33.958
as the functionality that you can access through this becomes greater --

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
things like banking, identity --

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:40.958
these things quite simply move very quickly around the world.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
And so the speed of the adoption of things

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
is just going to become that much more rapid,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
in a way that we just totally cannot conceive,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
when you get it to 6.3 billion

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
and the growth in the world's population.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.958
The next thing is that, however we design this stuff --

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:57.958
carefully design this stuff --

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
the street will take it, and will figure out ways to innovate,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
as long as it meets base needs --

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
the ability to transcend space and time, for example.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:10.958
And it will innovate in ways that we cannot anticipate.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
In ways that, despite our resources, they can do it better than us.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
That's my feeling.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
And if we're smart, we'll look at this stuff that's going on,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:25.958
and we'll figure out a way to enable it to inform and infuse

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
both what we design and how we design.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:35.958
And the last thing is that -- actually, the direction of the conversation.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:40.958
With another three billion people connected,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
they want to be part of the conversation.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:47.958
And I think our relevance and TED's relevance

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:53.958
is really about embracing that and learning how to listen, essentially.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:54.958
And we need to learn how to listen.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
So thank you very, very much.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:57.958
(Applause)

title: 3 clues to understanding your brain
transcript: Well, as Chris pointed out, I study the human brain, the functions and structure of the human brain. And I just want you to think for a minute about what this entails. Here is this mass of jelly, three-pound mass of jelly you can hold in the palm of your hand, and it can contemplate the vastness of interstellar space. It can contemplate the meaning of infinity and it can contemplate itself contemplating on the meaning of infinity. And this peculiar recursive quality that we call self-awareness, which I think is the holy grail of neuroscience, of neurology, and hopefully, someday, we'll understand how that happens.OK, so how do you study this mysterious organ? I mean, you have 100 billion nerve cells, little wisps of protoplasm, interacting with each other, and from this activity emerges the whole spectrum of abilities that we call human nature and human consciousness. How does this happen? Well, there are many ways of approaching the functions of the human brain. One approach, the one we use mainly, is to look at patients with sustained damage to a small region of the brain, where there's been a genetic change in a small region of the brain. What then happens is not an across-the-board reduction in all your mental capacities, a sort of blunting of your cognitive ability. What you get is a highly selective loss of one function, with other functions being preserved intact, and this gives you some confidence in asserting that that part of the brain is somehow involved in mediating that function. So you can then map function onto structure, and then find out what the circuitry's doing to generate that particular function. So that's what we're trying to do.So let me give you a few striking examples of this. In fact, I'm giving you three examples, six minutes each, during this talk. The first example is an extraordinary syndrome called Capgras syndrome. If you look at the first slide there, that's the temporal lobes, frontal lobes, parietal lobes, OK — the lobes that constitute the brain. And if you look, tucked away inside the inner surface of the temporal lobes — you can't see it there — is a little structure called the fusiform gyrus. And that's been called the face area in the brain, because when it's damaged, you can no longer recognize people's faces. You can still recognize them from their voice and say, "Oh yeah, that's Joe," but you can't look at their face and know who it is, right? You can't even recognize yourself in the mirror. I mean, you know it's you because you wink and it winks, and you know it's a mirror, but you don't really recognize yourself as yourself.OK. Now that syndrome is well known as caused by damage to the fusiform gyrus. But there's another rare syndrome, so rare, in fact, that very few physicians have heard about it, not even neurologists. This is called the Capgras delusion, and that is a patient, who's otherwise completely normal, has had a head injury, comes out of coma, otherwise completely normal, he looks at his mother and says, "This looks exactly like my mother, this woman, but she's an impostor. She's some other woman pretending to be my mother." Now, why does this happen? Why would somebody — and this person is perfectly lucid and intelligent in all other respects, but when he sees his mother, his delusion kicks in and says, it's not mother.Now, the most common interpretation of this, which you find in all the psychiatry textbooks, is a Freudian view, and that is that this chap — and the same argument applies to women, by the way, but I'll just talk about guys. When you're a little baby, a young baby, you had a strong sexual attraction to your mother. This is the so-called Oedipus complex of Freud. I'm not saying I believe this, but this is the standard Freudian view. And then, as you grow up, the cortex develops, and inhibits these latent sexual urges towards your mother. Thank God, or you would all be sexually aroused when you saw your mother. And then what happens is, there's a blow to your head, damaging the cortex, allowing these latent sexual urges to emerge, flaming to the surface, and suddenly and inexplicably you find yourself being sexually aroused by your mother. And you say, "My God, if this is my mom, how come I'm being sexually turned on? She's some other woman. She's an impostor." It's the only interpretation that makes sense to your damaged brain.This has never made much sense to me, this argument. It's very ingenious, as all Freudian arguments are — (Laughter) — but didn't make much sense because I have seen the same delusion, a patient having the same delusion, about his pet poodle. (Laughter) He'll say, "Doctor, this is not Fifi. It looks exactly like Fifi, but it's some other dog." Right? Now, you try using the Freudian explanation there. (Laughter) You'll start talking about the latent bestiality in all humans, or some such thing, which is quite absurd, of course.Now, what's really going on? So, to explain this curious disorder, we look at the structure and functions of the normal visual pathways in the brain. Normally, visual signals come in, into the eyeballs, go to the visual areas in the brain. There are, in fact, 30 areas in the back of your brain concerned with just vision, and after processing all that, the message goes to a small structure called the fusiform gyrus, where you perceive faces. There are neurons there that are sensitive to faces. You can call it the face area of the brain, right? I talked about that earlier. Now, when that area's damaged, you lose the ability to see faces, right?But from that area, the message cascades into a structure called the amygdala in the limbic system, the emotional core of the brain, and that structure, called the amygdala, gauges the emotional significance of what you're looking at. Is it prey? Is it predator? Is it mate? Or is it something absolutely trivial, like a piece of lint, or a piece of chalk, or a — I don't want to point to that, but — or a shoe, or something like that? OK? Which you can completely ignore. So if the amygdala is excited, and this is something important, the messages then cascade into the autonomic nervous system. Your heart starts beating faster. You start sweating to dissipate the heat that you're going to create from muscular exertion. And that's fortunate, because we can put two electrodes on your palm and measure the change in skin resistance produced by sweating. So I can determine, when you're looking at something, whether you're excited or whether you're aroused, or not, OK? And I'll get to that in a minute.So my idea was, when this chap looks at an object, when he looks at his — any object for that matter, it goes to the visual areas and, however, and it's processed in the fusiform gyrus, and you recognize it as a pea plant, or a table, or your mother, for that matter, OK? And then the message cascades into the amygdala, and then goes down the autonomic nervous system. But maybe, in this chap, that wire that goes from the amygdala to the limbic system, the emotional core of the brain, is cut by the accident. So because the fusiform is intact, the chap can still recognize his mother, and says, "Oh yeah, this looks like my mother." But because the wire is cut to the emotional centers, he says, "But how come, if it's my mother, I don't experience a warmth?" Or terror, as the case may be? Right? (Laughter) And therefore, he says, "How do I account for this inexplicable lack of emotions? This can't be my mother. It's some strange woman pretending to be my mother."How do you test this? Well, what you do is, if you take any one of you here, and put you in front of a screen, and measure your galvanic skin response, and show pictures on the screen, I can measure how you sweat when you see an object, like a table or an umbrella. Of course, you don't sweat. If I show you a picture of a lion, or a tiger, or a pinup, you start sweating, right? And, believe it or not, if I show you a picture of your mother — I'm talking about normal people — you start sweating. You don't even have to be Jewish. (Laughter)Now, what happens if you show this patient? You take the patient and show him pictures on the screen and measure his galvanic skin response. Tables and chairs and lint, nothing happens, as in normal people, but when you show him a picture of his mother, the galvanic skin response is flat. There's no emotional reaction to his mother, because that wire going from the visual areas to the emotional centers is cut. So his vision is normal because the visual areas are normal, his emotions are normal — he'll laugh, he'll cry, so on and so forth — but the wire from vision to emotions is cut and therefore he has this delusion that his mother is an impostor. It's a lovely example of the sort of thing we do: take a bizarre, seemingly incomprehensible, neural psychiatric syndrome and say that the standard Freudian view is wrong, that, in fact, you can come up with a precise explanation in terms of the known neural anatomy of the brain.By the way, if this patient then goes, and mother phones from an adjacent room — phones him — and he picks up the phone, and he says, "Wow, mom, how are you? Where are you?" There's no delusion through the phone. Then, she approaches him after an hour, he says, "Who are you? You look just like my mother." OK? The reason is there's a separate pathway going from the hearing centers in the brain to the emotional centers, and that's not been cut by the accident. So this explains why through the phone he recognizes his mother, no problem. When he sees her in person, he says it's an impostor.OK, how is all this complex circuitry set up in the brain? Is it nature, genes, or is it nurture? And we approach this problem by considering another curious syndrome called phantom limb. And you all know what a phantom limb is. When an arm is amputated, or a leg is amputated, for gangrene, or you lose it in war — for example, in the Iraq war, it's now a serious problem — you continue to vividly feel the presence of that missing arm, and that's called a phantom arm or a phantom leg. In fact, you can get a phantom with almost any part of the body. Believe it or not, even with internal viscera. I've had patients with the uterus removed — hysterectomy — who have a phantom uterus, including phantom menstrual cramps at the appropriate time of the month. And in fact, one student asked me the other day, "Do they get phantom PMS?" (Laughter) A subject ripe for scientific enquiry, but we haven't pursued that.OK, now the next question is, what can you learn about phantom limbs by doing experiments? One of the things we've found was, about half the patients with phantom limbs claim that they can move the phantom. It'll pat his brother on the shoulder, it'll answer the phone when it rings, it'll wave goodbye. These are very compelling, vivid sensations. The patient's not delusional. He knows that the arm is not there, but, nevertheless, it's a compelling sensory experience for the patient. But however, about half the patients, this doesn't happen. The phantom limb — they'll say, "But doctor, the phantom limb is paralyzed. It's fixed in a clenched spasm and it's excruciatingly painful. If only I could move it, maybe the pain will be relieved."Now, why would a phantom limb be paralyzed? It sounds like an oxymoron. But when we were looking at the case sheets, what we found was, these people with the paralyzed phantom limbs, the original arm was paralyzed because of the peripheral nerve injury. The actual nerve supplying the arm was severed, was cut, by say, a motorcycle accident. So the patient had an actual arm, which is painful, in a sling for a few months or a year, and then, in a misguided attempt to get rid of the pain in the arm, the surgeon amputates the arm, and then you get a phantom arm with the same pains, right? And this is a serious clinical problem. Patients become depressed. Some of them are driven to suicide, OK?So, how do you treat this syndrome? Now, why do you get a paralyzed phantom limb? When I looked at the case sheet, I found that they had an actual arm, and the nerves supplying the arm had been cut, and the actual arm had been paralyzed, and lying in a sling for several months before the amputation, and this pain then gets carried over into the phantom itself.Why does this happen? When the arm was intact, but paralyzed, the brain sends commands to the arm, the front of the brain, saying, "Move," but it's getting visual feedback saying, "No." Move. No. Move. No. Move. No. And this gets wired into the circuitry of the brain, and we call this learned paralysis, OK? The brain learns, because of this Hebbian, associative link, that the mere command to move the arm creates a sensation of a paralyzed arm. And then, when you've amputated the arm, this learned paralysis carries over into your body image and into your phantom, OK?Now, how do you help these patients? How do you unlearn the learned paralysis, so you can relieve him of this excruciating, clenching spasm of the phantom arm? Well, we said, what if you now send the command to the phantom, but give him visual feedback that it's obeying his command, right? Maybe you can relieve the phantom pain, the phantom cramp. How do you do that? Well, virtual reality. But that costs millions of dollars. So, I hit on a way of doing this for three dollars, but don't tell my funding agencies. (Laughter)OK? What you do is you create what I call a mirror box. You have a cardboard box with a mirror in the middle, and then you put the phantom — so my first patient, Derek, came in. He had his arm amputated 10 years ago. He had a brachial avulsion, so the nerves were cut and the arm was paralyzed, lying in a sling for a year, and then the arm was amputated. He had a phantom arm, excruciatingly painful, and he couldn't move it. It was a paralyzed phantom arm.So he came there, and I gave him a mirror like that, in a box, which I call a mirror box, right? And the patient puts his phantom left arm, which is clenched and in spasm, on the left side of the mirror, and the normal hand on the right side of the mirror, and makes the same posture, the clenched posture, and looks inside the mirror. And what does he experience? He looks at the phantom being resurrected, because he's looking at the reflection of the normal arm in the mirror, and it looks like this phantom has been resurrected. "Now," I said, "now, look, wiggle your phantom — your real fingers, or move your real fingers while looking in the mirror." He's going to get the visual impression that the phantom is moving, right? That's obvious, but the astonishing thing is, the patient then says, "Oh my God, my phantom is moving again, and the pain, the clenching spasm, is relieved."And remember, my first patient who came in — (Applause) — thank you. (Applause) My first patient came in, and he looked in the mirror, and I said, "Look at your reflection of your phantom." And he started giggling, he says, "I can see my phantom." But he's not stupid. He knows it's not real. He knows it's a mirror reflection, but it's a vivid sensory experience. Now, I said, "Move your normal hand and phantom." He said, "Oh, I can't move my phantom. You know that. It's painful." I said, "Move your normal hand." And he says, "Oh my God, my phantom is moving again. I don't believe this! And my pain is being relieved." OK? And then I said, "Close your eyes." He closes his eyes. "And move your normal hand." "Oh, nothing. It's clenched again." "OK, open your eyes." "Oh my God, oh my God, it's moving again!" So, he was like a kid in a candy store.So, I said, OK, this proves my theory about learned paralysis and the critical role of visual input, but I'm not going to get a Nobel Prize for getting somebody to move his phantom limb. (Laughter) (Applause) It's a completely useless ability, if you think about it. (Laughter) But then I started realizing, maybe other kinds of paralysis that you see in neurology, like stroke, focal dystonias — there may be a learned component to this, which you can overcome with the simple device of using a mirror.So, I said, "Look, Derek" — well, first of all, the guy can't just go around carrying a mirror to alleviate his pain — I said, "Look, Derek, take it home and practice with it for a week or two. Maybe, after a period of practice, you can dispense with the mirror, unlearn the paralysis, and start moving your paralyzed arm, and then, relieve yourself of pain." So he said OK, and he took it home. I said, "Look, it's, after all, two dollars. Take it home."So, he took it home, and after two weeks, he phones me, and he said, "Doctor, you're not going to believe this." I said, "What?" He said, "It's gone." I said, "What's gone?" I thought maybe the mirror box was gone. (Laughter) He said, "No, no, no, you know this phantom I've had for the last 10 years? It's disappeared." And I said — I got worried, I said, my God, I mean I've changed this guy's body image, what about human subjects, ethics and all of that? And I said, "Derek, does this bother you?" He said, "No, last three days, I've not had a phantom arm and therefore no phantom elbow pain, no clenching, no phantom forearm pain, all those pains are gone away. But the problem is I still have my phantom fingers dangling from the shoulder, and your box doesn't reach." (Laughter) "So, can you change the design and put it on my forehead, so I can, you know, do this and eliminate my phantom fingers?" He thought I was some kind of magician.Now, why does this happen? It's because the brain is faced with tremendous sensory conflict. It's getting messages from vision saying the phantom is back. On the other hand, there's no proprioception, muscle signals saying that there is no arm, right? And your motor command saying there is an arm, and, because of this conflict, the brain says, to hell with it, there is no phantom, there is no arm, right? It goes into a sort of denial — it gates the signals. And when the arm disappears, the bonus is, the pain disappears because you can't have disembodied pain floating out there, in space. So, that's the bonus.Now, this technique has been tried on dozens of patients by other groups in Helsinki, so it may prove to be valuable as a treatment for phantom pain, and indeed, people have tried it for stroke rehabilitation. Stroke you normally think of as damage to the fibers, nothing you can do about it. But, it turns out some component of stroke paralysis is also learned paralysis, and maybe that component can be overcome using mirrors. This has also gone through clinical trials, helping lots and lots of patients.OK, let me switch gears now to the third part of my talk, which is about another curious phenomenon called synesthesia. This was discovered by Francis Galton in the nineteenth century. He was a cousin of Charles Darwin. He pointed out that certain people in the population, who are otherwise completely normal, had the following peculiarity: every time they see a number, it's colored. Five is blue, seven is yellow, eight is chartreuse, nine is indigo, OK? Bear in mind, these people are completely normal in other respects. Or C sharp — sometimes, tones evoke color. C sharp is blue, F sharp is green, another tone might be yellow, right?Why does this happen? This is called synesthesia. Galton called it synesthesia, a mingling of the senses. In us, all the senses are distinct. These people muddle up their senses. Why does this happen? One of the two aspects of this problem are very intriguing. Synesthesia runs in families, so Galton said this is a hereditary basis, a genetic basis. Secondly, synesthesia is about — and this is what gets me to my point about the main theme of this lecture, which is about creativity — synesthesia is eight times more common among artists, poets, novelists and other creative people than in the general population. Why would that be? I'm going to answer that question. It's never been answered before.OK, what is synesthesia? What causes it? Well, there are many theories. One theory is they're just crazy. Now, that's not really a scientific theory, so we can forget about it. Another theory is they are acid junkies and potheads, right? Now, there may be some truth to this, because it's much more common here in the Bay Area than in San Diego. (Laughter) OK. Now, the third theory is that — well, let's ask ourselves what's really going on in synesthesia. All right?So, we found that the color area and the number area are right next to each other in the brain, in the fusiform gyrus. So we said, there's some accidental cross wiring between color and numbers in the brain. So, every time you see a number, you see a corresponding color, and that's why you get synesthesia. Now remember — why does this happen? Why would there be crossed wires in some people? Remember I said it runs in families? That gives you the clue. And that is, there is an abnormal gene, a mutation in the gene that causes this abnormal cross wiring.In all of us, it turns out we are born with everything wired to everything else. So, every brain region is wired to every other region, and these are trimmed down to create the characteristic modular architecture of the adult brain. So, if there's a gene causing this trimming and if that gene mutates, then you get deficient trimming between adjacent brain areas. And if it's between number and color, you get number-color synesthesia. If it's between tone and color, you get tone-color synesthesia. So far, so good.Now, what if this gene is expressed everywhere in the brain, so everything is cross-connected? Well, think about what artists, novelists and poets have in common, the ability to engage in metaphorical thinking, linking seemingly unrelated ideas, such as, "It is the east, and Juliet is the Sun." Well, you don't say, Juliet is the sun, does that mean she's a glowing ball of fire? I mean, schizophrenics do that, but it's a different story, right? Normal people say, she's warm like the sun, she's radiant like the sun, she's nurturing like the sun. Instantly, you've found the links.Now, if you assume that this greater cross wiring and concepts are also in different parts of the brain, then it's going to create a greater propensity towards metaphorical thinking and creativity in people with synesthesia. And, hence, the eight times more common incidence of synesthesia among poets, artists and novelists. OK, it's a very phrenological view of synesthesia. The last demonstration — can I take one minute? (Applause)OK. I'm going to show you that you're all synesthetes, but you're in denial about it. Here's what I call Martian alphabet. Just like your alphabet, A is A, B is B, C is C. Different shapes for different phonemes, right? Here, you've got Martian alphabet. One of them is Kiki, one of them is Bouba. Which one is Kiki and which one is Bouba? How many of you think that's Kiki and that's Bouba? Raise your hands. Well, it's one or two mutants. (Laughter) How many of you think that's Bouba, that's Kiki? Raise your hands. Ninety-nine percent of you.Now, none of you is a Martian. How did you do that? It's because you're all doing a cross-model synesthetic abstraction, meaning you're saying that that sharp inflection — ki-ki, in your auditory cortex, the hair cells being excited — Kiki, mimics the visual inflection, sudden inflection of that jagged shape. Now, this is very important, because what it's telling you is your brain is engaging in a primitive — it's just — it looks like a silly illusion, but these photons in your eye are doing this shape, and hair cells in your ear are exciting the auditory pattern, but the brain is able to extract the common denominator. It's a primitive form of abstraction, and we now know this happens in the fusiform gyrus of the brain, because when that's damaged, these people lose the ability to engage in Bouba Kiki, but they also lose the ability to engage in metaphor.If you ask this guy, what — "all that glitters is not gold," what does that mean?" The patient says, "Well, if it's metallic and shiny, it doesn't mean it's gold. You have to measure its specific gravity, OK?" So, they completely miss the metaphorical meaning. So, this area is about eight times the size in higher — especially in humans — as in lower primates. Something very interesting is going on here in the angular gyrus, because it's the crossroads between hearing, vision and touch, and it became enormous in humans. And something very interesting is going on. And I think it's a basis of many uniquely human abilities like abstraction, metaphor and creativity. All of these questions that philosophers have been studying for millennia, we scientists can begin to explore by doing brain imaging, and by studying patients and asking the right questions. Thank you. (Applause) Sorry about that. (Laughter)

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
Well, as Chris pointed out, I study the human brain,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:17.958
the functions and structure of the human brain.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:21.958
And I just want you to think for a minute about what this entails.

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:25.958
Here is this mass of jelly, three-pound mass of jelly

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
you can hold in the palm of your hand,

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:32.958
and it can contemplate the vastness of interstellar space.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
It can contemplate the meaning of infinity

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:39.958
and it can contemplate itself contemplating on the meaning of infinity.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:44.958
And this peculiar recursive quality that we call self-awareness,

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:48.958
which I think is the holy grail of neuroscience, of neurology,

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
and hopefully, someday, we'll understand how that happens.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
OK, so how do you study this mysterious organ?

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:58.958
I mean, you have 100 billion nerve cells,

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:01.958
little wisps of protoplasm, interacting with each other,

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:05.958
and from this activity emerges the whole spectrum of abilities

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
that we call human nature and human consciousness.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:09.958
How does this happen?

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
Well, there are many ways of approaching the functions of the human brain.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
One approach, the one we use mainly,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:20.958
is to look at patients with sustained damage to a small region of the brain,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
where there's been a genetic change in a small region of the brain.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:26.958
What then happens is not an across-the-board reduction

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
in all your mental capacities,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
a sort of blunting of your cognitive ability.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
What you get is a highly selective loss of one function,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
with other functions being preserved intact,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
and this gives you some confidence in asserting

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:42.958
that that part of the brain is somehow involved in mediating that function.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
So you can then map function onto structure,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
and then find out what the circuitry's doing

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
to generate that particular function.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
So that's what we're trying to do.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
So let me give you a few striking examples of this.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:58.958
In fact, I'm giving you three examples, six minutes each, during this talk.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:02.958
The first example is an extraordinary syndrome called Capgras syndrome.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
If you look at the first slide there,

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:09.958
that's the temporal lobes, frontal lobes, parietal lobes, OK --

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
the lobes that constitute the brain.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:15.958
And if you look, tucked away inside the inner surface of the temporal lobes --

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
you can't see it there --

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
is a little structure called the fusiform gyrus.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
And that's been called the face area in the brain,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
because when it's damaged, you can no longer recognize people's faces.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
You can still recognize them from their voice

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
and say, "Oh yeah, that's Joe,"

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
but you can't look at their face and know who it is, right?

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
You can't even recognize yourself in the mirror.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
I mean, you know it's you because you wink and it winks,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
and you know it's a mirror,

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
but you don't really recognize yourself as yourself.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:46.958
OK. Now that syndrome is well known as caused by damage to the fusiform gyrus.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
But there's another rare syndrome, so rare, in fact,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
that very few physicians have heard about it, not even neurologists.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
This is called the Capgras delusion,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
and that is a patient, who's otherwise completely normal,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
has had a head injury, comes out of coma,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
otherwise completely normal, he looks at his mother

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
and says, "This looks exactly like my mother, this woman,

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
but she's an impostor.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
She's some other woman pretending to be my mother."

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
Now, why does this happen?

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
Why would somebody -- and this person is perfectly lucid and intelligent

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
in all other respects, but when he sees his mother,

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
his delusion kicks in and says, it's not mother.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
Now, the most common interpretation of this,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
which you find in all the psychiatry textbooks,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.958
is a Freudian view, and that is that this chap --

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
and the same argument applies to women, by the way,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
but I'll just talk about guys.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
When you're a little baby, a young baby,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
you had a strong sexual attraction to your mother.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
This is the so-called Oedipus complex of Freud.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
I'm not saying I believe this,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
but this is the standard Freudian view.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
And then, as you grow up, the cortex develops,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
and inhibits these latent sexual urges towards your mother.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:55.958
Thank God, or you would all be sexually aroused when you saw your mother.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
And then what happens is,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
there's a blow to your head, damaging the cortex,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:03.958
allowing these latent sexual urges to emerge,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
flaming to the surface, and suddenly and inexplicably

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
you find yourself being sexually aroused by your mother.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
And you say, "My God, if this is my mom,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
how come I'm being sexually turned on?

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
She's some other woman. She's an impostor."

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:19.958
It's the only interpretation that makes sense to your damaged brain.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
This has never made much sense to me, this argument.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
It's very ingenious, as all Freudian arguments are --

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
(Laughter)

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:32.958
-- but didn't make much sense because I have seen the same delusion,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
a patient having the same delusion, about his pet poodle.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:35.958
(Laughter)

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:40.958
He'll say, "Doctor, this is not Fifi. It looks exactly like Fifi,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
but it's some other dog." Right?

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
Now, you try using the Freudian explanation there.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:45.958
(Laughter)

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:49.958
You'll start talking about the latent bestiality in all humans,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
or some such thing, which is quite absurd, of course.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
Now, what's really going on?

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
So, to explain this curious disorder,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:05:00.958
we look at the structure and functions of the normal visual pathways in the brain.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
Normally, visual signals come in, into the eyeballs,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
go to the visual areas in the brain.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
There are, in fact, 30 areas in the back of your brain concerned with just vision,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
and after processing all that, the message goes to a small structure

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:16.958
called the fusiform gyrus, where you perceive faces.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
There are neurons there that are sensitive to faces.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
You can call it the face area of the brain, right?

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
I talked about that earlier.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:27.958
Now, when that area's damaged, you lose the ability to see faces, right?

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
But from that area, the message cascades

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
into a structure called the amygdala in the limbic system,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
the emotional core of the brain,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and that structure, called the amygdala,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
gauges the emotional significance of what you're looking at.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:43.958
Is it prey? Is it predator? Is it mate?

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
Or is it something absolutely trivial, like a piece of lint,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:49.958
or a piece of chalk, or a -- I don't want to point to that, but --

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
or a shoe, or something like that? OK?

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
Which you can completely ignore.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
So if the amygdala is excited, and this is something important,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
the messages then cascade into the autonomic nervous system.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
Your heart starts beating faster.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
You start sweating to dissipate the heat that you're going to

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
create from muscular exertion.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:10.958
And that's fortunate, because we can put two electrodes on your palm

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and measure the change in skin resistance produced by sweating.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
So I can determine, when you're looking at something,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
whether you're excited or whether you're aroused, or not, OK?

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
And I'll get to that in a minute.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.958
So my idea was, when this chap looks at an object, when he looks at his --

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:30.958
any object for that matter, it goes to the visual areas and,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
however, and it's processed in the fusiform gyrus,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
and you recognize it as a pea plant, or a table,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
or your mother, for that matter, OK?

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
And then the message cascades into the amygdala,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
and then goes down the autonomic nervous system.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:48.958
But maybe, in this chap, that wire that goes from the amygdala to the limbic system,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
the emotional core of the brain, is cut by the accident.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
So because the fusiform is intact,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
the chap can still recognize his mother,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
and says, "Oh yeah, this looks like my mother."

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
But because the wire is cut to the emotional centers,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
he says, "But how come, if it's my mother, I don't experience a warmth?"

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
Or terror, as the case may be? Right?

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:08.958
(Laughter)

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:14.958
And therefore, he says, "How do I account for this inexplicable lack of emotions?

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
This can't be my mother.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
It's some strange woman pretending to be my mother."

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
How do you test this?

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
Well, what you do is, if you take any one of you here, and put you in front of a screen,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and measure your galvanic skin response,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
and show pictures on the screen,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
I can measure how you sweat when you see an object,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
like a table or an umbrella. Of course, you don't sweat.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:38.958
If I show you a picture of a lion, or a tiger, or a pinup, you start sweating, right?

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And, believe it or not, if I show you a picture of your mother --

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
I'm talking about normal people -- you start sweating.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
You don't even have to be Jewish.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
(Laughter)

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.958
Now, what happens if you show this patient?

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:55.958
You take the patient and show him pictures on the screen

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
and measure his galvanic skin response.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:02.958
Tables and chairs and lint, nothing happens, as in normal people,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
but when you show him a picture of his mother,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
the galvanic skin response is flat.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
There's no emotional reaction to his mother,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:13.958
because that wire going from the visual areas to the emotional centers is cut.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
So his vision is normal because the visual areas are normal,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
his emotions are normal -- he'll laugh, he'll cry, so on and so forth --

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
but the wire from vision to emotions is cut

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
and therefore he has this delusion that his mother is an impostor.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
It's a lovely example of the sort of thing we do:

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
take a bizarre, seemingly incomprehensible, neural psychiatric syndrome

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
and say that the standard Freudian view is wrong,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:38.958
that, in fact, you can come up with a precise explanation

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
in terms of the known neural anatomy of the brain.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
By the way, if this patient then goes,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:47.958
and mother phones from an adjacent room -- phones him --

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
and he picks up the phone, and he says, "Wow, mom, how are you? Where are you?"

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
There's no delusion through the phone.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
Then, she approaches him after an hour, he says, "Who are you?

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
You look just like my mother." OK?

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
The reason is there's a separate pathway

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.958
going from the hearing centers in the brain to the emotional centers,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
and that's not been cut by the accident.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:10.958
So this explains why through the phone he recognizes his mother, no problem.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
When he sees her in person, he says it's an impostor.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.958
OK, how is all this complex circuitry set up in the brain?

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Is it nature, genes, or is it nurture?

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
And we approach this problem

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:26.958
by considering another curious syndrome called phantom limb.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
And you all know what a phantom limb is.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
When an arm is amputated, or a leg is amputated, for gangrene,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
or you lose it in war -- for example, in the Iraq war,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
it's now a serious problem --

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:39.958
you continue to vividly feel the presence of that missing arm,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
and that's called a phantom arm or a phantom leg.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
In fact, you can get a phantom with almost any part of the body.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
Believe it or not, even with internal viscera.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
I've had patients with the uterus removed -- hysterectomy --

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:56.958
who have a phantom uterus, including phantom menstrual cramps

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
at the appropriate time of the month.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
And in fact, one student asked me the other day,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
"Do they get phantom PMS?"

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:03.958
(Laughter)

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.958
A subject ripe for scientific enquiry, but we haven't pursued that.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
OK, now the next question is,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
what can you learn about phantom limbs by doing experiments?

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
One of the things we've found was,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
about half the patients with phantom limbs

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
claim that they can move the phantom.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
It'll pat his brother on the shoulder,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
it'll answer the phone when it rings, it'll wave goodbye.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
These are very compelling, vivid sensations.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
The patient's not delusional.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
He knows that the arm is not there,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
but, nevertheless, it's a compelling sensory experience for the patient.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
But however, about half the patients, this doesn't happen.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
The phantom limb -- they'll say, "But doctor, the phantom limb is paralyzed.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
It's fixed in a clenched spasm and it's excruciatingly painful.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
If only I could move it, maybe the pain will be relieved."

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
Now, why would a phantom limb be paralyzed?

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
It sounds like an oxymoron.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
But when we were looking at the case sheets, what we found was,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
these people with the paralyzed phantom limbs,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
the original arm was paralyzed because of the peripheral nerve injury.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
The actual nerve supplying the arm was severed,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
was cut, by say, a motorcycle accident.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
So the patient had an actual arm, which is painful,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
in a sling for a few months or a year, and then,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
in a misguided attempt to get rid of the pain in the arm,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
the surgeon amputates the arm,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
and then you get a phantom arm with the same pains, right?

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
And this is a serious clinical problem.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
Patients become depressed.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
Some of them are driven to suicide, OK?

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
So, how do you treat this syndrome?

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
Now, why do you get a paralyzed phantom limb?

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.958
When I looked at the case sheet, I found that they had an actual arm,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
and the nerves supplying the arm had been cut,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
and the actual arm had been paralyzed,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958
and lying in a sling for several months before the amputation,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:51.958
and this pain then gets carried over into the phantom itself.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
Why does this happen?

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
When the arm was intact, but paralyzed,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
the brain sends commands to the arm, the front of the brain, saying, "Move,"

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
but it's getting visual feedback saying, "No."

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:04.958
Move. No. Move. No. Move. No.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
And this gets wired into the circuitry of the brain,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
and we call this learned paralysis, OK?

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
The brain learns, because of this Hebbian, associative link,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
that the mere command to move the arm

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
creates a sensation of a paralyzed arm.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
And then, when you've amputated the arm,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
this learned paralysis carries over into your body image

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
and into your phantom, OK?

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
Now, how do you help these patients?

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
How do you unlearn the learned paralysis,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:36.958
so you can relieve him of this excruciating, clenching spasm

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
of the phantom arm?

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:43.958
Well, we said, what if you now send the command to the phantom,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:47.958
but give him visual feedback that it's obeying his command, right?

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Maybe you can relieve the phantom pain, the phantom cramp.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
How do you do that? Well, virtual reality.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
But that costs millions of dollars.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
So, I hit on a way of doing this for three dollars,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
but don't tell my funding agencies.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:00.958
(Laughter)

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.958
OK? What you do is you create what I call a mirror box.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
You have a cardboard box with a mirror in the middle,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
and then you put the phantom -- so my first patient, Derek, came in.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
He had his arm amputated 10 years ago.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
He had a brachial avulsion, so the nerves were cut

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:20.958
and the arm was paralyzed, lying in a sling for a year, and then the arm was amputated.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
He had a phantom arm, excruciatingly painful, and he couldn't move it.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
It was a paralyzed phantom arm.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
So he came there, and I gave him a mirror like that, in a box,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
which I call a mirror box, right?

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
And the patient puts his phantom left arm,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
which is clenched and in spasm, on the left side of the mirror,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
and the normal hand on the right side of the mirror,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
and makes the same posture, the clenched posture,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
and looks inside the mirror. And what does he experience?

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
He looks at the phantom being resurrected,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
because he's looking at the reflection of the normal arm in the mirror,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
and it looks like this phantom has been resurrected.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
"Now," I said, "now, look, wiggle your phantom --

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
your real fingers, or move your real fingers while looking in the mirror."

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
He's going to get the visual impression that the phantom is moving, right?

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
That's obvious, but the astonishing thing is,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
the patient then says, "Oh my God, my phantom is moving again,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
and the pain, the clenching spasm, is relieved."

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
And remember, my first patient who came in --

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:16.958
(Applause)

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
-- thank you. (Applause)

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
My first patient came in, and he looked in the mirror,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
and I said, "Look at your reflection of your phantom."

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
And he started giggling, he says, "I can see my phantom."

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
But he's not stupid. He knows it's not real.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
He knows it's a mirror reflection,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
but it's a vivid sensory experience.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
Now, I said, "Move your normal hand and phantom."

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
He said, "Oh, I can't move my phantom. You know that. It's painful."

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
I said, "Move your normal hand."

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And he says, "Oh my God, my phantom is moving again. I don't believe this!

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
And my pain is being relieved." OK?

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:47.958
And then I said, "Close your eyes."

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
He closes his eyes.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:50.958
"And move your normal hand."

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:51.958
"Oh, nothing. It's clenched again."

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
"OK, open your eyes."

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:54.958
"Oh my God, oh my God, it's moving again!"

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
So, he was like a kid in a candy store.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:01.958
So, I said, OK, this proves my theory about learned paralysis

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
and the critical role of visual input,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
but I'm not going to get a Nobel Prize

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
for getting somebody to move his phantom limb.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:08.958
(Laughter)

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:09.958
(Applause)

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
It's a completely useless ability, if you think about it.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:13.958
(Laughter)

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
But then I started realizing, maybe other kinds of paralysis

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:22.958
that you see in neurology, like stroke, focal dystonias --

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
there may be a learned component to this,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
which you can overcome with the simple device of using a mirror.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
So, I said, "Look, Derek" --

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
well, first of all, the guy can't just go around carrying a mirror to alleviate his pain --

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
I said, "Look, Derek, take it home and practice with it for a week or two.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
Maybe, after a period of practice,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
you can dispense with the mirror, unlearn the paralysis,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
and start moving your paralyzed arm,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
and then, relieve yourself of pain."

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
So he said OK, and he took it home.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
I said, "Look, it's, after all, two dollars. Take it home."

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
So, he took it home, and after two weeks, he phones me,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
and he said, "Doctor, you're not going to believe this."

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:54.958
I said, "What?"

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
He said, "It's gone."

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:57.958
I said, "What's gone?"

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
I thought maybe the mirror box was gone.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:00.958
(Laughter)

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
He said, "No, no, no, you know this phantom I've had for the last 10 years?

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
It's disappeared."

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
And I said -- I got worried, I said, my God,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
I mean I've changed this guy's body image,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
what about human subjects, ethics and all of that?

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
And I said, "Derek, does this bother you?"

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
He said, "No, last three days, I've not had a phantom arm

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.958
and therefore no phantom elbow pain, no clenching,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
no phantom forearm pain, all those pains are gone away.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
But the problem is I still have my phantom fingers dangling from the shoulder,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
and your box doesn't reach."

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:30.958
(Laughter)

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
"So, can you change the design and put it on my forehead,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
so I can, you know, do this and eliminate my phantom fingers?"

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
He thought I was some kind of magician.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:39.958
Now, why does this happen?

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
It's because the brain is faced with tremendous sensory conflict.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
It's getting messages from vision saying the phantom is back.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
On the other hand, there's no proprioception,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
muscle signals saying that there is no arm, right?

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
And your motor command saying there is an arm,

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
and, because of this conflict, the brain says, to hell with it,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
there is no phantom, there is no arm, right?

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
It goes into a sort of denial -- it gates the signals.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:05.958
And when the arm disappears, the bonus is, the pain disappears

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:09.958
because you can't have disembodied pain floating out there, in space.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
So, that's the bonus.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
Now, this technique has been tried on dozens of patients

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
by other groups in Helsinki,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
so it may prove to be valuable as a treatment for phantom pain,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
and indeed, people have tried it for stroke rehabilitation.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
Stroke you normally think of as damage to the fibers,

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
nothing you can do about it.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:30.958
But, it turns out some component of stroke paralysis is also learned paralysis,

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
and maybe that component can be overcome using mirrors.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
This has also gone through clinical trials,

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
helping lots and lots of patients.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:41.958
OK, let me switch gears now to the third part of my talk,

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:45.958
which is about another curious phenomenon called synesthesia.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
This was discovered by Francis Galton in the nineteenth century.

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:50.958
He was a cousin of Charles Darwin.

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
He pointed out that certain people in the population,

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:56.958
who are otherwise completely normal, had the following peculiarity:

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:59.958
every time they see a number, it's colored.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:03.958
Five is blue, seven is yellow, eight is chartreuse,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
nine is indigo, OK?

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
Bear in mind, these people are completely normal in other respects.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
Or C sharp -- sometimes, tones evoke color.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.958
C sharp is blue, F sharp is green,

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
another tone might be yellow, right?

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
Why does this happen?

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:21.958
This is called synesthesia. Galton called it synesthesia,

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:23.958
a mingling of the senses.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:25.958
In us, all the senses are distinct.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:27.958
These people muddle up their senses.

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:28.958
Why does this happen?

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
One of the two aspects of this problem are very intriguing.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:32.958
Synesthesia runs in families,

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:35.958
so Galton said this is a hereditary basis, a genetic basis.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:39.958
Secondly, synesthesia is about -- and this is what gets me to my point

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:42.958
about the main theme of this lecture, which is about creativity --

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:47.958
synesthesia is eight times more common among artists, poets, novelists

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
and other creative people than in the general population.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:51.958
Why would that be?

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:53.958
I'm going to answer that question.

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:55.958
It's never been answered before.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:56.958
OK, what is synesthesia? What causes it?

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:57.958
Well, there are many theories.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
One theory is they're just crazy.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:02.958
Now, that's not really a scientific theory, so we can forget about it.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:06.958
Another theory is they are acid junkies and potheads, right?

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:08.958
Now, there may be some truth to this,

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:10.958
because it's much more common here in the Bay Area than in San Diego.

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:11.958
(Laughter)

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:14.958
OK. Now, the third theory is that --

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:19.958
well, let's ask ourselves what's really going on in synesthesia. All right?

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
So, we found that the color area and the number area

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:25.958
are right next to each other in the brain, in the fusiform gyrus.

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:27.958
So we said, there's some accidental cross wiring

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:30.958
between color and numbers in the brain.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:33.958
So, every time you see a number, you see a corresponding color,

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:35.958
and that's why you get synesthesia.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:37.958
