When medicine became somewhat scientific, in about 450 BC,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
with Hippocrates and those boys,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:15.958
they tried to look for herbs, plants

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
that would literally shake the bad spirits out.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
So, they found certain plants that could cause convulsions.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:27.958
And the herbals, the botanical books of up to the late Middle Ages,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:31.958
the Renaissance are filled with prescriptions

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:36.958
for causing convulsions to shake the evil spirits out.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:40.958
Finally, in about the sixteenth century,

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:46.958
a physician whose name was Theophrastus Bombastus Aureolus von Hohenheim,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:50.958
called Paracelsus, a name probably familiar to some people here --

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:55.958
(Laughter) -- good, old Paracelsus

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:59.958
found that he could predict the degree of convulsion

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:03.958
by using a measured amount of camphor to produce the convulsion.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
Can you imagine going to your closet, pulling out a mothball, and

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
chewing on it if you're feeling depressed?

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
It's better than Prozac, but I wouldn't recommend it.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
So what we see in the seventeenth, eighteenth century

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:20.958
is the continued search for medications other than camphor that'll do the trick.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
Well, along comes Benjamin Franklin,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
and he comes close to convulsing himself

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:28.958
with a bolt of electricity off the end of his kite.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:33.958
And so people begin thinking in terms of electricity to produce convulsions.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:37.958
And then, we fast-forward to about 1932,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:43.958
when three Italian psychiatrists, who were largely treating depression,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
began to notice among their patients, who were also epileptics,

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
that if they had an epileptic -- a series of epileptic fits,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
a lot of them in a row -- the depression would very frequently lift.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.958
Not only would it lift, but it might never return.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:02.958
So they got very interested in producing convulsions,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
measured types of convulsions.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
And they thought, "Well, we've got electricity, we'll plug somebody into the wall.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
That always makes hair stand up and people shake a lot."

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:14.958
So, they tried it on a few pigs, and none of the pigs were killed.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
So, they went to the police and they said,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
"We know that at the Rome railroad station,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
there are all these lost souls wandering around,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:25.958
muttering gibberish. Can you bring one of them to us?"

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
Someone who is, as the Italians say, "cagoots."

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
So they found this "cagoots" guy,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
a 39-year-old man who was really hopelessly schizophrenic,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
who was known, had been known for months,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:40.958
to be literally defecating on himself,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
talking nothing that made any sense,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
and they brought him into the hospital.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:48.958
So these three psychiatrists, after about two or three weeks of observation,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
laid him down on a table,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:55.958
connected his temples to a very small source of current.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:59.958
They thought, "Well, we'll try 55 volts, two-tenths of a second.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
That's not going to do anything terrible to him."

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:03.958
So they did that.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
Well, I have the following from a firsthand observer,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
who told me this about 35 years ago,

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
when I was thinking about these things

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
for some research project of mine.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:19.958
He said, "This fellow" -- remember, he wasn't even put to sleep --

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
"after this major grand mal convulsion,

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
sat right up, looked at these three fellas and said,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:28.958
'What the fuck are you assholes trying to do?' "

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:36.958
(Laughter)

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
If I could only say that in Italian.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
Well, they were happy as could be, because he

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:46.958
hadn't said a rational word in the weeks of observation.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:51.958
So they plugged him in again,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:55.958
and this time they used 110 volts for half a second.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
And to their amazement, after it was over,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
he began speaking like he was perfectly well.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
He relapsed a little bit, they gave him a series of treatments,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:05.958
and he was essentially cured.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
But of course, having schizophrenia,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
within a few months, it returned.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
But they wrote a paper about this,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:17.958
and everybody in the Western world began using electricity

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:21.958
to convulse people who were either schizophrenic or severely depressed.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
It didn't work very well on the schizophrenics,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
but it was pretty clear in the '30s and by the middle of the '40s

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:32.958
that electroconvulsive therapy was very, very effective

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
in the treatment of depression.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
And of course, in those days, there were no antidepressant drugs,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
and it became very, very popular.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
They would anesthetize people,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
convulse them, but the real difficulty was

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
that there was no way to paralyze muscles.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
So people would have a real grand mal seizure.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
Bones were broken. Especially in old, fragile people,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
you couldn't use it.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:06:00.958
And then in the 1950s, late 1950s, the so-called muscle relaxants

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
were developed by pharmacologists,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
and it got so that you could induce a complete convulsion,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
an electroencephalographic convulsion -- you could see it on the brain waves --

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:14.958
without causing any convulsion in the body except a little bit of twitching of the toes.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:20.958
So again, it was very, very popular and very, very useful.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Well, you know, in the middle '60s,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.958
the first antidepressants came out. Tofranil was the first.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:30.958
In the late '70s, early '80s, there were others,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:31.958
and they were very effective.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
And patients' rights groups seemed to get very upset

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
about the kinds of things that they would witness.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:43.958
And so the whole idea of electroconvulsive, electroshock therapy disappeared,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:47.958
but has had a renaissance in the last 10 years.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
And the reason that it has had a renaissance

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:56.958
is that probably about 10 percent of the people, severe depressives,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:01.958
do not respond, regardless of what is done for them.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
Now, why am I telling you this story at this meeting?

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
I'm telling you this story, because actually ever since

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
Richard called me and asked me to talk about

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
-- as he asked all of his speakers --

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
to talk about something that would be new to this audience,

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
that we had never talked about, never written about,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
I've been planning this moment.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:26.958
This reason really is that I am a man who, almost 30 years ago,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:34.958
had his life saved by two long courses of electroshock therapy.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
And let me tell you this story.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:44.958
I was, in the 1960s, in a marriage. To use the word bad

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
would be perhaps the understatement of the year.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
It was dreadful.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
There are, I'm sure, enough divorced people in this room

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:58.958
to know about the hostility, the anger, who knows what.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:03.958
Being someone who had had a very difficult childhood,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:04.958
a very difficult adolescence --

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:08.958
it had to do with not quite poverty but close.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
It had to do with being brought up in a family where no one spoke English,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
no one could read or write English.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
It had to do with death and disease and lots of other things.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
I was a little prone to depression.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.958
So, as things got worse, as we really began to hate each other,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.958
I became progressively depressed over a period of a couple of years,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
trying to save this marriage,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:33.958
which was inevitably not to be saved.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:39.958
Finally, I would schedule -- all my major surgical cases,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:43.958
I was scheduling them for 12, one o'clock in the afternoon,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:47.958
because I couldn't get out of bed before about 11 o'clock.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And anybody who's been depressed here knows what that's like.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
I couldn't even pull the covers off myself.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Well, you're in a university medical center,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
where everybody knows everybody, and it's perfectly clear to my colleagues,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
so my referrals began to decrease.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
As my referrals began to decrease,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.958
I clearly became increasingly depressed

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
until I thought, my God, I can't work anymore.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
And, in fact, it didn't make any difference

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
because I didn't have any patients anymore.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.958
So, with the advice of my physician,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:23.958
I had myself admitted to the acute care psychiatric unit of our university hospital.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
And my colleagues, who had known me since medical school

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
in that place, said, "Don't worry, chap. Six weeks,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:32.958
you're back in the operating room. Everything's going to be great."

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:36.958
Well, you know what bovine stercus is?

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:42.958
That proved to be a lot of bovine stercus.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:47.958
I know some people who got tenure in that place with lies like that.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:53.958
(Laughter)

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
So I was one of their failures.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
But it wasn't that simple. Because by the time

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:03.958
I got out of that unit, I was not functional at all.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
I could hardly see five feet in front of myself.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
I shuffled when I walked. I was bowed over.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:13.958
I rarely bathed. I sometimes didn't shave. It was dreadful.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
And it was clear -- not to me,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
because nothing was clear to me at that time anymore --

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:23.958
that I would need long-term hospitalization

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:27.958
in that awful place called a mental hospital.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:33.958
So I was admitted, in 1973, in the spring of 1973,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
to the Institute of Living, which used to be called the Hartford Retreat.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
It was founded in the eighteenth century,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
the largest psychiatric hospital in the state of

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
Connecticut, other than the huge public hospitals

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
that existed at that time.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And they tried everything they had.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
They tried the usual psychotherapy.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
They tried every medication available in those days.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:57.958
And they did have Tofranil and other things -- Mellaril, who knows what.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:01.958
Nothing happened except that I got jaundiced from one of these things.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:07.958
And finally, because I was well known in Connecticut,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
they decided they better have a meeting of the senior staff.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:17.958
All the senior staff got together, and I later found out what happened.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
They put all their heads together and they decided

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
that there was nothing that could be done

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:27.958
for this surgeon who had essentially separated himself from the world,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:31.958
who by that time had become so overwhelmed,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
not just with depression and feelings

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
of worthlessness and inadequacy,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
but with obsessional thinking,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
obsessional thinking about coincidences.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
And there were particular numbers that every time I saw them,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:50.958
just got me dreadfully upset -- all kinds of ritualistic observances,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
just awful, awful stuff.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Remember when you were a kid, and you had to step on every line?

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
Well, I was a grown man who had all of these rituals,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:03.958
and it got so there was a throbbing, there was a ferocious fear in my head.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
You've seen this painting by Edvard Munch,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:10.958
The Scream. Every moment was a scream.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
It was impossible. So they decided there was no therapy,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
there was no treatment. But there was one treatment,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:21.958
which actually had been pioneered at the Hartford hospital in the early 1940s,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:29.958
and you can imagine what it was. It was pre-frontal lobotomy.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
So they decided -- I didn't know this, again,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:32.958
I found this out later --

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
that the only thing that could be done was

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.958
for this 43-year-old man to have a pre-frontal

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
lobotomy.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
Well, as in all hospitals, there was a resident

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
assigned to my case. He was 27 years old,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
and he would meet with me two or three times a week.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:53.958
And of course, I had been there, what, three or four months at the time.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
And he asked to meet with the senior staff, and they agreed to meet with him

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
because he was very well thought of in that place.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
They thought he had a really extraordinary future.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:03.958
And he dug in his heels and said,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:07.958
"No. I know this man better than any of you. I have met with him over and over again.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:11.958
You've just seen him from time to time. You've read reports and so forth.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:16.958
I really honestly believe that the basic problem here is pure depression,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
and all of the obsessional thinking comes out of it.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
And you know, of course, what'll happen if you do a pre-frontal lobotomy.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Any of the results along the spectrum,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
from pretty bad to terrible, terrible, terrible

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
is going to happen. If he does the best he can,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
he will have no further obsessions,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
probably no depression, but his affect will be dulled,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
he will never go back to surgery,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:43.958
he will never be the loving father that he was to his two children,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
his life will be changed. If he has the usual result,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
he will end up like 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.'

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:54.958
And you know about that, just essentially in a stupor the rest of his life."

00:13:54.958 --> 00:14:00.958
Well, he said, "Can't we try a course of electroshock therapy?"

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
And you know why they agreed? They agreed to humor him.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
They just thought, "Well, we'll give a course of 10.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
And so we'll lose a little time. Big deal. It doesn't make any difference."

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:12.958
So they gave the course of 10,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
and the first -- the usual course, incidentally, was six to eight

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
and still is six to eight.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
Plugged me into the wires, put me to sleep, gave me the muscle relaxant.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
Six didn't work. Seven didn't work.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
Eight didn't work. At nine, I noticed --

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
and it's wonderful that I could notice anything

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
-- I noticed a change. And at 10, I noticed a real change.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
And he went back to them, and they agreed to do another 10.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
Again, not a single one of them

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
-- I think there are about seven or eight of them --

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
thought this would do any good. They thought this was a temporary change.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.958
But, lo and behold, by 16, by 17,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
there were demonstrable differences in the way I felt.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
By 18 and 19, I was sleeping through the night.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
And by 20, I had the sense, I really had the sense

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
that I could overcome this,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
that I was now strong enough that by an act of will,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
I could blow the obsessional thinking away.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
I could blow the depression away.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
And I've never forgotten -- I never will forget

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
-- standing in the kitchen of the unit,

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:19.958
it was a Sunday morning in January of 1974,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:25.958
standing in the kitchen by myself and thinking, "I've got the strength now to do this."

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:30.958
It was as though those tightly coiled wires in my head had been disconnected

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
and I could think clearly.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:37.958
But I need a formula. I need some thing to say to myself

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
when I begin thinking obsessionally, obsessively.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:46.958
Well, the Gilbert and Sullivan fans in this room

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
will remember "Ruddigore," and they will remember Mad Margaret,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
and they will remember that she was married

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
to a fellow named Sir Despard Murgatroyd.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:59.958
And she used to go nuts, every five minutes or so in the play,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
and he said to her, "We must have a word to bring you back to reality,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:06.958
and the word, my dear, will be 'Basingstoke.'"

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
So every time she got a little nuts,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
he would say, "Basingstoke!" And she would say,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:14.958
"Basingstoke, it is." And she would be fine for a little while.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:18.958
Well, you know, I'm from the Bronx. I can't say "Basingstoke."

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:22.958
But I had something better. And it was very simple.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
It was, "Ah, fuck it!"

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:30.958
(Laughter) Much better than "Basingstoke,"

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:34.958
at least for me. And it worked -- my God, it worked.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
Every time I would begin thinking obsessionally --

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:40.958
again, once more, after 20 shock treatments

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:44.958
-- I would say, "Ah, fuck it."

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
And things got better and better,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
and within three or four months,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
I was discharged from that hospital, and I joined a group of surgeons

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:56.958
where I could work with other people in the community,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
not in New Haven, but fairly close by.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
I stayed there for three years.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:05.958
At the end of three years, I went back to New Haven,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:09.958
had remarried by that time.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:15.958
I brought my wife with me, actually, to make sure I could get through this.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:21.958
My children came back to live with us.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
We had two more children after that.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:29.958
Resuscitated the career, even better than it had been before.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:33.958
Went right back into the university

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
and began to write books.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
Well, you know, it's been a wonderful life.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:43.958
It's been, as I said, close to 30 years.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
I stopped doing surgery about six years ago

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:50.958
and became a full-time writer, as many people know.

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958
But it's been very exciting. It's been very happy.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
Every once in a while, I have to say, "Ah, fuck it."

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
Every once in a while, I get somewhat depressed and a little obsessional.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:08.958
So, I'm not free of all of this. But it's worked. It's always worked.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:16.958
Why have I chosen, after never, ever talking about this, to talk about it now?

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:19.958
Well, those of you who know some of these books

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:22.958
know that one is about death and dying,

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
one is about the human body and the human spirit,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:29.958
one is about the way mystical thoughts are constantly in our minds,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:34.958
and they have always to do with my own personal experiences.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
One might think reading these books

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
-- and I've gotten thousands of letters about them

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.958
by people who do think this --

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:45.958
that based on my life's history as I've portrayed in the books,

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:50.958
my early life's history, I am someone who has overcome adversity.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:55.958
That I am someone who has drunk, drank, drunk

00:18:55.958 --> 00:19:02.958
of the bitter dregs of near-disaster in childhood

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:07.958
and emerged not just unscathed but strengthened.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:10.958
I really have it figured out, so that I can advise people about

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:15.958
death and dying, so that I can talk about mysticism and the human spirit.

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:17.958
And I've always felt guilty about that.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:20.958
I've always felt that somehow I was an impostor

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:25.958
because my readers don't know what I have just told you.

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
It's known by some people in New Haven, obviously,

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
but it is not generally known.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:35.958
So one of the reasons that I have come here to talk about this today

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:40.958
is to -- frankly, selfishly --

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:43.958
unburden myself and let it be known

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:49.958
that this is not an untroubled mind that has written all of these books.

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:52.958
But more importantly, I think,

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:54.958
is the fact that a very significant proportion

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:58.958
of people in this audience are under 30,

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:04.958
and there are many, of course, who are well over 30.

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:07.958
For people under 30, and it looks to me like almost all of you

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:08.958
-- I would say all of you --

00:20:08.958 --> 00:20:13.958
are either on the cusp of a magnificent and exciting career

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:17.958
or right into a magnificent and exciting career:

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:21.958
anything can happen to you. Things change.

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:25.958
Accidents happen. Something from childhood comes back to haunt you.

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:27.958
You can be thrown off the track.

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:28.958
I hope it happens to none of you,

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:33.958
but it will probably happen to a small percentage of you.

00:20:33.958 --> 00:20:38.958
To those to whom it doesn't happen, there will be adversities.

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:42.958
If I, with the bleakness of spirit,

00:20:42.958 --> 00:20:47.958
with no spirit, that I had in the 1970s

00:20:47.958 --> 00:20:49.958
and no possibility of recovery,

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:53.958
as far as that group of very experienced psychiatrists thought,

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:55.958
if I can find my way back from this,

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:59.958
believe me, anybody can find their way back

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:04.958
from any adversity that exists in their lives.

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:05.958
And for those who are older, who have lived through

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:08.958
perhaps not something as bad as this,

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:11.958
but who have lived through difficult times,

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:13.958
perhaps where they lost everything, as I did,

00:21:13.958 --> 00:21:20.958
and started out all over again, some of these things will seem very familiar.

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:25.958
There is recovery.

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:33.958
There is redemption. And there is resurrection.

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:37.958
There are resurrection themes in every society that has ever been studied,

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:40.958
and it is because not just only do we fantasize

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:43.958
about the possibility of resurrection and recovery,

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:47.958
but it actually happens. And it happens a lot.

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:51.958
Perhaps the most popular resurrection theme,

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:54.958
outside of specifically religious ones,

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:58.958
is the one about the phoenix, the ancient story of the phoenix,

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:05.958
who, every 500 years, resurrects itself from its own ashes

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:08.958
to go on to live a life that is

00:22:08.958 --> 00:22:11.958
even more beautiful than it was before. Richard,

00:22:11.958 --> 00:22:12.958
thanks very much.

title: The habits of happiness
transcript: So, I guess it is a result of globalization that you can find Coca-Cola tins on top of Everest and a Buddhist monk in Monterey.(Laughter)And so I just came, two days ago, from the Himalayas to your kind invitation. So I would like to invite you, also, for a while, to the Himalayas themselves. And to show the place where meditators, like me, who began with being a molecular biologist in Pasteur Institute, and found their way to the mountains.So these are a few images I was lucky to take and be there. There's Mount Kailash in Eastern Tibet — wonderful setting. This is from Marlboro country.(Laughter)This is a turquoise lake. A meditator. This is the hottest day of the year somewhere in Eastern Tibet, on August 1. And the night before, we camped, and my Tibetan friends said, "We are going to sleep outside." And I said, "Why? We have enough space in the tent." They said, "Yes, but it's summertime."(Laughter)So now, we are going to speak of happiness. As a Frenchman, I must say that there are a lot of French intellectuals that think happiness is not at all interesting.(Laughter)I just wrote an essay on happiness, and there was a controversy. And someone wrote an article saying, "Don't impose on us the dirty work of happiness."(Laughter)"We don't care about being happy. We need to live with passion. We like the ups and downs of life. We like our suffering because it's so good when it ceases for a while."(Laughter)This is what I see from the balcony of my hermitage in the Himalayas. It's about two meters by three, and you are all welcome any time.(Laughter)Now, let's come to happiness or well-being. And first of all, you know, despite what the French intellectuals say, it seems that no one wakes up in the morning thinking, "May I suffer the whole day?"(Laughter)Which means that somehow, consciously or not, directly or indirectly, in the short or the long term, whatever we do, whatever we hope, whatever we dream — somehow, is related to a deep, profound desire for well-being or happiness. As Pascal said, even the one who hangs himself, somehow, is looking for cessation of suffering. He finds no other way. But then, if you look in the literature, East and West, you can find incredible diversity of definition of happiness. Some people say, I only believed in remembering the past, imagining the future, never the present. Some people say happiness is right now; it's the quality of the freshness of the present moment. And that led Henri Bergson, the French philosopher, to say, "All the great thinkers of humanity have left happiness in the vague so that each of them could define their own terms."Well, that would be fine if it was just a secondary preoccupation in life. But now, if it is something that is going to determine the quality of every instant of our life, then we better know what it is, have some clearer idea. And probably, the fact that we don't know that is why, so often, although we seek happiness, it seems we turn our back to it. Although we want to avoid suffering, it seems we are running somewhat towards it. And that can also come from some kind of confusions.One of the most common ones is happiness and pleasure. But if you look at the characteristics of those two, pleasure is contingent upon time, upon its object, upon the place. It is something that — changes of nature. Beautiful chocolate cake: first serving is delicious, second one not so much, then we feel disgust.(Laughter)That's the nature of things. We get tired. I used to be a fan of Bach. I used to play it on the guitar, you know. I can hear it two, three, five times. If I had to hear it 24 hours, non-stop, it might be very tiring. If you are feeling very cold, you come near a fire, it's so wonderful. After some moments, you just go a little back, and then it starts burning. It sort of uses itself as you experience it. And also, again, it can — also, it's something that you — it is not something that is radiating outside. Like, you can feel intense pleasure and some others around you can be suffering a lot.Now, what, then, will be happiness? And happiness, of course, is such a vague word, so let's say well-being. And so, I think the best definition, according to the Buddhist view, is that well-being is not just a mere pleasurable sensation. It is a deep sense of serenity and fulfillment. A state that actually pervades and underlies all emotional states, and all the joys and sorrows that can come one's way. For you, that might be surprising. Can we have this kind of well-being while being sad? In a way, why not? Because we are speaking of a different level.Look at the waves coming near the shore. When you are at the bottom of the wave, you hit the bottom. You hit the solid rock. When you are surfing on the top, you are all elated. So you go from elation to depression — there's no depth. Now, if you look at the high sea, there might be beautiful, calm ocean, like a mirror. There might be storms, but the depth of the ocean is still there, unchanged. So now, how is that? It can only be a state of being, not just a fleeting emotion, sensation. Even joy — that can be the spring of happiness. But there's also wicked joy, you can rejoice in someone's suffering.So how do we proceed in our quest for happiness? Very often, we look outside. We think that if we could gather this and that, all the conditions, something that we say, "Everything to be happy — to have everything to be happy." That very sentence already reveals the doom, destruction of happiness. To have everything. If we miss something, it collapses. And also, when things go wrong, we try to fix the outside so much, but our control of the outer world is limited, temporary, and often, illusory. So now, look at inner conditions. Aren't they stronger? Isn't it the mind that translates the outer condition into happiness and suffering? And isn't that stronger? We know, by experience, that we can be what we call "a little paradise," and yet, be completely unhappy within.The Dalai Lama was once in Portugal, and there was a lot of construction going on everywhere. So one evening, he said, "Look, you are doing all these things, but isn't it nice, also, to build something within?" And he said, "[Without] that — even if you get a high-tech flat on the 100th floor of a super-modern and comfortable building, if you are deeply unhappy within, all you are going to look for is a window from which to jump." So now, at the opposite, we know a lot of people who, in very difficult circumstances, manage to keep serenity, inner strength, inner freedom, confidence. So now, if the inner conditions are stronger — of course, the outer conditions do influence, and it's wonderful to live longer, healthier, to have access to information, education, to be able to travel, to have freedom. It's highly desirable. However, this is not enough. Those are just auxiliary, help conditions. The experience that translates everything is within the mind. So then, when we ask oneself how to nurture the condition for happiness, the inner conditions, and which are those which will undermine happiness. So then, this just needs to have some experience.We have to know from ourselves, there are certain states of mind that are conducive to this flourishing, to this well-being, what the Greeks called eudaimonia, flourishing. There are some which are adverse to this well-being. And so, if we look from our own experience, anger, hatred, jealousy, arrogance, obsessive desire, strong grasping, they don't leave us in such a good state after we have experienced it. And also, they are detrimental to others' happiness. So we may consider that the more those are invading our mind, and, like a chain reaction, the more we feel miserable, we feel tormented. At the opposite, everyone knows deep within that an act of selfless generosity, if from the distance, without anyone knowing anything about it, we could save a child's life, make someone happy. We don't need the recognition. We don't need any gratitude. Just the mere fact of doing that fills such a sense of adequation with our deep nature. And we would like to be like that all the time.So is that possible, to change our way of being, to transform one's mind? Aren't those negative emotions, or destructive emotions, inherent to the nature of mind? Is change possible in our emotions, in our traits, in our moods? For that we have to ask, what is the nature of mind? And if we look from the experiential point of view, there is a primary quality of consciousness that's just the mere fact to be cognitive, to be aware. Consciousness is like a mirror that allows all images to rise on it. You can have ugly faces, beautiful faces in the mirror. The mirror allows that, but the mirror is not tainted, is not modified, is not altered by those images. Likewise, behind every single thought there is the bare consciousness, pure awareness. This is the nature. It cannot be tainted intrinsically with hatred or jealousy because then, if it was always there — like a dye that would permeate the whole cloth — then it would be found all the time, somewhere. We know we're not always angry, always jealous, always generous.So, because the basic fabric of consciousness is this pure cognitive quality that differentiates it from a stone, there is a possibility for change because all emotions are fleeting. That is the ground for mind training. Mind training is based on the idea that two opposite mental factors cannot happen at the same time. You could go from love to hate. But you cannot, at the same time, toward the same object, the same person, want to harm and want to do good. You cannot, in the same gesture, shake hand and give a blow. So, there are natural antidotes to emotions that are destructive to our inner well-being. So that's the way to proceed. Rejoicing compared to jealousy. A kind of sense of inner freedom as opposite to intense grasping and obsession. Benevolence, loving kindness against hatred. But, of course, each emotion then would need a particular antidote.Another way is to try to find a general antidote to all emotions, and that's by looking at the very nature. Usually, when we feel annoyed, hatred or upset with someone, or obsessed with something, the mind goes again and again to that object. Each time it goes to the object, it reinforces that obsession or that annoyance. So then, it's a self-perpetuating process. So what we need to look for now is, instead of looking outward, we look inward. Look at anger itself. It looks very menacing, like a billowing monsoon cloud or thunderstorm. We think we could sit on the cloud, but if you go there, it's just mist. Likewise, if you look at the thought of anger, it will vanish like frost under the morning sun. If you do this again and again, the propensity, the tendencies for anger to arise again will be less and less each time you dissolve it. And, at the end, although it may rise, it will just cross the mind, like a bird crossing the sky without leaving any track. So this is the principal of mind training.Now, it takes time, because it took time for all those faults in our mind, the tendencies, to build up, so it will take time to unfold them as well. But that's the only way to go. Mind transformation — that is the very meaning of meditation. It means familiarization with a new way of being, new way of perceiving things, which is more in adequation with reality, with interdependence, with the stream and continuous transformation, which our being and our consciousness is.So, the interface with cognitive science, since we need to come to that, it was, I suppose, the subject of — we have to deal in such a short time — with brain plasticity. The brain was thought to be more or less fixed. All the nominal connections, in numbers and quantities, were thought, until the last 20 years, to be more or less fixed when we reached adult age. Now, recently, it has been found that it can change a lot. A violinist, as we heard, who has done 10,000 hours of violin practice, some area that controls the movements of fingers in the brain changes a lot, increasing reinforcement of the synaptic connections. So can we do that with human qualities? With loving kindness, with patience, with openness?So that's what those great meditators have been doing. Some of them who came to the labs, like in Madison, Wisconsin, or in Berkeley, did 20 to 40,000 hours of meditation. They do, like, three years' retreat, where they do meditate 12 hours a day. And then, the rest of their life, they will do three or four hours a day. They are real Olympic champions of mind training.(Laughter)This is the place where the meditators — you can see it's kind of inspiring. Now, here with 256 electrodes.(Laughter)So what did they find? Of course, same thing. The scientific embargo — if it's ever submitted to "Nature," hopefully, it will be accepted. It deals with the state of compassion, unconditional compassion. We asked meditators, who have been doing that for years and years, to put their mind in a state where there's nothing but loving kindness, total availability to sentient being. Of course, during the training, we do that with objects. We think of people suffering, of people we love, but at some point, it can be a state which is all pervading. Here is the preliminary result, which I can show because it's already been shown. The bell curve shows 150 controls, and what is being looked at is the difference between the right and the left frontal lobe. In very short, people who have more activity in the right side of the prefrontal cortex are more depressed, withdrawn. They don't describe a lot of positive affect. It's the opposite on the left side: more tendency to altruism, to happiness, to express, and curiosity and so forth. So there's a basic line for people. And also, it can be changed. If you see a comic movie, you go off to the left side. If you are happy about something, you'll go more to the left side. If you have a bout of depression, you'll go to the right side. Here, the -0.5 is the full standard deviation of a meditator who meditated on compassion. It's something that is totally out of the bell curve.So, I've no time to go into all the different scientific results. Hopefully, they will come. But they found that — this is after three and a half hours in an fMRI, it's like coming out of a space ship. Also, it has been shown in other labs — for instance, Paul Ekman's labs in Berkeley — that some meditators are able, also, to control their emotional response more than it could be thought. Like the startle experiments, for example. If you sit a guy on a chair with all this apparatus measuring your physiology, and there's kind of a bomb that goes off, it's such an instinctive response that, in 20 years, they never saw anyone who would not jump. Some meditators, without trying to stop it, but simply by being completely open, thinking that that bang is just going to be a small event like a shooting star, they are able not to move at all.So the whole point of that is not, sort of, to make, like, a circus thing of showing exceptional beings who can jump, or whatever. It's more to say that mind training matters. That this is not just a luxury. This is not a supplementary vitamin for the soul. This is something that's going to determine the quality of every instant of our lives. We are ready to spend 15 years achieving education. We love to do jogging, fitness. We do all kinds of things to remain beautiful. Yet, we spend surprisingly little time taking care of what matters most — the way our mind functions — which, again, is the ultimate thing that determines the quality of our experience.Now, compassion is supposed to be put in action. That's what we try to do in different places. Just this one example is worth a lot of work. This lady with bone TB, left alone in a tent, was going to die with her only daughter. One year later, how she is. Different schools and clinics we've been doing in Tibet.And just, I leave you with the beauty of those looks that tells more about happiness than I could ever say.(Laughter)And jumping monks of Tibet.(Laughter)Flying monks.Thank you very much.

whatever we dream --

00:02:52.857 --> 00:02:58.663
somehow, is related to a deep, profound
desire for well-being or happiness.

00:02:59.886 --> 00:03:03.303
As Pascal said,
even the one who hangs himself,

00:03:03.327 --> 00:03:07.581
somehow, is looking
for cessation of suffering.

00:03:08.391 --> 00:03:09.966
He finds no other way.

00:03:11.156 --> 00:03:14.443
But then, if you look
in the literature, East and West,

00:03:14.467 --> 00:03:19.389
you can find incredible diversity
of definition of happiness.

00:03:19.413 --> 00:03:23.934
Some people say, I only believed
in remembering the past,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.934
imagining the future, never the present.

00:03:26.415 --> 00:03:29.328
Some people say happiness is right now;

00:03:29.352 --> 00:03:32.247
it's the quality of the freshness
of the present moment.

00:03:33.640 --> 00:03:37.477
And that led Henri Bergson,
the French philosopher, to say,

00:03:37.501 --> 00:03:41.356
"All the great thinkers of humanity
have left happiness in the vague

00:03:41.380 --> 00:03:44.958
so that each of them
could define their own terms."

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:50.958
Well, that would be fine if it was just
a secondary preoccupation in life.

00:03:51.751 --> 00:03:54.728
But now, if it is something
that is going to determine

00:03:54.752 --> 00:03:57.529
the quality of every instant of our life,

00:03:57.553 --> 00:04:01.548
then we better know what it is,
have some clearer idea.

00:04:02.632 --> 00:04:07.934
And probably, the fact
that we don't know that is why, so often,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:11.223
although we seek happiness,
it seems we turn our back to it.

00:04:11.247 --> 00:04:13.042
Although we want to avoid suffering,

00:04:13.066 --> 00:04:15.202
it seems we are running
somewhat towards it.

00:04:16.147 --> 00:04:19.162
And that can also come
from some kind of confusions.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.528
One of the most common ones
is happiness and pleasure.

00:04:23.552 --> 00:04:27.534
But if you look at
the characteristics of those two,

00:04:27.558 --> 00:04:32.796
pleasure is contingent upon time,
upon its object,

00:04:32.820 --> 00:04:34.218
upon the place.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
It is something that -- changes of nature.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:43.515
Beautiful chocolate cake:
first serving is delicious,

00:04:43.539 --> 00:04:46.516
second one not so much,
then we feel disgust.

00:04:46.540 --> 00:04:49.315
(Laughter)

00:04:49.339 --> 00:04:50.862
That's the nature of things.

00:04:50.886 --> 00:04:52.086
We get tired.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.238
I used to be a fan of Bach.

00:04:55.262 --> 00:04:57.263
I used to play it on the guitar, you know.

00:04:57.287 --> 00:04:59.096
I can hear it two, three, five times.

00:04:59.120 --> 00:05:03.632
If I had to hear it 24 hours,
non-stop, it might be very tiring.

00:05:04.220 --> 00:05:08.010
If you are feeling very cold,
you come near a fire, it's so wonderful.

00:05:08.401 --> 00:05:10.550
After some moments,
you just go a little back,

00:05:10.574 --> 00:05:11.895
and then it starts burning.

00:05:12.601 --> 00:05:16.114
It sort of uses itself
as you experience it.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.934
And also, again, it can --
also, it's something that you --

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.149
it is not something
that is radiating outside.

00:05:25.173 --> 00:05:27.439
Like, you can feel intense pleasure

00:05:27.463 --> 00:05:30.413
and some others around you
can be suffering a lot.

00:05:32.112 --> 00:05:34.934
Now, what, then, will be happiness?

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.840
And happiness, of course, is such
a vague word, so let's say well-being.

00:05:41.370 --> 00:05:45.698
And so, I think the best definition,
according to the Buddhist view,

00:05:45.722 --> 00:05:51.276
is that well-being is not just
a mere pleasurable sensation.

00:05:53.108 --> 00:05:57.006
It is a deep sense
of serenity and fulfillment.

00:05:58.999 --> 00:06:05.355
A state that actually pervades

00:06:05.379 --> 00:06:09.100
and underlies all emotional states,

00:06:09.124 --> 00:06:11.989
and all the joys and sorrows
that can come one's way.

00:06:13.446 --> 00:06:15.569
For you, that might be surprising.

00:06:15.593 --> 00:06:18.450
Can we have this kind of well-being
while being sad?

00:06:19.165 --> 00:06:20.432
In a way, why not?

00:06:21.201 --> 00:06:23.958
Because we are speaking
of a different level.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.850
Look at the waves coming near the shore.

00:06:30.878 --> 00:06:33.689
When you are at the bottom
of the wave, you hit the bottom.

00:06:34.838 --> 00:06:36.559
You hit the solid rock.

00:06:36.583 --> 00:06:39.228
When you are surfing on the top,
you are all elated.

00:06:39.252 --> 00:06:42.139
So you go from elation
to depression -- there's no depth.

00:06:43.577 --> 00:06:46.719
Now, if you look at the high sea,

00:06:46.743 --> 00:06:50.166
there might be beautiful,
calm ocean, like a mirror.

00:06:50.491 --> 00:06:52.613
There might be storms,

00:06:52.637 --> 00:06:56.967
but the depth of the ocean
is still there, unchanged.

00:06:58.467 --> 00:06:59.934
So now, how is that?

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:04.699
It can only be a state of being,
not just a fleeting emotion, sensation.

00:07:04.723 --> 00:07:08.469
Even joy -- that can be
the spring of happiness.

00:07:08.493 --> 00:07:12.023
But there's also wicked joy,
you can rejoice in someone's suffering.

00:07:13.395 --> 00:07:16.728
So how do we proceed
in our quest for happiness?

00:07:17.923 --> 00:07:20.875
Very often, we look outside.

00:07:21.568 --> 00:07:25.872
We think that if we could gather
this and that, all the conditions,

00:07:25.896 --> 00:07:28.934
something that we say,
"Everything to be happy --

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.214
to have everything to be happy."

00:07:31.238 --> 00:07:35.654
That very sentence already reveals
the doom, destruction of happiness.

00:07:35.678 --> 00:07:36.933
To have everything.

00:07:36.957 --> 00:07:39.180
If we miss something, it collapses.

00:07:40.783 --> 00:07:44.582
And also, when things go wrong,
we try to fix the outside so much,

00:07:44.606 --> 00:07:50.118
but our control
of the outer world is limited,

00:07:50.142 --> 00:07:53.007
temporary, and often, illusory.

00:07:54.061 --> 00:07:57.022
So now, look at inner conditions.

00:07:57.046 --> 00:07:58.447
Aren't they stronger?

00:07:58.471 --> 00:08:01.236
Isn't it the mind that translates

00:08:01.260 --> 00:08:03.749
the outer condition
into happiness and suffering?

00:08:04.106 --> 00:08:05.934
And isn't that stronger?

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.707
We know, by experience,

00:08:07.731 --> 00:08:11.065
that we can be
what we call "a little paradise,"

00:08:11.089 --> 00:08:14.098
and yet, be completely unhappy within.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.146
The Dalai Lama was once in Portugal,

00:08:18.170 --> 00:08:20.934
and there was a lot of construction
going on everywhere.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
So one evening, he said,
"Look, you are doing all these things,

00:08:23.982 --> 00:08:26.934
but isn't it nice, also,
to build something within?"

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:31.934
And he said, "[Without] that --
even if you get a high-tech flat

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:37.208
on the 100th floor of a super-modern
and comfortable building,

00:08:37.232 --> 00:08:38.934
if you are deeply unhappy within,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
all you are going to look for
is a window from which to jump."

00:08:44.408 --> 00:08:45.934
So now, at the opposite,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:50.394
we know a lot of people who,
in very difficult circumstances,

00:08:50.418 --> 00:08:55.789
manage to keep serenity, inner strength,
inner freedom, confidence.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.197
So now, if the inner conditions
are stronger --

00:08:59.221 --> 00:09:01.844
of course, the outer
conditions do influence,

00:09:01.868 --> 00:09:05.452
and it's wonderful to live
longer, healthier,

00:09:05.476 --> 00:09:08.269
to have access to information, education,

00:09:08.293 --> 00:09:10.246
to be able to travel, to have freedom.

00:09:10.967 --> 00:09:13.463
It's highly desirable.

00:09:13.487 --> 00:09:15.046
However, this is not enough.

00:09:15.070 --> 00:09:19.406
Those are just auxiliary, help conditions.

00:09:20.261 --> 00:09:23.740
The experience that translates
everything is within the mind.

00:09:24.441 --> 00:09:26.126
So then, when we ask oneself

00:09:26.150 --> 00:09:30.530
how to nurture
the condition for happiness,

00:09:30.554 --> 00:09:35.998
the inner conditions, and which are those
which will undermine happiness.

00:09:36.766 --> 00:09:39.742
So then, this just needs
to have some experience.

00:09:40.147 --> 00:09:43.202
We have to know from ourselves,
there are certain states of mind

00:09:43.226 --> 00:09:46.535
that are conducive to this flourishing,
to this well-being,

00:09:46.559 --> 00:09:49.148
what the Greeks called
eudaimonia, flourishing.

00:09:50.846 --> 00:09:54.514
There are some which are adverse
to this well-being.

00:09:55.703 --> 00:09:59.262
And so, if we look
from our own experience,

00:09:59.286 --> 00:10:03.495
anger, hatred, jealousy, arrogance,

00:10:03.519 --> 00:10:08.284
obsessive desire, strong grasping,

00:10:08.308 --> 00:10:12.061
they don't leave us in such a good state
after we have experienced it.

00:10:12.655 --> 00:10:15.655
And also, they are detrimental
to others' happiness.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:21.644
So we may consider that the more
those are invading our mind,

00:10:21.668 --> 00:10:23.319
and, like a chain reaction,

00:10:23.343 --> 00:10:26.576
the more we feel miserable,
we feel tormented.

00:10:27.497 --> 00:10:31.047
At the opposite,
everyone knows deep within

00:10:31.071 --> 00:10:33.270
that an act of selfless generosity,

00:10:33.294 --> 00:10:37.579
if from the distance, without anyone
knowing anything about it,

00:10:37.603 --> 00:10:41.805
we could save a child's life,
make someone happy.

00:10:41.829 --> 00:10:45.379
We don't need the recognition.
We don't need any gratitude.

00:10:45.403 --> 00:10:48.124
Just the mere fact of doing that

00:10:48.148 --> 00:10:51.881
fills such a sense of adequation
with our deep nature.

00:10:52.568 --> 00:10:54.764
And we would like to be
like that all the time.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.539
So is that possible,

00:10:57.563 --> 00:11:01.163
to change our way of being,
to transform one's mind?

00:11:02.468 --> 00:11:05.934
Aren't those negative emotions,
or destructive emotions,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.044
inherent to the nature of mind?

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:14.028
Is change possible in our emotions,
in our traits, in our moods?

00:11:14.822 --> 00:11:17.400
For that we have to ask,
what is the nature of mind?

00:11:17.870 --> 00:11:22.432
And if we look from
the experiential point of view,

00:11:22.456 --> 00:11:24.934
there is a primary
quality of consciousness

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.451
that's just the mere fact
to be cognitive, to be aware.

00:11:30.108 --> 00:11:34.618
Consciousness is like a mirror
that allows all images to rise on it.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:38.092
You can have ugly faces,
beautiful faces in the mirror.

00:11:38.116 --> 00:11:41.588
The mirror allows that,
but the mirror is not tainted,

00:11:41.612 --> 00:11:45.013
is not modified,
is not altered by those images.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.891
Likewise, behind every single thought

00:11:48.915 --> 00:11:53.007
there is the bare consciousness,
pure awareness.

00:11:53.765 --> 00:11:55.080
This is the nature.

00:11:55.104 --> 00:11:59.705
It cannot be tainted intrinsically
with hatred or jealousy because then,

00:11:59.729 --> 00:12:01.336
if it was always there --

00:12:01.360 --> 00:12:05.264
like a dye that would permeate
the whole cloth --

00:12:05.288 --> 00:12:08.156
then it would be found
all the time, somewhere.

00:12:08.180 --> 00:12:12.033
We know we're not always angry,
always jealous, always generous.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.934
So, because the basic
fabric of consciousness

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:20.250
is this pure cognitive quality
that differentiates it from a stone,

00:12:20.274 --> 00:12:23.521
there is a possibility for change
because all emotions are fleeting.

00:12:24.100 --> 00:12:26.236
That is the ground for mind training.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:31.772
Mind training is based on the idea
that two opposite mental factors

00:12:31.796 --> 00:12:33.621
cannot happen at the same time.

00:12:34.061 --> 00:12:36.010
You could go from love to hate.

00:12:36.034 --> 00:12:39.251
But you cannot, at the same time,
toward the same object,

00:12:39.275 --> 00:12:42.654
the same person, want to harm
and want to do good.

00:12:42.678 --> 00:12:46.401
You cannot, in the same gesture,
shake hand and give a blow.

00:12:47.385 --> 00:12:50.645
So, there are natural
antidotes to emotions

00:12:50.669 --> 00:12:53.065
that are destructive
to our inner well-being.

00:12:54.401 --> 00:12:56.426
So that's the way to proceed.

00:12:56.904 --> 00:12:59.745
Rejoicing compared to jealousy.

00:13:00.408 --> 00:13:02.768
A kind of sense of inner freedom

00:13:02.792 --> 00:13:06.494
as opposite to intense
grasping and obsession.

00:13:07.702 --> 00:13:12.063
Benevolence, loving kindness
against hatred.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.943
But, of course, each emotion then
would need a particular antidote.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:22.934
Another way is to try to find
a general antidote to all emotions,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.084
and that's by looking at the very nature.

00:13:25.838 --> 00:13:31.297
Usually, when we feel annoyed,
hatred or upset with someone,

00:13:31.321 --> 00:13:33.614
or obsessed with something,

00:13:33.638 --> 00:13:36.172
the mind goes again
and again to that object.

00:13:36.196 --> 00:13:38.022
Each time it goes to the object,

00:13:38.046 --> 00:13:41.101
it reinforces that obsession
or that annoyance.

00:13:41.704 --> 00:13:44.944
So then, it's a self-perpetuating process.

00:13:45.672 --> 00:13:47.432
So what we need to look for now is,

00:13:47.456 --> 00:13:50.045
instead of looking outward,
we look inward.

00:13:50.798 --> 00:13:52.142
Look at anger itself.

00:13:52.166 --> 00:13:53.704
It looks very menacing,

00:13:53.728 --> 00:13:58.166
like a billowing monsoon cloud
or thunderstorm.

00:13:58.615 --> 00:14:00.878
We think we could sit on the cloud,

00:14:00.902 --> 00:14:02.958
but if you go there, it's just mist.

00:14:03.283 --> 00:14:06.425
Likewise, if you look
at the thought of anger,

00:14:06.449 --> 00:14:09.638
it will vanish like frost
under the morning sun.

00:14:10.336 --> 00:14:13.195
If you do this again
and again, the propensity,

00:14:13.219 --> 00:14:15.934
the tendencies for anger to arise again

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.812
will be less and less
each time you dissolve it.

00:14:19.307 --> 00:14:21.320
And, at the end, although it may rise,

00:14:21.344 --> 00:14:22.934
it will just cross the mind,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.629
like a bird crossing the sky
without leaving any track.

00:14:26.328 --> 00:14:28.804
So this is the principal of mind training.

00:14:30.156 --> 00:14:33.661
Now, it takes time,

00:14:33.685 --> 00:14:40.656
because it took time for all those faults
in our mind, the tendencies, to build up,

00:14:40.680 --> 00:14:42.934
so it will take time
to unfold them as well.

00:14:43.445 --> 00:14:44.934
But that's the only way to go.

00:14:45.405 --> 00:14:49.196
Mind transformation --
that is the very meaning of meditation.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.934
It means familiarization
with a new way of being,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.612
new way of perceiving things,

00:14:54.636 --> 00:14:56.934
which is more in adequation with reality,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:00.934
with interdependence, with the stream
and continuous transformation,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.104
which our being and our consciousness is.

00:15:03.917 --> 00:15:05.894
So, the interface with cognitive science,

00:15:05.918 --> 00:15:09.078
since we need to come to that,
it was, I suppose, the subject of --

00:15:09.102 --> 00:15:12.626
we have to deal in such a short time --
with brain plasticity.

00:15:12.650 --> 00:15:15.623
The brain was thought
to be more or less fixed.

00:15:15.647 --> 00:15:18.289
All the nominal connections,
in numbers and quantities,

00:15:18.313 --> 00:15:21.254
were thought, until the last 20 years,

00:15:21.278 --> 00:15:24.745
to be more or less fixed
when we reached adult age.

00:15:25.182 --> 00:15:27.934
Now, recently, it has been found
that it can change a lot.

00:15:28.453 --> 00:15:32.355
A violinist, as we heard, who has done
10,000 hours of violin practice,

00:15:32.379 --> 00:15:37.200
some area that controls the movements
of fingers in the brain changes a lot,

00:15:37.224 --> 00:15:40.176
increasing reinforcement
of the synaptic connections.

00:15:41.238 --> 00:15:44.532
So can we do that with human qualities?

00:15:44.556 --> 00:15:48.283
With loving kindness,
with patience, with openness?

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:52.074
So that's what those great
meditators have been doing.

00:15:53.176 --> 00:15:56.686
Some of them who came to the labs,

00:15:56.710 --> 00:16:00.610
like in Madison, Wisconsin,
or in Berkeley,

00:16:00.634 --> 00:16:03.924
did 20 to 40,000 hours of meditation.

00:16:04.734 --> 00:16:08.262
They do, like, three years' retreat,
where they do meditate 12 hours a day.

00:16:08.286 --> 00:16:11.746
And then, the rest of their life,
they will do three or four hours a day.

00:16:11.770 --> 00:16:14.747
They are real Olympic
champions of mind training.

00:16:14.771 --> 00:16:16.272
(Laughter)

00:16:17.772 --> 00:16:21.616
This is the place where the meditators --
you can see it's kind of inspiring.

00:16:21.640 --> 00:16:25.327
Now, here with 256 electrodes.

00:16:27.775 --> 00:16:30.467
(Laughter)

00:16:30.854 --> 00:16:32.035
So what did they find?

00:16:32.059 --> 00:16:34.934
Of course, same thing.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.655
The scientific embargo --

00:16:36.679 --> 00:16:40.853
if it's ever submitted to "Nature,"
hopefully, it will be accepted.

00:16:41.204 --> 00:16:45.195
It deals with the state of compassion,
unconditional compassion.

00:16:45.219 --> 00:16:48.934
We asked meditators, who have
been doing that for years and years,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:53.651
to put their mind in a state
where there's nothing but loving kindness,

00:16:53.675 --> 00:16:55.651
total availability to sentient being.

00:16:56.109 --> 00:16:58.735
Of course, during the training,
we do that with objects.

00:16:58.759 --> 00:17:01.045
We think of people suffering,
of people we love,

00:17:01.069 --> 00:17:04.083
but at some point, it can be
a state which is all pervading.

00:17:05.122 --> 00:17:07.641
Here is the preliminary result,

00:17:07.665 --> 00:17:09.995
which I can show
because it's already been shown.

00:17:10.019 --> 00:17:14.919
The bell curve shows 150 controls,

00:17:14.943 --> 00:17:17.132
and what is being looked at

00:17:17.156 --> 00:17:20.524
is the difference between the right
and the left frontal lobe.

00:17:20.548 --> 00:17:23.383
In very short, people
who have more activity

00:17:23.407 --> 00:17:26.070
in the right side of the prefrontal cortex

00:17:26.094 --> 00:17:29.087
are more depressed, withdrawn.

00:17:29.570 --> 00:17:32.220
They don't describe
a lot of positive affect.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.898
It's the opposite on the left side:

00:17:35.922 --> 00:17:37.934
more tendency to altruism,

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:42.097
to happiness, to express,
and curiosity and so forth.

00:17:42.695 --> 00:17:46.788
So there's a basic line for people.
And also, it can be changed.

00:17:46.812 --> 00:17:49.336
If you see a comic movie,
you go off to the left side.

00:17:49.360 --> 00:17:52.776
If you are happy about something,
you'll go more to the left side.

00:17:52.800 --> 00:17:55.705
If you have a bout of depression,
you'll go to the right side.

00:17:56.508 --> 00:18:02.214
Here, the -0.5 is the full
standard deviation

00:18:02.238 --> 00:18:04.934
of a meditator
who meditated on compassion.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.783
It's something that is totally out
of the bell curve.

00:18:09.090 --> 00:18:12.934
So, I've no time to go
into all the different scientific results.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.496
Hopefully, they will come.

00:18:14.520 --> 00:18:17.291
But they found that --
this is after three and a half hours

00:18:17.315 --> 00:18:19.258
in an fMRI,

00:18:19.282 --> 00:18:22.375
it's like coming out of a space ship.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:25.934
Also, it has been shown in other labs --

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:29.934
for instance,
Paul Ekman's labs in Berkeley --

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:32.493
that some meditators are able, also,

00:18:32.517 --> 00:18:35.934
to control their emotional response
more than it could be thought.

00:18:36.355 --> 00:18:38.370
Like the startle experiments, for example.

00:18:38.394 --> 00:18:39.925
If you sit a guy on a chair

00:18:39.949 --> 00:18:42.378
with all this apparatus
measuring your physiology,

00:18:42.402 --> 00:18:44.370
and there's kind of a bomb that goes off,

00:18:44.394 --> 00:18:46.934
it's such an instinctive response that,

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:50.550
in 20 years, they never saw
anyone who would not jump.

00:18:51.414 --> 00:18:53.934
Some meditators,
without trying to stop it,

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.332
but simply by being completely open,

00:18:56.356 --> 00:19:01.934
thinking that that bang is just going
to be a small event like a shooting star,

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.595
they are able not to move at all.

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:07.934
So the whole point of that is not,
sort of, to make, like,

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:14.759
a circus thing of showing exceptional
beings who can jump, or whatever.

00:19:14.783 --> 00:19:17.630
It's more to say
that mind training matters.

00:19:18.149 --> 00:19:21.432
That this is not just a luxury.

00:19:21.456 --> 00:19:25.854
This is not a supplementary
vitamin for the soul.

00:19:25.878 --> 00:19:29.610
This is something
that's going to determine

00:19:29.634 --> 00:19:31.695
the quality of every instant of our lives.

00:19:31.719 --> 00:19:35.339
We are ready to spend 15 years
achieving education.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:38.934
We love to do jogging, fitness.

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:41.879
We do all kinds of things
to remain beautiful.

00:19:42.870 --> 00:19:49.847
Yet, we spend surprisingly little time
taking care of what matters most --

00:19:49.871 --> 00:19:52.115
the way our mind functions --

00:19:52.139 --> 00:19:55.886
which, again, is the ultimate thing

00:19:55.910 --> 00:19:58.076
that determines
the quality of our experience.

00:19:58.573 --> 00:20:01.448
Now, compassion
is supposed to be put in action.

00:20:01.830 --> 00:20:04.269
That's what we try to do
in different places.

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:08.609
Just this one example
is worth a lot of work.

00:20:09.254 --> 00:20:12.136
This lady with bone TB,
left alone in a tent,

00:20:12.160 --> 00:20:14.891
was going to die with her only daughter.

00:20:15.386 --> 00:20:17.567
One year later, how she is.

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:23.411
Different schools and clinics
we've been doing in Tibet.

00:20:26.437 --> 00:20:30.643
And just, I leave you
with the beauty of those looks

00:20:30.667 --> 00:20:34.676
that tells more about happiness
than I could ever say.

00:20:34.700 --> 00:20:35.843
(Laughter)

00:20:35.867 --> 00:20:37.327
And jumping monks of Tibet.

00:20:37.351 --> 00:20:38.934
(Laughter)

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:40.606
Flying monks.
